member.name: T:Au.AAcc
member.summary: Accessible object. Finds controls and smaller objects in a window or web page. Clicks, gets properties, etc.
member.remarks:
Accessible objects (AO) are various user interface (UI) objects in windows and controls. For example buttons, links, list items. This class can find them, get properties, click, etc. Especially useful with web pages, because there are no controls. And many other windows don't use controls but support AO. But not all UI objects are AO.
An AAcc instance holds an AO COM pointer (IAccessible) and a simple element id (int). Most AAcc functions wrap IAccessible interface functions or/and related API.
AAcc functions that get properties don't throw exception when the wrapped IAccessible/etc function failed (returned an error code of HRESULT type). Then they return "" (string properties), 0, false, null or empty collection, dependin on return type. Applications implement AOs differently, often with bugs, and their IAccessible interface functions return a variety of error codes. It's impossible to reliably detect whether the error code means a serious error or the property is merely unavailable. These AAcc functions also set the last error code of this thread = the return value (HRESULT) of the IAccessible function, and callers can use to get it. If ALastError.Code returns 1 (S_FALSE), in most cases it's not an error, just the property is unavailable. On error it will probably be a negative error code.
You can dispose AAcc variables to release the COM object, but it is not necessary (GC will do it later).
An AAcc variable cannot be used in multiple threads. Only Dispose can be called in any thread.
AOs are implemented and live in their applications. This class just communicates with them.
Many applications have various problems with their AOs: bugs, incorrect/nonstandard/partial implementation, or initially disabled. This class implements workarounds for known problems, where possible.
Known problematic applications
Application Problems
Chrome web browser. Also Opera and other apps that use Chrome code. Window class name is like "Chrome_WidgetWin_1".
Web page AOs initially are disabled(missing). Workarounds:
Functions Find, Wait and FindAll enable it if used role prefix "web:" or "chrome:". Functions FromXY, FromMouse and Focused enable it if window class name starts with "Chrome". However Chrome does it lazily, therefore first time the functions often get wrong AO. Note: this auto-enabing may fail with future Chrome versions.
Start Chrome with command line --force-renderer-accessibility.
In the future the script editor will have an option to enable Chrome AOs when it starts.
Some new web browser versions add new features or bugs that break something.
Firefox web browser.
By default, the Find function is about 50 times slower than it could be. Also for this reason the Wait function consumes much CPU. And HTML attributes may be unavailable. See . Workaround: disable the Firefox multiprocess feature: set system environment variable MOZ_FORCE_DISABLE_E10S=1 and restart Firefox. Note: Firefox may remove this option in the future. If this does not work, google how to disable Firefox multiprocess. Or use Chrome instead.
When Firefox starts, its web page AOs are unavailable. It creates them only when somebody asks (eg function Find), but does it lazily, and Find at first fails. Workaround: use Wait, not Find.
Ocassionally Firefox briefly turns off its web page AOs. Workaround: use Wait, not Find. With other web browsers also it's better to use Wait.
Some new web browser versions add new features or bugs that break something.
Edge web browser, JavaFX and other applications that don't have true accessible objects but have UI Automation elements.
To find AOs in these applications, need flag .
Java applications that use AWT/Swing. Window class name starts with "SunAwt".
Not supported on 32-bit OS.
Must be enabled Java Access Bridge (JAB).
If JAB is disabled or does not work, the "Find accessible object" tool shows an "enable" link when you try to capture something in a Java window. The link calls Au.Tools.FormAAcc.Java.EnableDisableJabUI. Or you can enable JAB in Control Panel -> Ease of Access Center -> Use the computer without a display. Or use jabswitch.exe. Then restart Java apps. Also may need to restart apps that tried to use Java AOs.
Your process must have the same 32/64 bitness as the installed Java. To remove this limitation, install Java 32-bit and 64-bit (they coexist).
OpenOffice.
Often crashes after using AOs, usually when closing. Noticed in OpenOffice 4.1.4; may be fixed in newer versions.
LibreOffice.
AOs are unavailable unless this process is 32-bit (when LibreOffice is 64-bit). Also need flag .
Some controls.
AOs of some controls are not connected to the AO of the parent control. Then Find cannot find them if searches in whole window.
Workaround: search only in that control. For example, use prop "class" or "id". If it's a web browser control, use role prefix "web:". Or find the control with and search in it. Or use .
Some controls with flag .
AOs of many standard Windows controls have bugs when they are retrieved without loading dll into the target process (see ). Known bugs:
Toolbar buttons don't have Name in some cases.
and often don't work properly.
Workarounds: Don't use . Or use .
When cannot load dll into the target process. For example Windows Store apps.
Function Find is much slower. Function Wait then consumes much more CPU. More info: .
Processes of a different 32/64 bitness than this process.
To load the dll is used rundll32.exe, which makes slower by about 50 ms first time.
DPI-scaled windows.
Currently this library does not support auto-scaled windows when using high DPI (text size 125%, 150% or more). If the target process is auto-scaled and this process isn't (or vice versa, or they have a different scaling factor), most coordinate-related functions don't work properly. For example, they get wrong AO rectangles.

member.summary: Creates AAcc from IAccessible and child id. By default does not AddRef. iacc must not be Is0.

member.summary: Creates AAcc from Cpp_Acc. By default does not AddRef. x.acc must not be Is0.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc._Set(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,Au.AAcc._Misc,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets fields. _iacc must be 0, iacc not 0.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Dispose
member.summary: Releases IAccessible COM object and clears this variable.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.SimpleElementId
member.summary: Gets or changes simple element id, also known as child id.
member.remarks: Most accessible objects (AO) are not simple elements. Then this property is 0. Often (but not always) this property is the 1-based item index in parent AO. For example LISTITEM in LIST. The 'set' function sometimes can be used as a fast alternative to . It modifies only this variable. It does not check whether the value is valid. Simple elements cannot have child AOs.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.MiscFlags
member.summary: Returns some additional info about this variable, such as how the accessible object was retrieved (inproc, UIA, Java).

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Level
member.summary: Gets or sets indentation level for .
member.remarks: When Find or similar function finds an accessible object, it sets this property of the AAcc variable. If FromXY etc, it is 0 (unknown). When searching in a window, at level 0 are direct children of the WINDOW object. When searching in controls (specified class or id), at level 0 is the object of the control; however if used path, at level 0 are direct children. When searching in AAcc, at level 0 are direct children of the AAcc. When searching in web page (role prefix "web:" etc), at level 0 is the web page object (role DOCUMENT or PANE).

member.name: P:Au.AAcc._Disposed
member.summary: Returns true if this variable is disposed.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Focused(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the accessible object that has the keyboard focus. Returns null if fails.
member.param: Use UI Automation API. Need this with windows that don't support accessible objects but support UI Automation elements. Can be used with most other windows too. More info: .

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.FromEvent(Au.AWnd,Au.Types.AccOBJID,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the accessible object that generated the event that is currently being processed by the callback function used with API SetWinEventHook or . Returns null if failed. Suports .
member.remarks: The parameters are of the callback function. Uses API AccessibleObjectFromEvent. Often fails because the object already does not exist, because the callback function is called asynchronously, especially when the event is OBJECT_DESTROY, OBJECT_HIDE, SYSTEM_*END. Returns null if failed. Always check the return value, to avoid NullReferenceException. An exception in the callback function kills this process.

member.name: T:Au.AAcc._FuncId
member.summary: Used only for debug.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc._Hresult(Au.AAcc._FuncId,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls Native.SetError and returns hr. In Debug config also outputs error in red. If hr looks like not an error but just the property or action is unavailable, changes it to S_FALSE and does not show error. These are: S_FALSE, DISP_E_MEMBERNOTFOUND, E_NOTIMPL. _FuncId also can be char, like (_FuncId)'n' for name.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.ToString
member.summary: Formats string from main properties of this accessible object.
member.remarks: The string starts with role. Other properties have format like x="value", where x is a property character like with ; character e is . HTML attributes have format @name="value". In string values are used C# escape sequences, for example \r\n for new line. Indentation depends on .

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.PrintAll(Au.AWnd,System.String,Au.Types.AFFlags,System.String)
member.summary: Displays properties of all found accessible objects of window w.
member.remarks: Uses . Catches exceptions. On exception writes to the output: $"!exception! exceptionType exceptionMessage". Parameters are of . By default skips invisible objects and objects in menus. Use flags to include them. Chrome web page accessible objects normally are disabled (missing) when it starts. Use role prefix "web:" or "chrome:" to enable. See example.

member.name: T:Au.AAcc.Finder

member.remarks: Can be used instead of .

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Finder.ResultProperty
member.summary: The requested propery of the found accessible object, depending on . null if: 1. Object not found. 2. ResultGetProperty not used or is '-'. 3. Failed to get the property.
member.remarks: The type depends on the property. Most properties are String. Others: , , , .

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Finder.ResultGetProperty
member.summary: Set this when you need only some property of the accessible object (name, etc) and not the object itself. The value is a character, the same as with , for example 'n' for Name. Use '-' if you don't need any property.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Finder.Find(Au.AWnd,Au.AWnd.ChildFinder)
member.summary: Finds accessible object (AO) in the specified control of window w. Returns true if found. The property will be the found AO.
member.param: Window that contains the control.
Control properties. This functions searches in all matching controls.
member.remarks: Alternatively you can specify control class name or id in role. How this function is different: 1. Allows to specify more control properties. 2. Works better/faster when the control is of a different process or thread than the parent window; else slightly slower.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Finder.Find(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Finds accessible object (AO) in window w, like . Returns true if found. The property will be the found AO.
member.param: Window or control that contains the AO.
member.exception: - role is "" or invalid. - name is invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression). - prop has invalid format or contains unknown property names or invalid wildcard expressions. - flag when searching in web page (role prefix "web:" etc).
Failed. For example, window of a higher [](xref:uac) integrity level process.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Find(Au.AWnd,System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.AFFlags,System.Func{Au.AAcc,System.Boolean},System.Int32,System.String,Au.AWnd.ChildFinder)
member.summary: Finds an accessible object (AO) in window. Returns the found AO. Returns null if not found.
member.param: Window or control that contains the AO.

AO role, like "LINK". Or path, like "ROLE/ROLE/ROLE". Can have prefix "web:", "firefox:" or "chrome:" which means "search only in web page" and enables Chrome AOs. Case-sensitive. Not wildcard. null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "". More info in Remarks.
AO name (). String format: [](xref:wildcard_expression). null means 'any'. "" means 'empty or unavailable'.
Other AO properties and search settings. Example: "description=xxx\0 @href=yyy". More info in Remarks.
Callback function. Called for each matching AO. Let it return true if this is the wanted AO. Example: the AO must contain point x y: o => o.GetRect(out var r, o.WndTopLevel) && r.Contains(266, 33)
0-based index of matching AO. For example, if 1, the function skips the first matching AO and returns the second.
If not null, the specified object is an intermediate object. After finding it, call with this string and return its result.

Defines child controls where to search. This is an alternative for class/id in prop. Allows to specify more control properties. Works better/faster when the control is of a different process or thread than the parent window; else slightly slower.
member.exception: - role is "" or invalid. - name is invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression). - prop has invalid format or contains unknown property names or invalid wildcard expressions. - navig string is invalid. - flags has when searching in web page (role prefix "web:" etc).
Failed. For example, window of a higher [](xref:uac) integrity level process.
member.remarks:
To create code for this function, use dialog "Find accessible object". It is form Au.Tools.FormAAcc in Au.Tools.dll.
Walks the tree of accessible objects, until finds a matching AO.
Uses . You can use it directly. See example.
In wildcard expressions supports PCRE regular expressions (prefix "**r ") but not .NET regular expressions (prefix "**R "). They are similar.
To find web page AOs usually it's better to use instead, it's more reliable.
More info in topic.
##### About the role parameter
Can be standard role (see ) like "LINK" or custom role like "div". More info: .
Can have a prefix: - "web:" - search only in the visible web page, not in whole window. Examples: "web:LINK", "web:/LIST/LISTITEM/LINK".\ Supports Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer (IE) and apps that use their code. With other windows, searches in the first found visible AO that has DOCUMENT role.\ Tip: To search only NOT in web pages, use prop "notin=DOCUMENT" (Chrome, Firefox) or "notin=PANE" (IE). - "firefox:" - search only in the visible web page of Firefox or Firefox-based web browser. If w window class name starts with "Mozilla", can be used "web:" instead. - "chrome:" - search only in the visible web page of Chrome or Chrome-based web browser. If w window class name starts with "Chrome", can be used "web:" instead.
Chrome web page accessible objects normally are disabled (don't exist). Use prefix "web:" or "chrome:" to enable.
Prefix cannot be used: - if prop contains "id" or "class"; - with flag ; - with the non-static Find overload (searching in an AO).
Can be path consisting of roles separated by "/". Examples: - "web:DOCUMENT/div/LIST/LISTITEM/LINK" - find LINK using its full path in web page. - "web:/div/LIST//LINK" - the empty parts mean 'any role'. For example don't need to specify DOCUMENT because in web pages the first part is always DOCUMENT (Firefox, Chrome) or PANE (IE). - "web:/div/LIST[4]/LISTITEM[-1]/LINK" - the 4 is 1-based index of div child from which to start searching (4-th, then 3-th, 5-th and so on). It can make faster. Negative means 'index from end', for example use -1 to search in reverse order. Flag is not applied to path parts with an index. If index is invalid, will use the nearest valid index. - "web:/div/LIST[4!]/LISTITEM[-1!]/LINK" - like the above, but the LIST must be exactly 4-th child (don't search 3-th, 5-th etc) and the LISTITEM must be the last child. This can be useful when waiting (uses less CPU), however useless if AO indices in the window or web page change often. - "web://[4]/[-1!]/[2]" - index without role. - "CLIENT/WINDOW/TREE/TREEITEM[-1]" - path in window or control. The first path part is a direct child AO of the WINDOW AO of the window/control. The WINDOW AO itself is not included in the search; if you need it, instead use .
##### About the prop parameter
Format: one or more "name=value", separated with "\0" or "\0 ", like "description=xxx\0 @href=yyy". Names must match case. Values of string properties are wildcard expressions.
- "class" - search only in child controls that have this class name (see ). Cannot be used when searching in an AO. - "id" - search only in child controls that have this id (see ). If the value is not a number - Windows Forms control name (see ); case-sensitive, not wildcard. Cannot be used when searching in an AO. - "value" - . - "description" - . - "state" - . List of states that the AO must have and/or not have. Example: "state=CHECKED, FOCUSABLE, !DISABLED". Example: "state=0x100010, !0x1". Will find AO that has all states without "!" prefix and does not have any of states with "!" prefix. - "rect" - . Can be specified left, top, width and/or height, using format. Example: "rect={L=1155 T=1182 W=132 H=13}". Example: "rect={W=132 T=1182}". The L T coordinates are relative to the primary screen. - "level" - level (see ) at which the AO can be found. Can be exact level, or minimal and maximal level separated by space. The default value is 0 1000. Alternatively you can use path in role, like "////LINK". - "elem" - . - "action" - . - "key" - . - "help" - . - "uiaid" - . - "maxcc" - when searching, skip children of AO that have more than this number of direct children. It can make faster. The default value is 10000. It also prevents hanging or crashing when an AO in the object tree has large number of children. For example OpenOffice Calc TABLE has one billion children. - "notin" - when searching, skip children of AO that have these roles. It can make faster. Example: "notin=TREE,LIST,TOOLBAR". Roles in the list must be separated with "," or ", ". Case-sensitive, not wildcard. See also: . - "@attr" - . Here "attr" is any attribute name. Example: "@id=example".

member.summary: Gets the container window or control of this accessible object.

member.summary: Gets the top-level window that contains this accessible object.
member.remarks: Returns default(AWnd) if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property, but some have bugs and can return default(AWnd). Uses API WindowFromAccessibleObject and API GetAncestor.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Rect
member.summary: Gets location of this accessible object in screen.
member.remarks: Calls . Returns empty rectangle if failed or this property is unavailable. Supports . Most but not all objects support this property.

member.summary: Gets location of this accessible object in screen.
member.param: Receives object rectangle in screen coordinates.
member.remarks: Returns false if failed or this property is unavailable. Supports . Most but not all objects support this property. Uses IAccessible.accLocation.

Window or control.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.RoleInt
member.summary: Gets standard non-string role, as enum AccROLE.
member.remarks: Most objects have a standard role, as enum . Some objects have a custom role, usually as string, for example in web pages in Firefox and Chrome. Returns 0 if role is string or if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property. If failed, probably the object is invalid, for example its window was closed. Uses IAccessible.get_accRole.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Role
member.summary: Gets standard or custom role, as string.
member.remarks: Most objects have a standard role, defined in enum . Some objects have a custom role, usually as string, for example in web pages in Firefox and Chrome. For standard roles this function returns enum member name. For string roles - the string. For unknown non-string roles - the int value like "0" or "500". Returns "" if failed. Supports . All objects must support this property. If failed, probably the object is invalid, for example its window was closed. Uses IAccessible.get_accRole.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.State
member.summary: Gets object state (flags).
member.remarks: Returns 0 if failed. Supports . Uses IAccessible.get_accState.

example.code: if(a.State.Has(AccSTATE.INVISIBLE)) AOutput.Write("has state INVISIBLE"); if(a.IsInvisible) AOutput.Write("invisible");

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsChecked
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state CHECKED.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsDisabled
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state UNAVAILABLE.
member.remarks: Does not check whether this object is in a disabled parent/ancestor object.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsFocused
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state FOCUSED.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsInvisible
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state INVISIBLE and does not have state OFFSCREEN.
member.remarks: If the object has both INVISIBLE and OFFSCREEN states, it is either invisible or just offscreen, depending on application etc. Then this function works like Find and similar functions: for most objects returns false (is visible), but for objects that have these roles returns true (invisible): WINDOW, DOCUMENT, PROPERTYPAGE, GROUPING, ALERT, MENUPOPUP. Does not check whether this object is in an invisible parent/ancestor object.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsOffscreen
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state OFFSCREEN.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsPassword
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state PROTECTED.
member.remarks: This state is used for password fields.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsPressed
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state PRESSED.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsReadonly
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state READONLY.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.IsSelected
member.summary: Calls and returns true if has state SELECTED.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc._BstrToString(System.Int32,Au.Types.BSTR)
member.summary: Converts BSTR to string and disposes the BSTR. If hr is not 0, returns "" (never null).

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Name
member.summary: Gets name.
member.remarks: Object name usually is its read-only text (eg button text, link text), or its adjacent read-only text (eg text label by this edit box). It usually does not change, therefore can be used to find or identify the object. Returns "" if name is unavailable or if failed. Supports . Uses IAccessible.get_accName.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.NameOfWindow_(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Gets of window/control w. Returns null if w invalid. Returns "" if failed to get name.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets value.
member.remarks: Usually it is editable text or some other value that can be changed at run time, therefore in most cases it cannot be used to find or identify the object reliably. The 'get' function returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . Most objects don't support 'set'. Uses IAccessible.get_accValue or IAccessible.put_accValue.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Description
member.summary: Gets description.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . Uses IAccessible.get_accDescription.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.Help
member.summary: Gets help text.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . Uses IAccessible.get_accHelp.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.UiaId
member.summary: Gets UI Automation element AutomationId property.
member.remarks: Only objects found with flag can have this property. Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.KeyboardShortcut
member.summary: Gets keyboard shortcut.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . Uses IAccessible.get_accKeyboardShortcut.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.DefaultAction
member.summary: Gets default action.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . If this is a Java accessible object, returns all actions that can be used with , like "action1, action2, action3", from which the first is considered default and is used by . Uses IAccessible.get_accDefaultAction.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.DoAction
member.summary: Performs the object's default action (see ). Usually it is 'click', 'press' or similar.
member.remarks: Fails if the object does not have a default action. Then you can use , or try , , and keyboard functions. The action can take long time, for example show a dialog. This function normally does not wait. It allows the caller to automate the dialog. If it waits, try or one of the above functions (MouseClick etc). Uses IAccessible.accDoDefaultAction.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.VirtualClick
member.summary: Posts mouse-left-click message to the container window, using coordinates of this object.
member.exception: Failed to get rectangle, or the object is invisible/offscreen.
member.remarks: Does not move the mouse. Does not wait until the target application finishes processing the message. Works not with all objects. Use (try) this function when the object does not support . When both don't work, use MouseClick.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.VirtualRightClick
member.summary: Posts mouse-right-click message to the container window, using coordinates of this object.
member.exception: Failed to get rectangle, or the object is invisible/offscreen.
member.remarks: Does not move the mouse. Does not wait until the target application finishes processing the message. Works not with all objects. When does not work, use MouseClick.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.DoJavaAction(System.String)
member.summary: Performs one of actions supported by this Java accessible object.
member.param: Action name. See . If null (default), performs default action (like ) or posts Space key message. More info in Remarks.
member.remarks:
Read more about Java accessible objects in topic.
Problem: if the action opens a dialog, DoAction/DoJavaAction do not return until the dialog is closed (or fail after some time). The caller then waits and cannot automate the dialog. Also then this process cannot exit until the dialog is closed. If the action parameter is null and the object is focusable, this function tries a workaround: it makes the object (button etc) focused and posts Space key message, which should press the button; then this function does not wait.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.DoActionAndWaitForNewWebPage(System.Double,System.Action{Au.AAcc})
member.summary: Calls or action and waits until window name changes and web page name changes.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout). Default 60 seconds.
If used, calls it instead of .
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.exception: Failed. For example, when this object is invalid, or its top-level window does not contain a web page.
The window was closed while waiting.
Exceptions thrown by or by the action function.
member.remarks: This function is used to click a link in a web page and wait until current web page is gone. It prevents a following 'wait for object' function from finding a matching object in the old page, which would be bad. This function does not wait until the new page is completely loaded. There is no reliable/universal way for it. Instead, after calling it you can call a 'wait for object' function which waits for a known object that must be in the new page. This function cannot be used when the new page has the same title as current page. Then it waits until secondsTimeout time or forever. The same if the action does not open a web page.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Select(Au.Types.AccSELFLAG)
member.summary: Selects or deselects.
member.param: Specifies whether to select, focus, add to selection etc. Can be two flags, for example AccSELFLAG.TAKEFOCUS | AccSELFLAG.TAKESELECTION.
member.exception: Failed to activate the window () or focus the control ().
member.remarks: Uses IAccessible.accSelect. Not all objects support it. Most objects support not all flags. It depends on FOCUSABLE, SELECTABLE, MULTISELECTABLE, EXTSELECTABLE, DISABLED. Many object have bugs, especially with flag TAKEFOCUS. More bugs when the object found with flag .

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Focus(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this object focused for keyboard input.
member.param: Add flag TAKESELECTION. Note: it is for selecting a list item, not for selecting text in a text box.
member.remarks: Calls with flag TAKEFOCUS and optionally TAKESELECTION. Not all objects support this action and not all work correctly. More info in Select documentation.

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.SelectedChildren
member.summary: Gets selected direct child items. Returns empty array if there are no selected items of if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Au.AAcc.ChildCount
member.summary: Gets the number of direct child objects.
member.remarks: Uses IAccessible.get_accChildCount.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.GetProperties(System.String,Au.Types.AccProperties@)
member.summary: Gets multiple properties.
member.param: String that specifies properties to get, for example "nv" for name and value. - R - . - n - . - v - . - d - . - h - . - a - . - k - . - u - . - s - . - r - . - w - . - o - outer. - i - inner. - @ - .
Receives results.
member.remarks:
The returned variable contains values of properties specified in props. When a property is empty or failed to get, the member variable is "", empty dictionary or default value of that type; never null.
Normally this function is faster than calling multiple property functions, because it makes single remote procedure call. But not if this accessible object was found with flag etc.
Returns false if fails, for example when the object's window is closed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Navigate(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets an adjacent or related accessible object (AO) - next, child, parent, etc. Returns null if not found.
member.param: String consisting of one or more navigation direction strings separated by space, like "parent next child4 first". - "next" - next sibling AO in the same parent AO. - "previous" - previous sibling AO in the same parent AO. - "first" - first child AO. - "last" - last child AO. - "parent" - parent (container) AO. - "child" - child AO by 1-based index. Example: "child3" (3-th child). Negative index means from end, for example -1 is the last child. - "#N" - custom. More info in Remarks.
Wait for the wanted AO max this number of seconds. If negative, waits forever.
member.remarks:
Can be only 2 letters, like "pr" for "previous". A string like "next3" or "next,3" is the same as "next next next". Except for "child". Use string like "#1000" to specify a custom navDir value to pass to IAccessible.accNavigate. Can be any standard or custom value supported by the AO.
For "next", "previous", "firstchild", "lastchild" and "#N" is used IAccessible.accNavigate. Not all AOs support it. Some AOs skip invisible siblings. Instead you can use "parent childN" or "childN". For "parent" is used IAccessible.get_accParent. Few AOs don't support. Some AOs return a different parent than in the AO tree. For "child" is used API AccessibleChildren.

example.code: a = a.Navigate("parent next ch3", true);

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.Html(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets HTML.
member.param: If true, gets outer HTML (with tag and attributes), else inner HTML.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this is not a HTML element or if failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc. If this is the root of web page (role DOCUMENT or PANE), gets web page body HTML.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.HtmlAttribute(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a HTML attribute.
member.param: Attribute name, for example "href", "id", "class". Full, case-sensitive.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this is not a HTML element or does not have the specified attribute or failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.HtmlAttributes
member.summary: Gets all HTML attributes.
member.remarks: Returns empty dictionary if this is not a HTML element or does not have attributes or failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc.

member.name: M:Au.AAcc.ScrollTo
member.summary: Scrolls this accessible object into view.
member.exception: Failed to scroll, or the object does not support scrolling.
member.remarks: This function works with these objects: - Web page objects in Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). With Find use role prefix "web:", "firefox:" or "chrome:", and don't use flag . - Objects in Edge browser, standard treeview and listview controls, some other. With Find use flag .

member.name: T:Au.Types.AFFlags
member.summary: Flags for and similar functions.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.Reverse
member.summary: Search in reverse order. It can make faster. When control class or id is specified in the prop argument, controls are searched not in reverse order. Only accessible objects in them are searched in reverse order.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.HiddenToo
member.summary: The accessible object can be invisible. Without this flag skips objects that are invisible (have state INVISIBLE) or are descendants of invisible WINDOW, DOCUMENT, PROPERTYPAGE, GROUPING, ALERT, MENUPOPUP. Regardless of this flag, always skips invisible standard objects of nonclient area: TITLEBAR, MENUBAR, SCROLLBAR, GRIP.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.MenuToo
member.summary: Always search in MENUITEM. Without this flag skips MENUITEM descendant objects (for speed), unless role is MENUITEM or MENUPOPUP or searching in web page.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.ClientArea
member.summary: Search only in the client area of the window or control. Skips the title bar, standard menubars and scrollbars. Searches only in the client area root object (but will not find the object itself). When control class or id is specified in the prop argument, this flag is applied to these controls. Not applied to other controls. Don't use this flag when searching in AAcc or web page (role prefix "web:" etc) or with flag UIA.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.NotInProc
member.summary: Search without loading dll into the target process. Disadvantages: 1. Much slower. 2. Some properties are not supported, for example HTML attributes (while searching and later). 3. And more. Even without this flag, the default search method is not used with Windows Store app windows, console windows, most Java windows, windows of protected processes and processes of higher [](xref:uac) integrity level, Firefox web page if its multiprocess feature is not disabled. Some windows have child controls that belong to a different process or thread than the window. Example - Internet Explorer. When searching in such windows, the default search method is not used when searching in these controls. Workaround - find the control(s) and search in it/them. For it can be used one of: 1. With Internet Explorer use role prefix "web:". 2. Find the control with and search in it. 3. Use . Don't need this flag when searching in AAcc (then it is inherited from the Acc variable). See also: .

member.name: F:Au.Types.AFFlags.UIA
member.summary: Use UI Automation API. Need this flag to find objects in windows that don't support accessible objects but support UI Automation elements. Examples of such windows: Microsoft Edge web browser (web page), JavaFX applications. Objects found with this flag never have HtmlX properties, but can have . This flag can be used with most other windows too. Don't use this flag when searching in AAcc (then it is inherited from the Acc variable) or web page (role prefix "web:" etc). See also: .

member.name: T:Au.Types.OptMouse
member.summary: Options for functions of class .
member.remarks: Total Click(x, y) time is: mouse move + + button down + + button down + + .

member.name: M:Au.Types.OptMouse.#ctor(Au.Types.OptMouse)
member.summary: Initializes this instance with default values or values copied from another instance.
member.param: If not null, copies its options into this variable.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptMouse.ClickSpeed
member.summary: How long to wait (milliseconds) after sending each mouse button down or up event (2 events for click, 4 for double-click). Default: 20.
member.value: Valid values: 0 - 1000 (1 s). Valid values for : 0 - 100 (1 s).

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptMouse.MoveSpeed
member.summary: If not 0, makes mouse movements slower, not instant. Default: 0.
member.remarks: Used by , and other functions that generate mouse movement events, except . It is not milliseconds or some other unit. It adds intermediate mouse movements and small delays when moving the mouse cursor to the specified point. The speed also depends on the distance. Value 0 (default) does not add intermediate mouse movements. Adds at least 1 if some mouse buttons are pressed. Value 1 adds at least 1 intermediate mouse movement. Values 10-50 are good for visually slow movements.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptMouse.ClickSleepFinally
member.summary: How long to wait (milliseconds) before a 'mouse click' or 'mouse wheel' function returns. Default: 10.
member.value: Valid values: 0 - 10000 (10 s). Valid values for : 0 - 100.
member.remarks: The 'click' functions also sleep ms after button down and up. Default ClickSpeed is 20, default ClickSleepFinally is 10, therefore default click time without mouse-move is 20+20+10=50.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptMouse.MoveSleepFinally
member.summary: How long to wait (milliseconds) after moving the mouse cursor. Used in 'move+click' functions too. Default: 10.
member.value: Valid values: 0 - 1000 (1 s). Valid values for : 0 - 100.
member.remarks: Used by (finally), (between moving and clicking) and other functions that generate mouse movement events.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptMouse.Relaxed
member.summary: Make some functions less strict (throw less exceptions etc). Default: false.
member.remarks:
This option is used by these functions: - , and other functions that move the cursor (mouse pointer):
false - throw exception if cannot move the cursor to the specified x y. For example it the x y is not in screen.
true - try to move anyway. Don't throw exception, regardless of the final cursor position (which probably will be at a screen edge). - , and other functions that move the cursor (mouse pointer):
false - before moving the cursor, wait while a mouse button is pressed by the user or another thread. It prevents an unintended drag-drop.
true - do not wait. - and other functions that click or press a mouse button using window coordinates:
false - don't allow to click in another window. If need, activate the specified window (or its top-level parent). If that does not help, throw exception. However if the window is a control, allow x y anywhere in its top-level parent window.
true - allow to click in another window. Don't activate the window and don't throw exception.

member.name: T:Au.Types.OptKey
member.summary: Options for functions of class . Some options also are used with functions that send keys (Ctrl+V etc).

member.name: M:Au.Types.OptKey.#ctor(Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Initializes this instance with default values or values copied from another instance.
member.param: If not null, copies its options into this variable.

member.name: M:Au.Types.OptKey.CopyOrDefault_(Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Copies options from o, or sets default if o==null. Like ctor does.

member.name: M:Au.Types.OptKey.GetHookOptionsOrThis_(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Returns this variable, or OptKey cloned from this variable and possibly modified by Hook.
member.param: The focused or active window. Use Lib.GetWndFocusedOrActive().

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.TextSpeed
member.summary: How long to wait (milliseconds) between pressing and releasing each character key. Used by . Also by and similar functions for (KText)"text" arguments. Default: 0.
member.value: Valid values: 0 - 1000 (1 second). Valid values for : 0 - 10.
member.remarks: Not used for 'keys' arguments. See .

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.KeySpeed
member.summary: How long to wait (milliseconds) between pressing and releasing each key. Used by and similar functions, except for (KText)"text" arguments. Default: 1.
member.value: Valid values: 0 - 1000 (1 second). Valid values for : 0 - 10.
member.remarks: Not used for 'text' arguments. See .

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.KeySpeedClipboard
member.summary: How long to wait (milliseconds) between sending Ctrl+V and Ctrl+C keys of clipboard functions (paste, copy). Default: 5.
member.value: Valid values: 0 - 1000 (1 second). Valid values for : 0 - 50.
member.remarks: In most apps copy/paste works without this delay. Known apps that need it: Internet Explorer's address bar, BlueStacks.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.SleepFinally
member.summary: How long to wait (milliseconds) before a 'send keys or text' function returns. Default: 10.
member.value: Valid values: 0 - 10000 (10 seconds). Valid values for : 0 - 100.
member.remarks: Not used by .

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.TextOption
member.summary: How functions send text to the active window (keys, clipboard, etc). Default: .

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.PasteLength
member.summary: To send text use clipboard (like with option ) if text length is >= this value. Default: 300.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.PasteEnter
member.summary: When pasting text that ends with newline characters, remove the last newline and after pasting send the Enter key. Default: false.
member.remarks: Some apps remove the last newline when pasting. For example Word, WordPad, OpenOffice, LibreOffice, standard rich text controls. This option is a workaround.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.RestoreClipboard
member.summary: Whether to restore clipboard data when copying or pasting text. Default: true. By default restores only text. See also , .

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.RestoreClipboardAllFormats
member.summary: When copying or pasting text, restore clipboard data of all formats that are possible to restore. Default: false - restore only text.
member.remarks:
Restoring data of all formats set by some apps can be slow or cause problems. More info: .
This property is static, not thread-static. It should be set (if need) at the very start of script and not changed later.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.RestoreClipboardExceptFormats
member.summary: When copying or pasting text, and is true, do not restore clipboard data of these formats. Default: null.
member.remarks:
To restore clipboard data, the copy/paste functions at first get clipboard data. Getting data of some formats set by some apps can be slow (100 ms or more) or cause problems (the app can change something in its window or even show a dialog). It also depends on whether this is the first time the data is being retrieved. The app can render data on demand, when some app is retrieving it from the clipboard first time; then can be slow etc.
You can use function to see format names and get-data times.
There are several kinds of clipboard formats - registered, standard, private and display. Only registered formats have string names. For standard formats use API contant names, like "CF_WAVE". Private, display and metafile formats are never restored. These formats are never restored: CF_METAFILEPICT, CF_ENHMETAFILE, CF_PALETTE, CF_OWNERDISPLAY, CF_DSPx formats, CF_GDIOBJx formats, CF_PRIVATEx formats. Some other formats too, but they are automatically synthesized from other formats if need. Also does not restore if data size is 0 or > 10 MB.
This property is static, not thread-static. It should be set (if need) at the very start of script and not changed later.

member.name: M:Au.Types.OptKey.PrintClipboard
member.summary: Writes to the output some info about current clipboard data.
member.remarks: Shows this info for each clipboard format: format name, time spent to get data (microseconds), data size (bytes), and whether this format would be restored (depends on ). Copy something to the clipboard each time before calling this function. Don't use and don't call this function in loop. Else it shows small times. The time depends on app, etc. More info: .

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.NoModOff
member.summary: When starting to send keys or text, don't release modifier keys. Default: false.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.NoCapsOff
member.summary: When starting to send keys or text, don't turn off CapsLock. Default: false.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.NoBlockInput
member.summary: While sending or pasting keys or text, don't block user-pressed keys. Default: false.
member.remarks: If false (default), user-pressed keys are sent afterwards. If true, user-pressed keys can be mixed with script-pressed keys, which is particularly dangerous when modifier keys are mixed (and combined) with non-modifier keys.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptKey.Hook
member.summary: Callback function that can modify options of 'send keys or text' functions depending on active window etc. Default: null.
member.remarks: The callback function is called by , , , and similar functions. Not called by .

member.name: T:Au.Types.KOHookData
member.summary: Parameter type of the callback function.

member.name: F:Au.Types.KOHookData.opt
member.summary: Options used by the 'send keys or text' function. The callback function can modify them, except Hook, NoModOff, NoCapsOff, NoBlockInput.

member.name: F:Au.Types.KOHookData.w
member.summary: The focused control. If there is no focused control - the active window. Use w.Window to get top-level window; if w.Window == w, w is the active window, else the focused control. The callback function is not called if there is no active window.

member.name: T:Au.Types.KTextOption
member.summary: How functions send text. See .
member.remarks: There are three ways to send text to the active app using keys: 1. Characters (default) - use special key code VK_PACKET. 2. Keys - press keybord keys. 3. Paste - use the clipboard and Ctrl+V. Most but not all apps support all three ways. Most Unicode characters cannot be sent with Keys. Depending on text, the 'send text' functions may use other method than specified. For some characters or for whole text. More info below. Many apps don't support Unicode surrogate pairs sent as keys. If the text contains such characters, is used Paste instead of other options (implicitly). These characters are rarely used.

member.name: F:Au.Types.KTextOption.Characters
member.summary: Send text characters using special key code VK_PACKET. Few apps don't support it. This option is default. Supports most Unicode characters. For newlines sends key Enter, because VK_PACKET often does not work well.

member.name: F:Au.Types.KTextOption.Keys
member.summary: Send text keys, with Shift or other modifiers where need, depending on the keyboard layout of the active window. The numpad keys are not used. All apps support it. Some characters cannot be easily typed using the keyboard. For example most non-ASCII characters. Sends these characters like with the Characters option.

member.name: F:Au.Types.KTextOption.Paste
member.summary: Paste text using the clipboard and Ctrl+V. Few apps don't support it. This option is recommended for long text, because other ways then are too slow. Other options are unreliable when text length is more than 4000 or 5000 and the target app is too slow to process sent characters. Then can help. Also, other options are unreliable when the target app modifies typed text, for example has such features as auto-complete or auto-indent. However some apps modify even pasted text, for example trim the last newline. When pasting text, previous clipboard data is lost. Only text is restored.

member.name: T:Au.Types.OptWaitFor
member.summary: Options for 'wait for' functions.

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptWaitFor.Period
member.summary: The sleep time between checking the wait condition. Milliseconds. Default: 10.
member.remarks: Most 'wait for' functions of this library use , which repeatedly checks the wait condition and sleeps (waits) several ms. This property sets the initial sleep time, which then is incremented by Period/10 ms (default 1 ms) in each loop until reaches Period*50 (default 500 ms). This property makes the response time shorter or longer. If <10, makes it shorter (faster response), but increases CPU usage; if >10, makes it longer (slower response).

example.code: AOpt.WaitFor.Period = 100;

member.name: P:Au.Types.OptWaitFor.DoEvents
member.summary: Use instead of . Default: false.
member.remarks: Use this property when need to process Windows messages, events, hooks, timers, etc while waiting. More info: .

example.code: AOpt.WaitFor.DoEvents = true;

member.name: T:Au.Types.AuException
member.summary: The base exception class used in this library. Thrown when something fails and there is no better exception type for that failure.
member.remarks: Some constructors support Windows API error code. Then will contain its error description. If the string passed to the constructor starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If does not end with ".", appends ".".

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor
member.summary: Sets Message = "Failed.". Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Sets Message = message. Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets Message = "Failed. " + ALastError.MessageFor(winApiErrorCode). Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : ALastError.Code.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + " " + ALastError.MessageFor(winApiErrorCode). Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : ALastError.Code.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + "\r\n\t" + innerException.Message. Sets NativeErrorCode = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.#ctor(System.Int32,System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets Message = message + " " + ALastError.MessageFor(winApiErrorCode) + "\r\n\t" + innerException.Message. Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : ALastError.Code.

member.name: P:Au.Types.AuException.NativeErrorCode
member.summary: Gets the Windows API error code.

member.name: P:Au.Types.AuException.Message
member.summary: Gets error message.

member.name: F:Au.Types.AuException.FormattedMessage
member.summary: String created by FormatMessage(), which should be called by the Message override if null. Initially null.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.FormatMessage(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Formats error message. Sets and returns FormattedMessage. As base text, uses the text passed to the constructor (default "Failed."). If it starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If it ends with "*", replaces the "*" with commonPostfix if it is not empty. If then the message does not end with ".", appends ".". If appendMessage is null, uses ALastError.MessageFor(NativeErrorCode) if NativeErrorCode not 0. If then appendMessage is not empty, appends " " and appendMessage. Also appends InnerException.Message in new tab-indented line if InnerException is not null.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.ThrowIfHresultNot0(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: If errorCode is not 0, throws AuException that includes the code and its message. More info: .
member.param: Windows API error code or HRESULT.
Main message. The message of the error code will be appended to it.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuException.ThrowIfHresultNegative(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: If errorCode is less than 0, throws AuException that includes the code and its message. More info: .
member.param: Windows API error code or HRESULT.
Main message. The message of the error code will be appended to it.

member.name: T:Au.Types.AuWndException
member.summary: Exception thrown mostly by functions.
member.remarks: Some constructors support Windows API error code. Then Message also will contain its error description. If error code ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE, Message also depends on whether the window handle is 0. If parameter winApiErrorCode is 0 or not used: if the window handle is invalid, uses ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE. If the string passed to the constructor starts with "*", replaces the "*" with "Failed to ". If ends with "*", replaces the "*" with " window.". If does not end with ".", appends ".".

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuWndException.#ctor(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE. Sets Message = "Failed.".

member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuWndException.#ctor(Au.AWnd,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? ALastError.Code : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE). Sets Message = "Failed.".

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuWndException.#ctor(Au.AWnd,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? ALastError.Code : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE).

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuWndException.#ctor(Au.AWnd,System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = w.IsAlive ? 0 : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE.

member.name: M:Au.Types.AuWndException.#ctor(Au.AWnd,System.Int32,System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Sets NativeErrorCode = (winApiErrorCode != 0) ? winApiErrorCode : (w.IsAlive ? ALastError.Code : ERROR_INVALID_WINDOW_HANDLE).

member.name: T:Au.Types.Coord
member.summary: Contains x or y coordinate in screen or some other rectangle that can be specified in various ways: normal, reverse, fraction, center, max. Used for parameters of functions like , .
member.remarks: To specify a normal coordinate, assign an int value (implicit conversion from int to Coord). Else use static functions such as Reverse, Fraction (or assign float), Center, Max, MaxInside. Also there are functions to convert Coord to normal coodinates.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.Type
member.summary: Value type.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.Value
member.summary: Non-fraction value.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.FractionValue
member.summary: Fraction value.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.IsEmpty
member.summary: Returns true if Type == None (when assigned default(Coord)).

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.op_Implicit(System.Int32)~Au.Types.Coord
member.summary: Creates Coord of Normal type.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.op_Implicit(System.Single)~Au.Types.Coord
member.summary: Creates Coord of Fraction type.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.Reverse(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates Coord of Reverse type. Value 0 is at the right or bottom, and does not belong to the rectangle. Positive values are towards left or top.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.Fraction(System.Double)
member.summary: Creates Coord of Fraction type. Value 0.0 is the left or top of the rectangle. Value 1.0 is the right or bottom of the rectangle. Values <0.0 and >=1.0 are outside of the rectangle. Instead can be used implicit conversion from float, for example argument Coord.Fraction(0.5) can be replaced with 0.5f.

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.Center
member.summary: Returns Fraction(0.5).

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.Max
member.summary: Returns Reverse(0). This point will be outside of the rectangle. See also .

member.name: P:Au.Types.Coord.MaxInside
member.summary: Returns Reverse(1). This point will be inside of the rectangle, at the very right or bottom, assuming the rectangle is not empty.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.NormalizeInRange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts fractional/reverse coordinate to normal coordinate in a range.
member.param: Start of range.
End of range.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.NormalizeInRect(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.RECT,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts fractional/reverse coordinates to normal coordinates in a rectangle.
member.param: X coordinate relative to r.
Y coordinate relative to r.
The rectangle.
Use only width and height of r. If false (default), the function adds r offset (left and top).
If x or y is default(Coord), use Coord.Center. Not used with widthHeight.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.NormalizeInWindow(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.AWnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns normal coordinates relative to the client area of a window. Converts fractional/reverse coordinates etc.
member.param: X coordinate relative to the client area of w.
Y coordinate relative to the client area of w.
The window.
x y are relative to the entire w rectangle, not to its client area.
If x or y is default(Coord), use Coord.Center.

member.name: M:Au.Types.Coord.Normalize(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,Au.AScreen,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns normal coordinates relative to the primary screen. Converts fractional/reverse coordinates etc.
member.param: X coordinate relative to the specified screen (default - primary).
Y coordinate relative to the specified screen (default - primary).
x y are relative to the work area.
If used, x y are relative to this screen. Default - primary screen.
Use only width and height of the screen rectangle. If false, the function adds its offset (left and top, which can be nonzero if using the work area or a non-primary screen).
If x or y is default(Coord), use Coord.Center.

member.name: T:Au.Types.CoordType
member.summary: variable value type.

member.name: F:Au.Types.CoordType.None
member.summary: No value. The variable is default(Coord).

member.name: F:Au.Types.CoordType.Normal
member.summary: is pixel offset from left or top of a rectangle.

member.name: F:Au.Types.CoordType.Reverse
member.summary: is pixel offset from right or bottom of a rectangle, towards left or top.

member.name: F:Au.Types.CoordType.Fraction
member.summary: is fraction of a rectangle, where 0.0 is left or top, and 1.0 is right or bottom (outside of the rectangle).

member.name: T:Au.Types.LPARAM
member.summary: Similar to IntPtr (can be 32-bit or 64-bit), but more useful for usually-non-pointer values, eg WPARAM/LPARAM/LRESULT of API SendMessage.
member.remarks:
Unlike IntPtr: - Has implicit casts from most integral types. And explicit casts to. - Does not check overflow when casting from uint etc. IntPtr throws exception on overflow, which can create bugs.
There is no struct WPARAM. Use LPARAM instead, because it is the same in all cases except when casting to long or ulong (ambigous signed/unsigned). There is no cast operators for enum. When need, cast through int or uint. For AWnd cast through IntPtr.

member.name: M:Au.Types.LPARAM.Equals(Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Returns true if other == this. Implements IEquatable. Prevents boxing when used as a key of a collection.

member.name: M:Au.Types.LPARAM.CompareTo(Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Implements IComparable. It allows to sort a collection.

member.remarks: This type can be used with Windows API functions. The .NET Rectangle etc can't, because their fields are different. Has implicit conversions from/to Rectangle and RectangleF.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes this instance.
member.param: right or width, depending on useWidthHeight.
bottom or height, depending on useWidthHeight.
If true (default), rightOrWidth/bottomOrHeight are width/height. Else right/bottom.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.op_Implicit(System.ValueTuple{System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32})~Au.Types.RECT
member.summary: Creates new RECT from tuple containing left, top, width and height.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Set(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets fields like the constructor .

member.name: P:Au.Types.RECT.Is0
member.summary: Returns true if all fields == 0.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RECT.IsEmpty
member.summary: Returns true if the rectangle is empty or invalid: right<=left || bottom<=top;

member.name: P:Au.Types.RECT.Width
member.summary: Gets or sets width.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RECT.Height
member.summary: Gets or sets height.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RECT.CenterX
member.summary: Gets horizontal center.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RECT.CenterY
member.summary: Gets vertical center.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Contains(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true if this rectangle contains the specified point.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Contains(Au.Types.POINT)
member.summary: Returns true if this rectangle contains the specified point.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Contains(Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Returns true if this rectangle contains entire specified rectangle.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Inflate(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Makes this rectangle bigger or smaller: left-=dx; right+=dx; top-=dy; bottom+=dy; Use negative dx/dy to make the rectangle smaller. Note: too big negative dx/dy can make it invalid (right<left or bottom<top).

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Intersect(Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Replaces this rectangle with the intersection of itself and the specified rectangle. Returns true if the rectangles intersect. If they don't intersect, makes this RECT empty (IsEmpty would return true).

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Intersect(Au.Types.RECT,Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Returns the intersection rectangle of two rectangles. If they don't intersect, returns empty rectangle (IsEmpty would return true).

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.IntersectsWith(Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Returns true if this rectangle and another rectangle intersect.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Offset(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves this rectangle by the specified offsets: left+=dx; right+=dx; top+=dy; bottom+=dy; Negative dx moves to the left. Negative dy moves up.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Union(Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Replaces this rectangle with the union of itself and the specified rectangle. Union is the smallest rectangle that contains two full rectangles. Returns true if finally this rectangle is not empty. If either rectangle is empty (Width or Height is <=0), the result is another rectangle. If both empty - empty rectangle.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Union(Au.Types.RECT,Au.Types.RECT)
member.summary: Returns the union of two rectangles. Union is the smallest rectangle that contains two full rectangles. If either rectangle is empty (Width or Height is <=0), the result is another rectangle. If both empty - empty rectangle.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.Normalize(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If width or height are negative, modifies this rectangle so that they would not be negative.
member.param: true - swap right/left, bottom/top; false - set right = left, bottom = top.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.MoveInScreen(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.AScreen,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this rectangle to the specified coordinates in the specified screen, and ensures that whole rectangle is in screen. Final rectangle coordinates are relative to the primary screen.
member.param: X coordinate in the specified screen. If default(Coord) - screen center. Can be Coord.Reverse etc.
Y coordinate in the specified screen. If default(Coord) - screen center. Can be Coord.Reverse etc.
Use this screen (see ). If default, uses the primary screen.
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
If part of rectangle is not in screen, move and/or resize it so that entire rectangle would be in screen. Default true.
member.remarks: This function can be used to calculate new window location before creating it. If window already exists, use .

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.MoveInRect(Au.Types.RECT,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this rectangle to the specified coordinates in another rectangle r.
member.param: X coordinate relative to r. Default - center. Can be Coord.Reverse etc.
Y coordinate relative to r. Default - center. Can be Coord.Reverse etc.
Another rectangle.
If part of rectangle is not in r, move and/or resize it so that entire rectangle would be in r. Default true.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RECT.EnsureInScreen(Au.AScreen,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adjusts this rectangle to ensure that whole rectangle is in screen. Initial and final rectangle coordinates are relative to the primary screen.
member.param: Use this screen (see ). If default, uses screen of the rectangle (or nearest).
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
member.remarks: This function can be used to calculate new window location before creating it. If window already exists, use .

member.summary: Creates ColorInt from .

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.FromString(System.String,Au.Types.ColorInt@)
member.summary: Creates ColorInt from color name () or string "0xRRGGBB" or "#RRGGBB".
member.remarks: If s is a hex number that contains 6 or less hex digits, makes opaque (alpha 0xFF). If s is null or invalid, sets c.color = 0 and returns false.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.FromBGR(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates ColorInt (0xRRGGBB) from Windows native COLORREF (0xBBGGRR).
member.param: Color in 0xBBGGRR format.
Set alpha = 0xFF.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.ToBGR(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates Windows native COLORREF (0xBBGGRR) from ColorInt (0xRRGGBB). Returns color in COLORREF format. Does not modify this variable.
member.param: Set the alpha byte = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.op_Explicit(Au.Types.ColorInt)~System.Int32
member.summary: Creates int from ColorInt.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.op_Explicit(Au.Types.ColorInt)~System.UInt32
member.summary: Creates int from ColorInt.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.op_Explicit(Au.Types.ColorInt)~System.Drawing.Color
member.summary: Creates from ColorInt.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.op_Explicit(Au.Types.ColorInt)~System.Windows.Media.Color
member.summary: Creates from ColorInt.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.SwapRB(System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts color from ARGB (0xAARRGGBB) to ABGR (0xAABBGGRR) or vice versa (swaps the red and blue bytes). ARGB is used in .NET, GDI+ and HTML/CSS. ABGR is used by most Windows API.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.GetPerceivedBrightness
member.summary: Calculates color's perceived brightness. Returns a value in range 0 (brightness of black color) to 1 (brightness of white color).
member.remarks: Unlike Color.GetBrightness, this function gives different weights for red, green and blue components. Does not use alpha.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ColorInt.AdjustLuminance(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Changes color's luminance (makes darker or brighter). Returns new color. Does not modify this variable.
member.param: The luminance in units of 0.1 percent of the range (which depends on totalRange). Can be from -1000 to 1000.

If true, n is in the whole luminance range (from minimal to maximal possible). If false, n is in the range from current luminance of the color to the maximal (if n positive) or minimal (if n negative) luminance.
member.remarks: Calls API ColorAdjustLuma. Does not change hue and saturation. Does not use alpha.

member.summary: Display custom buttons as a column of command-links, not as a row of classic buttons. Command links can have multi-line text. The first line has bigger font. More info about custom buttons: .

member.summary: Show the dialog in the center of the owner window.

member.summary: x y are relative to the primary screen (ignore etc). Don't ensure thet entire window is in screen. More info: .

member.summary: Make the dialog a topmost window (always on top of other windows), regardless of ADialog.Options.TopmostIfNoOwnerWindow etc. More info: .

member.name: F:Au.Types.DFlags.XCancel
member.summary: Allow to cancel even if there is no Cancel button. It adds X (Close) button to the title bar, and also allows to close the dialog with the Esc key. When the dialog is closed with the X button or Esc, the returned result button id is 0 if there is no Cancel button; else the same as when clicked the Cancel button. The same as .

member.name: T:Au.Types.DSend
member.summary: Can be used through , to interact with dialog while it is open.
member.remarks: Example (in an event handler): e.dialog.Close();

member.name: M:Au.Types.DSend.Message(Au.Types.Native.TDM,Au.Types.LPARAM,Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Sends a message to the dialog.
member.remarks: Call this method while the dialog is open, eg in an event handler. Example (in an event handler): e.dialog.Send.Message(Native.TDM.CLICK_VERIFICATION, 1); Also there are several other functions to send some messages: change text, close dialog, enable/disable buttons, update progress. Reference: task dialog messages. NAVIGATE_PAGE currently not supported.

member.summary: Anchors are all edges. The toolbar is resized when resizing its owner.

member.name: F:Au.Types.TBAnchor.OppositeEdgeX
member.summary: Use owner's opposite left/right edge than specified. In other words, attach toolbar's left edge to owner's right edge or vice versa. This flag is for toolbars that normally are outside of the owner rectangle (at the left or right). This flag can be used with TopLeft, TopRight, BottomLeft or BottomRight.

member.name: F:Au.Types.TBAnchor.OppositeEdgeY
member.summary: Use owner's opposite top/bottom edge than specified. In other words, attach toolbar's top edge to owner's bottom edge or vice versa. This flag is for toolbars that normally are outside of the owner rectangle (above or below). This flag can be used with TopLeft, TopRight, BottomLeft or BottomRight.

member.name: T:Au.Types.ITBOwnerObject
member.summary: Used with .
member.remarks: Allows a toolbar to follow an object in the owner window, for example an accessible object or image. Or to hide in certain conditions. Define a class that implements this interface. Create a variable of that class and pass it to . The interface functions are called every 250 ms, sometimes more frequently. Not called when the owner window is invisible or cloaked or minimized.

member.name: P:Au.Types.ITBOwnerObject.IsAlive
member.summary: Returns false to close the toolbar.
member.remarks: Not called if the owner window is invisible or cloaked or minimized. The default implementation returns true.

member.name: P:Au.Types.ITBOwnerObject.IsVisible
member.summary: Returns false to hide the toolbar temporarily.
member.remarks: Not called if the owner window is invisible or cloaked or minimized. The default implementation returns true.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ITBOwnerObject.GetRect(Au.Types.RECT@)
member.summary: Gets object rectangle. Returns false if failed.
member.param: Rectangle in screen coordinates.
member.remarks: Not called if the owner window is invisible or cloaked or minimized or if returned false.

member.name: T:Au.Types.MTBase
member.summary: Base class of and .

member.name: M:Au.Types.MTBase.OnClick_(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Common Click even handler of all items. Calls the true item's onClick callback if need. Calls it in correct thread.

member.name: P:Au.Types.MTBase.ActionThread
member.summary: In what thread to execute item actions (callback functions). Default: for AMenu created with the parameterless constructor, else .
member.remarks: If current thread is a UI thread (has windows etc), and item callback functions execute some long automations in the same thread, current thread probably is hung during that time. Use this property to avoid it. This property is applied to items added afterwards.

member.name: P:Au.Types.MTBase.ExceptionHandling
member.summary: Whether/how to handle unhandled exceptions in item action code. Default: (don't handle exceptions if is (default), else show warning).
member.remarks: This property is applied to items added afterwards.

member.summary: Gets ToolStrip of AMenu and AToolbar, which override this.

member.name: P:Au.Types.MTBase.LastItem

member.name: E:Au.Types.MTBase.ItemAdded
member.summary: Occurs when added a non-separator item.
member.remarks: Allows to set item properties in single place instead of after each 'add item' code line. For example, the event handler can set item properties common to all items.

member.name: P:Au.Types.MTBase.IconSize
member.summary: Image width and height. Default is .
member.exception: The 'set' function is called after adding items.
member.remarks: This property is applied to all items, and can be set only before adding items (else exception). To set different icon size for a submenu: using(m.Submenu("sub")) { m.LastMenuItem.DropDown.ImageScalingSize = new Size(24, 24);

member.name: F:Au.Types.MTThread.StaBackgroundThread
member.summary: Execute item callback functions in new STA background threads (). Note: current thread does not wait until the callback function finishes.

member.name: T:Au.Types.MTExcept
member.summary: Used with .

member.name: F:Au.Types.MTExcept.Exception
member.summary: Don't handle exceptions. This is default. However if is not , handles exceptions and shows warning. On unhandled exception .NET probably will show an unhandled exception dialog with exception info and "Continue" button, unless your app uses event.

member.name: F:Au.Types.MTExcept.Warning
member.summary: Handle exceptions. On exception call .

member.name: F:Au.Types.MTExcept.Silent
member.summary: Handle exceptions. On exception do nothing.

member.name: T:Au.Types.MTImage
member.summary: Used for menu/toolbar function parameters to specify an image in different ways (file path, Image object, etc). More info in Remarks.
member.remarks: Has implicit conversions from: - string - path of .ico or any other file or folder or non-file object. See . - string with prefix "image:" - Base-64 encoded png file. Can be created with the "Find image..." dialog. - string with prefix "key:" - imagelist image key (). - int - imagelist image index (). - Image - image object. - Icon - icon object. - - a shell icon. - FolderPath - folder path. - default - no icon. If == true, extracts icon path from onClick code like AFile.TryRun(@"c:\path\file.exe") or AFile.TryRun(AFolders.System + "file.exe"). - "" - no icon.

member.name: P:Au.Types.MTImage.Value
member.summary: Gets the raw value stored in this variable. Can be string, int, Image, Icon, null.

member.name: T:Au.Types.FileDir

member.summary: Does not exist, or failed to get attributes.

member.summary: Is file, or symbolic link to a file.
