member.summary: Is directory, or symbolic link to a directory.

member.name: T:Au.Types.FileDir2
member.summary: File system entry type - file, directory, symbolic link, whether it exists and is accessible. Returned by . The enum value NotFound is 0; AccessDenied is negative ((int)0x80000000); other values are greater than 0.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileDir2.NotFound
member.summary: Does not exist.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileDir2.File
member.summary: Is file. Attributes: Directory no, ReparsePoint no.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileDir2.Directory
member.summary: Is directory. Attributes: Directory yes, ReparsePoint no.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileDir2.SymLinkFile
member.summary: Is symbolic link to a file. Attributes: Directory no, ReparsePoint yes.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileDir2.SymLinkDirectory
member.summary: Is symbolic link to a directory, or is a mounted folder. Attributes: Directory yes, ReparsePoint yes.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileDir2.AccessDenied
member.summary: Exists but this process cannot access it and get attributes.

member.name: T:Au.Types.FAFlags
member.summary: Flags for and some other functions.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FAFlags.UseRawPath
member.summary: Pass path to the API as it is, without any normalizing and validating.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FAFlags.DontThrow
member.summary: If failed, return false and don't throw exception. Then, if you need error info, you can use . If the file/directory does not exist, it will return ERROR_FILE_NOT_FOUND or ERROR_PATH_NOT_FOUND or ERROR_NOT_READY. If failed and the native error code is ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED or ERROR_SHARING_VIOLATION, the returned attributes will be (FileAttributes)(-1). The file probably exists but is protected so that this process cannot access and use it. Else attributes will be 0.

member.name: T:Au.Types.FileProperties
member.summary: File or directory properties. Used with .

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileProperties.Size
member.summary: File size. For directories it is usually 0.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileProperties.LastAccessTimeUtc
member.summary: Note: this is unreliable. The operating system may not record this time automatically.

member.name: T:Au.Types.FEFlags
member.summary: flags for .

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.AndSubdirectories
member.summary: Enumerate subdirectories too.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.AndSymbolicLinkSubdirectories
member.summary: Also enumerate symbolic link and mounted folder target directories. Use with AndSubdirectories.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.SkipHidden
member.summary: Skip files and subdirectories that have Hidden attribute.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.SkipHiddenSystem
member.summary: Skip files and subdirectories that have Hidden and System attributes (both). These files/directories usually are created and used only by the operating system. Drives usually have several such directories. Another example - thumbnail cache files. Without this flag the function skips only these hidden-system root directories when enumerating a drive: "$Recycle.Bin", "System Volume Information", "Recovery". If you want to include them too, use network path of the drive, for example @"\\localhost\D$\" for D drive.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.IgnoreInaccessible
member.summary: If fails to get contents of the directory or a subdirectory because of its security settings, assume that the [sub]directory is empty. Without this flag then throws exception or calls errorHandler.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.DisableRedirection
member.summary: Temporarily disable file system redirection in this thread of this 32-bit process running on 64-bit Windows. Then you can enumerate the 64-bit System32 folder in your 32-bit process. Uses API Wow64DisableWow64FsRedirection. For vice versa (in 64-bit process enumerate the 32-bit System folder), instead use path AFolders.SystemX86.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.UseRawPath
member.summary: Don't call (directoryPath) and don't throw exception for non-full path.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FEFlags.NeedRelativePaths
member.summary: Let be path relative to the specified directory path. Like @"\name.txt" or @"\subdirectory\name.txt" instead of "name.txt".

member.name: T:Au.Types.FCFlags
member.summary: flags for and some other similar functions. Used only when copying directory.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FCFlags.SkipHiddenSystem
member.summary: Skip descendant files and directories that have Hidden and System attributes (both). They usually are created and used only by the operating system. Drives usually have several such directories. Another example - thumbnail cache files. They often are protected and would fail to copy, ruining whole copy operation. Without this flag the function skips only these hidden-system root directories when enumerating a drive: "$Recycle.Bin", "System Volume Information", "Recovery".

member.name: F:Au.Types.FCFlags.IgnoreInaccessible
member.summary: If fails to get contents of the directory or a subdirectory because of its security settings, don't throw exception but assume that the [sub]directory is empty.

member.name: T:Au.Types.FEFile
member.summary: Contains name and other main properties of a file or subdirectory retrieved by . The values are not changed after creating the variable.

member.name: P:Au.Types.FEFile.Size
member.summary: Returns file size. For directories it is usually 0.

member.name: P:Au.Types.FEFile.IsDirectory
member.summary: Returns true if is directory or symbolic link to a directory or mounted folder.

member.name: P:Au.Types.FEFile.Level
member.summary: Descendant level. 0 if direct child of directoryPath, 1 if child of child, an so on.

member.name: M:Au.Types.FEFile.SkipThisDirectory
member.summary: Call this function if don't want to enumerate children of this subdirectory.

member.name: M:Au.Types.FEFile.ToString
member.summary: Returns FullPath.

member.name: T:Au.Types.FIfExists
member.summary: What to do if the destination directory contains a file or directory with the same name as the source file or directory when copying, moving or renaming. Used with , and similar functions. When renaming or moving, if the destination is the same as the source, these options are ignored and the destination is simply renamed. For example when renaming "file.txt" to "FILE.TXT".

member.name: F:Au.Types.FIfExists.Fail
member.summary: Throw exception. Default.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FIfExists.Delete
member.summary: Delete destination.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FIfExists.RenameExisting
member.summary: Rename (backup) destination.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FIfExists.MergeDirectory
member.summary: If destination directory exists, merge the source directory into it, replacing existing files. If destination file exists, deletes it. If destination directory exists and source is file, fails.

member.name: T:Au.Types.FileId
member.summary: Contains file properties that can be used to uniquely identify the file on a single computer.
member.remarks: Can be used with files and directories. To get it, use . There are many different ways to specify path to the same file or directory. To determine whether two paths represent the same file, get and compare their FileId.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileId.VolumeSerialNumber
member.summary: The serial number of the volume (aka disk drive) that contains the file.

member.name: F:Au.Types.FileId.FileIndex
member.summary: An identifier that is associated with the file. It is unique in that volume.

member.remarks: Implicit conversion from string sets .

member.name: M:Au.Types.ROptions.op_Implicit(System.String)~Au.Types.ROptions
member.summary: Sets .

member.name: F:Au.Types.ROptions.CurrentDirectory
member.summary: Initial current directory for the new process. If null (default), the new process will inherit the curent directory of this process. If "", the function gets parent directory path from the file parameter, if possible (if full path is specified or found). If not possible, same as null. Some programs look for their files in current directory and fail to start if it is not the program's directory.

member.name: F:Au.Types.ROptions.Verb
member.summary: File's right-click menu command, also known as verb. For example "edit", "print", "properties". The default verb is bold in the menu. Not all menu items will work. Some may have different name than in the menu.

member.name: F:Au.Types.ROptions.OwnerWindow
member.summary: Owner window for error message boxes. Also, new window should be opened on the same screen. However many programs ignore it.

member.name: F:Au.Types.ROptions.WindowState
member.summary: Preferred window state. Many programs ignore it.

member.name: T:Au.Types.RResult
member.summary: Results of .

member.name: P:Au.Types.RResult.ProcessExitCode
member.summary: The exit code of the process. 0 if no flag WaitForExit or if cannot wait.
member.remarks: Usually the exit code is 0 or a process-defined error code.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RResult.ProcessId
member.summary: The process id. 0 if used flag WaitForExit or if did not start new process (eg opened the document in an existing process) or if cannot get it.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RResult.ProcessHandle
member.summary: If used flag NeedProcessHandle, contains process handle. Later the variable must be disposed. null if no flag or if did not start new process (eg opened the document in an existing process) or if cannot get it.

member.name: M:Au.Types.RResult.ToString
member.summary: Returns as string.

member.name: T:Au.Types.SLTransaction
member.summary: A SQLite transaction or savepoint. The main purpose is to automatically rollback if not explicitly committed. Usage: using(var trans = new SLTransaction(db)) { ... trans.Commit(); }

member.name: P:Au.Types.SLTransaction.SqlOfDispose
member.summary: Gets or sets SQL to execute when disposing this variable if not called or . Initially = parameter sqlOfDispose of constructor.

member.name: M:Au.Types.SLTransaction.#ctor(Au.ASqlite,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Begins a SQLite transaction and prepares for automatic rollback if not explicitly committed. Usage: using(var trans = new SLTransaction(db)) { ... trans.Commit(); }
member.param: SQL to execute now. Default "BEGIN". For nested transaction use "SAVEPOINT name".
SQL to execute when disposing this variable if not called or . Default "ROLLBACK". For nested transaction use "ROLLBACK TO name". See also: .

member.name: M:Au.Types.SLTransaction.Dispose
member.summary: Calls if not called or .

member.name: M:Au.Types.SLTransaction.Rollback(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a rollback SQL (if in transaction) and disables . Usually don't need to call this function explicitly. It is implicitly called when disposing this variable if the transaction was not committed.
member.param: SQL to execute. Default: .

member.name: M:Au.Types.SLTransaction.Commit(System.String)
member.summary: Executes a commit SQL and disables .
member.param: SQL to execute. Default "COMMIT". For nested transaction use "RELEASE name".

member.name: T:Au.Types.UacIL
member.summary: UAC integrity level. See .

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacIL.Untrusted
member.summary: The most limited rights. Rare.

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacIL.Low
member.summary: Very limited rights. Used by web browser tab processes, Windows Store apps.

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacIL.Medium
member.summary: Limited rights. Most processes (unless UAC turned off).

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacIL.UIAccess
member.summary: Medium IL + can access/automate High IL windows (user interface).

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacIL.High
member.summary: Most rights. Processes that run as administrator.

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacIL.System
member.summary: Almost all rights. Services, some system processes.

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacIL.Protected
member.summary: Undocumented. Rare.

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacIL.Unknown
member.summary: Failed to get IL. Unlikely.

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacElevation.Unknown
member.summary: Failed to get. Normally it never happens.

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacElevation.Default
member.summary: Processes in this user session cannot be elevated. Can be: non-administrator user session (processes have limited rights); service session (processes have all rights); UAC is turned off (most processes have administrator rights).

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacElevation.Full
member.summary: Runs as administrator (High or System integrity level), and UAC is not turned off. Also known as "elevated".

member.name: F:Au.Types.UacElevation.Limited
member.summary: Runs as standard user (Medium, UIAccess or Low integrity level) in administrator user session (because of UAC).

member.name: T:Au.Types.ClipFormats
member.summary: Some clipboard format ids. These and other standard and registered format ids can be used with class functions.

member.name: F:Au.Types.ClipFormats.Text
member.summary: The text format. Standard, API constant CF_UNICODETEXT. The default format of add/get text functions.

member.name: F:Au.Types.ClipFormats.Image
member.summary: The image format. Standard, API constant CF_BITMAP. Used by add/get image functions.

member.name: F:Au.Types.ClipFormats.Files
member.summary: The file-list format. Standard, API constant CF_HDROP. Used by add/get files functions.

member.name: P:Au.Types.ClipFormats.Html
member.summary: The HTML format. Registered, name "HTML Format". Used by add/get HTML functions.

member.name: P:Au.Types.ClipFormats.Rtf
member.summary: The RTF format. Registered, name "Rich Text Format". Used by add/get RTF functions.

member.name: P:Au.Types.ClipFormats.ClipboardViewerIgnore
member.summary: The "Clipboard Viewer Ignore" registered format.
member.remarks: Some clipboard viewer/manager programs don't try to get clipboard data if this format is present. For example Ditto, Clipdiary. The copy/paste functions of this library add this format to the clipboard to avoid displaying the temporary text/data in these programs, which also could make the paste function slower and less reliable.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ClipFormats.Register(System.String,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Registers a clipboard format and returns its id. If already registered, just returns id.
member.param: Format name.
Text encoding, if it's a text format. Used by , and functions that call them. For example or (ANSI). If null, text of unknown formats is considered Unicode UTF-16 (no encoding/decoding needed).
member.remarks: Calls API RegisterClipboardFormat.

member.name: M:Au.Types.ClipFormats.GetTextEncoding_(System.Int32,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Gets text encoding for format. Returns null if UTF-16 or if the format is unknown and not in s_textEncoding.

member.name: M:Au.Types.HookData.ReplyMessage(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calls API API ReplyMessage, which allows to use and COM in the hook procedure.
member.param: Don't notify the target window about the event, and don't call other hook procedures. This value is used instead of the return value of the hook procedure, which is ignored.
member.remarks: It can be used as a workaround for this problem: in low-level hook procedure some functions don't work with some windows. For example cannot get an accessible object or use a COM object. Error/exception "An outgoing call cannot be made since the application is dispatching an input-synchronous call (0x8001010D)".

member.name: T:Au.Types.KMod
member.summary: Modifier keys as flags.
member.remarks: The values don't match those in the .NET enum . This library does not use the .NET enum for modifier keys, mostly because it: does not have Win as modifier flag; confusing names, for example Alt and Menu.

member.name: T:Au.Types.KKey
member.summary: Virtual-key codes.
member.remarks: The values are the same as the native VK_ constants. Also the same as in the enum, but not as in the WPF Key enum. Some key names are different than VK_/Keys, for example Alt instead of VK_MENU/Menu. Most rare and obsolete keys are not included. You can use Keys or VK_ (int) like (KKey)Keys.Attn. This library does not use the .NET Keys enum, mostly because it includes modifier key flags and it's easy to confuse eg Shift (flag) with ShiftKey (key). Also this library does not use the WPF Key enum; its values don't match the native VK_ constants that must be used with API functions.

member.name: T:Au.Types.MButton
member.summary: button parameter type for and similar functions.
member.remarks:
There are two groups of values: 1. Button (Left, Right, Middle, X1, X2). Default or 0: Left. 2. Action (Down, Up, DoubleClick). Default: click.
Multiple values from the same group cannot be combined. For example Left|Right is invalid. Values from different groups can be combined. For example Right|Down.

member.name: T:Au.Types.OsdShowMode
member.summary: Whether waits or shows the OSD window in this or new thread.
member.remarks: If this thread has windows, any value can be used, but usually Auto (default) or ThisThread is the best.

member.name: F:Au.Types.OsdShowMode.Auto
member.summary: Depends on . If it is true, uses ThisThread, else StrongThread. Does not wait.

member.name: F:Au.Types.OsdShowMode.ThisThread
member.summary: Show the OSD window in this thread and don't wait. Should not be used if this thread does not process messages and therefore cannot have windows.

member.name: F:Au.Types.OsdShowMode.WeakThread
member.summary: Show the OSD window in new thread and don't wait. Set =true, so that the OSD is closed when other threads of this app end.

member.name: F:Au.Types.OsdShowMode.StrongThread
member.summary: Show the OSD window in new thread and don't wait. Set =false, so that the OSD is not closed when other threads of this app end.

member.name: F:Au.Types.OsdShowMode.Wait
member.summary: Show the OSD window in this thread and wait until it disappears. Waits seconds. While waiting, dispatches messages etc; see .

member.name: T:Au.Types.WIArea
member.summary: Defines the search area for and similar functions.
member.remarks: It can be a window/control, accessible object, another image or a rectangle in screen. Also allows to specify a rectangle in it, which makes the search area smaller and the function faster. Has implicit conversions from AWnd, AAcc, Bitmap, RECT (rectangle in screen), tuple (AWnd, RECT), tuple (Acc, RECT). Example: AWinImage.Find((w, (left, top, width, height)), image);.

member.name: T:Au.Types.WIImage
member.summary: Image(s) or color(s) for and similar functions.
member.remarks:
Has implicit conversions from: - string - path of .png or .bmp file.
If not full path, uses .
If the file does not exist, looks in resources of the entry assembly. For example, looks for Project.Properties.Resources.X if file @"C:\X.png" not found. - string that starts with "image:" - Base64-encoded .png image embedded in script text.
Can be created with dialog "Find image or color in window" or with function Au.Controls.ImageUtil.ImageToString (in Au.Controls.dll). - ColorInt, int, Color - color. Int must be in 0xRRGGBB format. Alpha isn't used. - - image object. - WIImage[] - multiple images or/and colors. Action - find any. To create a different action can be used callback function (parameter also).
Icons are not supported directly, but you can use or .

member.name: P:Au.Types.WIImage.Value
member.summary: Gets the raw value stored in this variable. Can be string, Bitmap, ColorInt, WIImage[], null.

member.name: T:Au.Types.WIFlags
member.summary: Flags for and similar functions.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIFlags.WindowDC
member.summary: Get pixels from the device context (DC) of the window client area, not from screen DC. Usually much faster. Can get pixels from window parts that are covered by other windows or offscreen. But not from hidden and minimized windows. Does not work on Windows 7 if Aero theme is turned off. Then this flag is ignored. Cannot find images in some windows (including Windows Store apps), and in some window parts (glass). All pixels captured from these windows/parts are black. If the window is DPI-scaled, the image must be captured from its non-scaled version.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIFlags.PrintWindow
member.summary: Use API PrintWindow to get window pixels. Like WindowDC, works with background windows, etc. Differences: - On Windows 8.1 and later works with all windows and all window parts. - Works without Aero theme too. - Slower than with WindowDC, although usually faster than without these flags. - Some windows may flicker. - Does not work with windows of higher UAC integrity level. Then this flag is ignored.

member.name: T:Au.Types.WIAlso
member.summary: Used with and . Its callback function (parameter also) can return one of these values.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIAlso.OkReturn
member.summary: Stop searching. Let the main function (Find or Wait) return current result.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIAlso.OkFindMore
member.summary: Find more instances of current image. If used list of images, also search for other images. Then let the main function return current result.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIAlso.OkFindMoreOfThis
member.summary: Find more instances of current image. When used list of images, don't search for other images. Then let the main function return current result.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIAlso.OkFindMoreOfList
member.summary: If used list of images, search for other images. Don't search for more instances of current image. Then let the main function return current result.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIAlso.NotFound
member.summary: Stop searching. Let Find return null. Let Wait continue waiting. But if a Find...Return value used previously, return that result.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIAlso.FindOther
member.summary: Find more instances of current image. If used list of images, also search for other images. If not found, let Find return null; let Wait continue waiting; but if a Find...Return value used previously, return that result.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIAlso.FindOtherOfThis
member.summary: Find more instances of current image. When used list of images, don't search for other images. If not found, let Find return null; let Wait continue waiting; but if a Find...Return value used previously, return that result.

member.name: F:Au.Types.WIAlso.FindOtherOfList
member.summary: If used list of images, search for other images. Don't search for more instances of current image. If not found, let Find return null; let Wait continue waiting; but if a Find...Return value used previously, return that result.

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXMatch
member.summary: Regular expression match info. Used with class functions and String extension methods like .
member.remarks: Contains info about a regular expression match found in the subject string: index, length, substring, etc. Also contains an array of group matches, as . Groups are regular expression parts enclosed in (), except (?...). Group matches can be accessed like array elements. Group 0 is whole match. Group 1 is the first group. See examples.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.GroupCountPlusOne
member.summary: The number of groups in the regular expression, + 1 for the whole match.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Start
member.summary: Start offset of the match in the subject string. The same as that of group 0.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.End
member.summary: + . The same as that of group 0.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Length

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.StartNoK
member.summary: Start offset of whole match regardless of \K. When the regular expression contains \K, this is less than .

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Mark
member.summary: The name of a found mark, or null. Marks can be inserted in regular expression pattern like (*MARK:name) or (*:name). After a full successful match, it is the last mark encountered on the matching path through the pattern. After a "no match" or a partial match, it is the last encountered mark. For example, consider this pattern: "^(*MARK:A)((*MARK:B)a|b)c". When it matches "bc", the mark is A. The B mark is "seen" in the first branch of the group, but it is not on the matching path. On the other hand, when this pattern fails to match "bx", the mark is B.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXMatch.Exists
member.summary: Gets the return value of the call. Can be false only when the function returned false but a mark is available (see ). Otherwise, when the function returns flase, it returns null instead of a RXMatch object. When false, all properties except Exists and Mark have undefined values or throw exception.

member.summary: Returns the expanded version of the specified replacement pattern.
member.param: Replacement pattern. Can consist of any combination of literal text and substitutions like $1. Supports .NET regular expression substitution syntax. See . Also: replaces $* with the name of the last encountered mark; replaces ${+func} with the return value of a function registered with .
member.remarks: Works like . See also: .

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXGroup
member.summary: Regular expression group match info. Used with , and some String extension methods.
member.remarks:
Groups are regular expression parts enclosed in (). Except non-capturing parts, like (?:...) and (?options). A RXGroup variable contains info about a group found in the subject string: index, length, substring.
Some groups specified in regular expression may not exist in the subject string even if it matches the regular expression. For example, regular expression "A(\d+)?B" matches string "AB", but group (\d+) does not exist. Then is false, -1, 0, null.
When a group matches multiple times, the RXGroup variable contains only the last instance. For example, if subject is "begin 12 345 67 end" and regular expression is (\d+ )+, value of group 1 is "67". If you need all instances ("12", "345", "67"), instead use .NET and . Also you can get all instances with .
Examples and more info: , .

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXCalloutData
member.summary: Managed version of PCRE API struct pcre2_callout_block. When you set , your callout function's parameter is of this type. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout. Most properties are pcre2_callout_block fields as documented in PCRE help. Other properties and methods are easier/safer versions of unsafe fields like offset_vector.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.Result
member.summary: Sets the return value of the callout function, as documented in PCRE help topic pcre2callout. Default 0. If 1, matching fails at the current point, but the testing of other matching possibilities goes ahead, just as if a lookahead assertion had failed. If -1 (PCRE2_ERROR_NOMATCH), the match function returns false (no match). Values less tan -2 are PCRE error codes and cause exception.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.callout_number

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.capture_last
member.summary: The number of the most recently captured group. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout.

member.name: P:Au.Types.RXCalloutData.callout_flags

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXFlags
member.summary: Flags for constructor. Documented in PCRE help topic pcre2api.
member.remarks:
Many options also can be specified in regular expression (RE): - These can be anywhere in RE: (?i) CASELESS, (?m) MULTILINE, (?s) DOTALL, (?n) NO_AUTO_CAPTURE, (?x) EXTENDED, (?xx) EXTENDED_MORE, (?J) DUPNAMES, (?U) UNGREEDY. Can be multiple, like (?ms). Can be unset, like (?-i). RE "\Qtext\E" is like RE "text" with flag LITERAL. - Instead of ANCHORED can be used \A or \G at the start of RE. Or ^, except in multiline mode. - Instead of ENDANCHORED can be used \z at the end of RE. Or $, except in multiline mode. - Flag UTF is implicitly added if RE contains non-ASCII characters and there is no flag NEVER_UTF. - These must be at the very start and are named like flags: (*UTF), (*UCP), (*NOTEMPTY), (*NOTEMPTY_ATSTART), (*NO_AUTO_POSSESS), (*NO_DOTSTAR_ANCHOR), (*NO_START_OPT). - More info in PCRE syntax reference.
Some of RXFlags flags also exist in . You can set them either when calling ARegex constructor or when calling ARegex functions that have parameter more. You can use different flags for each function call with the same ARegex variable.

member.name: F:Au.Types.RXFlags.UTF
member.summary: Fully support Unicode text (case-insensitivity etc). More info in PCRE documentation topic pcre2unicode. This flag is implicitly added if regular expression contains non-ASCII characters and there is no flag NEVER_UTF.

member.name: T:Au.Types.RXMatchFlags
member.summary: Flags for and other class functions. Documented in PCRE help topic pcre2api.
member.remarks: These flags also exist in (ARegex constructor flags). You can set them either when calling constructor or when calling other functions.

member.name: T:Au.ALastError
member.summary: Gets, sets or clears the last error code of Windows API. Gets error text.
member.remarks:
Many Windows API functions, when failed, set an error code. Code 0 means no error. It is stored in an internal thread-specific int variable. But only if the API declaration's DllImport attribute has SetLastError = true.
Some functions of this library simply call these API functions and don't throw exception when API fail. For example, most propery-get functions. When failed, they return false/0/null/empty. Then you can use to get the error code or to get error text.
Most of functions set error code only when failed, and don't clear the old error code when succeeded. Therefore may need to call before.
Windows API error code definitions and documentation are not included in this library. You can look for them in API function documentation on the internet.

member.name: M:Au.ALastError.Clear
member.summary: Calls API SetLastError(0), which clears the Windows API last error code of this thread.
member.remarks: Need it before calling some functions if you want to use or . The same as ALastError.Code = 0;.

member.name: P:Au.ALastError.Code
member.summary: Gets () or sets (API SetLastError) the Windows API last error code of this thread.

member.name: P:Au.ALastError.Message
member.summary: Gets the text message of the Windows API last error code of this thread. Returns null if the code is 0.
member.remarks: The string always ends with ".".

member.name: M:Au.ALastError.MessageFor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the text message of a Windows API error code. Returns null if errorCode is 0.
member.remarks: The string always ends with ".".

member.name: T:Au.AOpt
member.summary: Options for some functions of this library.
member.remarks:
Some frequently used static functions of this library have some options (settings). For example allows to change speed, text sending method, etc. Passing options as parameters in each call usually isn't what you want to do in automation scripts. Instead you can set options using static properties. This class contains several groups of options for functions of various classes. See examples.
There are two sets of identical or similar options - in class AOpt and in class : - AOpt - thread-static options (each thread has its own instance). Functions of this library use them. You can change or change-restore them anywhere in script. Initial options are automatically copied from AOpt.Static when that group of options (Key, Mouse, etc) is used first time in that thread (explicitly or by library functions). - AOpt.Static - static options. Contains initial property values for AOpt. Normally you change them at the very start of script. Don't change later, it's not thread-safe.

member.name: P:Au.AOpt.Key
member.summary: Options for keyboard and clipboard functions (classes , and functions that use them).
member.remarks: Each thread has its own AOpt.Key instance. It inherits options from . Also can be used when creating instances. See the second example.

member.name: P:Au.AOpt.Mouse
member.summary: Options for mouse functions (class and functions that use it).
member.remarks: Each thread has its own AOpt.Mouse instance. It inherits options from .

example.code: AOpt.Mouse.ClickSpeed = 100; AMouse.Click();

member.name: P:Au.AOpt.WaitFor
member.summary: Options for 'wait for' functions.
member.remarks: Each thread has its own AOpt.WaitFor instance. There is no AOpt.Static.WaitFor. Most 'wait for' functions of this library use these options. Functions of .NET classes don't.

member.name: P:Au.AOpt.Warnings
member.summary: Options for showing run-time warnings and other info that can be useful to find problems in code at run time.
member.remarks: Each thread has its own AOpt.Warnings instance. It inherits options from .

member.name: T:Au.AOpt.Static
member.summary: Default properties of each thread.
member.remarks: You can change these options at the start of your script/program. Don't change later.

member.name: P:Au.AOpt.Static.Key
member.summary: Default option values for of each thread.
member.remarks: Also can be used when creating instances. See the second example.
member.example:
AOpt.Static.Key.KeySpeed = 10; ... AKeys.Key("Tab Ctrl+V"); //uses AOpt.Key, which is implicitly copied from AOpt.Static.Key
Use an AKeys instance.
var k = new AKeys(AOpt.Static.Key); //create new AKeys instance and copy options from AOpt.Static.Key to it k.Options.KeySpeed = 100; //changes option of k but not of AOpt.Static.Key k.Add("Tab Ctrl+V").Send(); //uses options of k

member.name: P:Au.ADialog.Send
member.summary: Allows to modify dialog controls while it is open, and close the dialog.
member.remarks:
Example: d.Send.Close(); . Example: d.Send.ChangeText2("new text", false); . Example: d.Send.Message(Native.TDM.CLICK_VERIFICATION, 1); .
Can be used only while the dialog is open. Before showing the dialog returns null. After closing the dialog the returned variable is deactivated; its method calls are ignored. Can be used in dialog event handlers. Also can be used in another thread, for example with and .

member.name: M:Au.ADialog.Show(System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.DFlags,Au.Types.DIcon,Au.Types.AnyWnd,System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.DControls,System.Int32,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Int32,System.Action{Au.Types.DEventArgs})
member.summary: Shows dialog. Returns selected button id.
member.param: Main instruction. Bigger font.
Text below main instruction.

Button ids and labels. Examples: "OK|Cancel", "1 &Save|2 Do&n't Save|0 Cancel". If omitted, null or "", the dialog will have OK button, id 1. Common buttons: OK, Yes, No, Retry, Cancel, Close. More info in Remarks.
Owner window. See .
Text that the user can show and hide.
Text at the bottom of the dialog. Icon can be specified like "i|Text", where i is: x error, ! warning, i info, v shield, a app.
Title bar text. If omitted, null or "", uses .
Can be used to add more controls and later get their values: checkbox, radio buttons, text input.
id of button that responds to the Enter key.
X position in . If default - screen center. You also can use etc.
Y position in . If default - screen center. You also can use etc.
If not 0, after this time (seconds) auto-close the dialog and return .
member.remarks:
Tip: Use named arguments. Example: ADialog.Show("Text", icon: DIcon.Info, title: "Title") .
This function allows you to use many dialog features, but not all. Alternatively you can create an ADialog class instance, set properties and call ShowDialog. Example in class help.
##### More info about the buttons parameter
Missing ids are auto-generated, for example "OK|Cancel|100 Custom1|Custom2" is the same as "1 OK|2 Cancel|100 Custom1|101 Custom2".
The first in the list button is default, ie responds to the Enter key. For example, "2 No|1 Yes" adds Yes and No buttons and makes No default.
To create keyboard shortcuts, use & character in custom button labels. Use && for literal &. Example: "1 &Tuesday[]2 T&hursday[]3 Saturday && Sunday".
Trims newlines around ids and labels. For example, "\r\n1 One\r\n|\r\n2\r\nTwo\r\n\r\n" is the same as "1 One|2 Two".
There are 6 common buttons: OK, Yes, No, Retry, Cancel, Close. Buttons that have other labels are custom buttons. How common buttons are different: 1. DFlags.CommandLinks does not change their style. 2. They have keyboard shortcuts that cannot be changed. Inserting & in a label makes it a custom button. 3. Button Cancel can be selected with the Esc key. It also adds X (Close) button in title bar, which selects Cancel. 4. Always displayed in standard order (eg Yes No, never No Yes). But you can for example use "2 No|1 Yes" to set default button = No. 5. The displayed button label is localized, ie different when the Windows UI language is not English.
You can use flag to change the style of custom buttons.
See also: .

member.name: M:Au.AMenu.Separator
member.summary: Adds separator.

member.name: M:Au.AMenu.Submenu(System.String,Au.Types.MTImage,System.Action{Au.Types.MTClickArgs},System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds new item () that will open a submenu. Then the add-item functions will add items to the submenu.
member.param: Text.
Callback function. Called when the item clicked. Rarely used.
member.remarks:
Can be used in 2 ways: - using(m.Submenu(...)) { add items; }. See example. - m.Submenu(...); add items; m.EndSubmenu();. See .
Submenus inherit these properties of the main menu, set before adding submenus (see example): BackgroundImage, BackgroundImageLayout, Cursor, Font, ForeColor, ImageList, ImageScalingSize, Renderer, ShowCheckMargin, ShowImageMargin.

member.name: M:Au.AMenu.EndSubmenu
member.summary: Call this to end adding items to the current submenu if was called without 'using' and without a callback function that adds submenu items.

member.name: M:Au.AMenu.LazySubmenu(System.String,System.Action{Au.AMenu},Au.Types.MTImage,System.Action{Au.Types.MTClickArgs},System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds new item () that will open a submenu. When showing the submenu first time, your callback function will be called and can add submenu items.
member.param: Text.
Callback function that should add submenu items.
Callback function. Called when the item clicked. Rarely used.

member.name: P:Au.AMenu.CurrentAddMenu
member.summary: Gets of the main menu or submenu where new items currently would be added.

member.name: P:Au.AMenu.LastMenuItem
member.summary: Gets the last added item as . Returns null if it is not a ToolStripMenuItem.
member.remarks: You can instead use , which gets , the base class of all supported item types; cast it to a derived type if need.

member.name: M:Au.AMenu.Show(System.Nullable{Au.Types.POINT},System.Boolean,System.Nullable{System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownDirection})
member.summary: Shows the menu unowned.
member.param: Position in screen. If null (default), uses the mouse cursor or caret position.
Show at the text cursor (caret) position, if available. Then xy is offset.
Menu drop direction.

member.name: M:Au.AMenu.Show(System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Nullable{Au.Types.POINT},System.Boolean,System.Nullable{System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownDirection})
member.summary: Shows the menu owned by a control or form.
member.param: A control or form that will own the menu.
Position in control's client area. If null (default), uses the mouse cursor or caret position.
Show at the text cursor (caret) position, if available. Then xy is offset.
Menu drop direction.
member.remarks: Alternatively you can assign the context menu to a control or toolstrip's drop-down button etc, then don't need to call Show. Use the property, which gets .

member.name: P:Au.AMenu.MultiShow
member.summary: If false, disposes the menu when it is closed. If true, does not dispose. Then you can call Show again and again. Default is false, but is automatically set to true when showing the menu not with Show, eg when assigned to a control's ContextMenuStrip.

member.name: P:Au.AMenu.DefaultMultiShow
member.summary: Default value for new AMenu instances.

member.name: P:Au.AMenu.Modal
member.summary: If true, Show waits until the menu is closed. If false, does not wait (this thread must have a message loop). If null (default), does not wait if the thread has a .NET message loop ().

remarks.note: If false, this thread must have a message loop, either already running or started soon after showing the menu. Without it the menu will not work.

member.name: P:Au.AMenu.ActivateMenuWindow
member.summary: Activate the menu window. It enables selecting menu items with the keyboard (arrows, Tab, Enter, etc). If false, only Esc works, it closes the menu. If the menu is owned by a control or toolbar button, keyboard navigation works in any case, don't need this property to enable it.

member.name: P:Au.AMenu.MouseClosingDistance
member.summary: Close the menu when the mouse cursor moves away from it to this distance, pixels. Only if the toolbar's thread is not the active UI thread.
member.remarks: At first the mouse must be or move at less than half of the distance. Default is , default Au.Util.ADpi.ScaleInt(200).

member.name: P:Au.AMenu.DefaultMouseClosingDistance
member.summary: Default value of AMenu instances.

member.name: M:Au.AMenu.Close
member.summary: Closes the menu and its submenus.

member.name: M:Au.AMenu.ShowSimple(Au.Types.DStringList,System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Nullable{Au.Types.POINT},System.Boolean,System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownDirection)
member.summary: Creates and shows popup menu where items use ids instead of actions. Returns selected item id, or 0 if cancelled.
member.param: Menu items. Can be string[], List<string> or string like "One|Two|Three". Item id can be optionally specified like "1 One|2 Two|3 Three". If missing, uses id of previous non-separator item + 1. Example: "One|Two|100 Three Four" //1|2|100|101. For separators use null or empty strings: "One|Two||Three|Four".
Owner control/form or null.
Position in screen or owner's client area. If null (default), uses the mouse cursor position.
Show at the text cursor (caret) position, if available. Then xy is offset.
Menu drop direction.
member.remarks: The menu is modal; the function returns when it is closed.

member.name: T:Au.AToolbar
member.summary: Floating toolbar. Can be attached to windows of other programs.
member.remarks: Based on . Not thread-safe. All functions must be called from the same thread that created the AToolbar object, except where documented otherwise. Note that item actions by default run in other threads; see .

member.param: Toolbar name. Must be valid filename. Used for the toolbar's settings file name. Also sets 's Text property and is used by and some other functions.

If not null, sets the property. Can be used to extend the toolbar (add or change some features) by overriding control's functions etc. Define class that inherits from . Then create toolbars like var t = new AToolbar("name", control: new MyToolStripWindow());.
member.remarks:
Reads the settings file if exists, ie if settings changed in the past. See . If fails, writes warning to the output and uses default settings.
Creates object or uses control. Its window handle will be created in .
Sets properties: - = . - = true. - = . - = .

member.name: M:Au.AToolbar.Show(Au.AScreen)
member.summary: Shows the toolbar.
member.param: Can be used to define the screen. For example a screen index (0 the primary, 1 the first non-primary, and so on). If not specified, the toolbar will be attached to the screen where it is now or where will be moved later. If not specified and this toolbar is created by , uses its screen parameter.
member.remarks: The toolbar will be moved when the screen moved or resized.

member.name: M:Au.AToolbar.Show(Au.AWnd,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows the toolbar and attaches to a window.
member.param: Window or control. Can belong to any process.
Let the toolbar position be relative to the client area of the window.
member.remarks: The toolbar will be above the window in the Z order; moved when the window moved or resized; hidden when the window hidden, cloaked or minimized; destroyed when the window destroyed.

member.name: M:Au.AToolbar.Show(Au.AWnd,Au.Types.ITBOwnerObject)
member.summary: Shows the toolbar and attaches to an object in a window.
member.param: Window that contains the object. Can be control. Can belong to any process.
A variable of a user-defined class that implements interface. It provides object location, visibility, etc.
member.remarks: The toolbar will be above the window in the Z order; moved when the object or window moved or resized; hidden when the object or window hidden, cloaked or minimized; destroyed when the object or window destroyed.

member.name: M:Au.AToolbar.Show(Au.Triggers.TriggerArgs)
member.summary: Shows the toolbar. If ta is WindowTriggerArgs, attaches the toolbar to the trigger window. Else if ta != null, calls .

member.name: M:Au.AToolbar.Close
member.summary: Hides and disposes the toolbar. If it's a satellite toolbar, closes its owner too.
member.remarks: Can be called from any thread.

member.name: M:Au.AToolbar.Hide(System.Boolean,Au.Types.TBHide)
member.summary: Adds or removes a reason to temporarily hide the toolbar. The toolbar is hidden if at least one reason exists. See also .
member.param: true to hide (add reason), false to show (remove reason).
An user-defined reason to hide/unhide. Can be or a bigger value, eg (TBHide)0x20000, (TBHide)0x40000.
member.exception: - The toolbar was never shown ( not called). - It is a satellite toolbar. - Wrong thread. Must be called from the same thread that created the toolbar. See .
member.remarks: Toolbars are automatically hidden when the owner window is hidden, minimized, etc. This function can be used to hide toolbars for other reasons.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Hidden
member.summary: Gets current reasons why the toolbar is hidden. Returns 0 if not hidden.
member.remarks: Not used with satellite toolbars.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.IsOwned
member.summary: Returns true if the toolbar is attached to a window or an object in a window.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.OwnerWindow
member.summary: Returns the owner top-level window. Returns default(AWnd) if the toolbar is not owned. See .

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.NoText
member.summary: If true, buttons added afterwards will have image without text displayed (unless there is no image). Text will be displayed as tooltip, unless tooltip is specified.
member.remarks: This property is applied to items added afterwards. If true and the item has an image, sets item DisplayStyle property = Image. Else sets item AutoToolTip property = false.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Border
member.summary: Border style.
member.remarks: This property is in the context menu and is saved.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.BorderColor
member.summary: Border color.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Anchor
member.summary: Specifies to which owner window's edges the toolbar keeps constant distance when moving or resizing the owner.
member.remarks: The owner also can be a screen, control or other object. It is specified when calling . This property is in the context menu and is saved.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Offsets
member.summary: Specifies distances between edges of the toolbar and edges of its owner, depending on .
member.remarks:
Owner is specified when calling . It can be a window, screen, control or other object.
The type has 4 properties - Top, Bottom, Left and Right, but used are only those included in . For example, if Anchor is TopLeft, used are only Top and Left.
This property is updated when moving or resizing the toolbar. It is saved.

example.code: t.Offsets = new TBOffsets(150, 5, 0, 0);

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Layout
member.summary: Gets or sets Control's .
member.remarks: This property is in the context menu and is saved.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Sizable
member.summary: Whether the border can be used to resize the toolbar.
member.remarks: This property is in the context menu and is saved.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Size
member.summary: Toolbar width and height.
member.remarks: This property is updated when resizing the toolbar. It is saved.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.AutoSize
member.summary: Automatically resize the toolbar to make all buttons visible.
member.remarks:
Autosizing occurs when: - When showing the toolbar. - When the user resizes the toolbar. It also sets the wrap width. - When setting this property = true (in code or in the context menu) or changing or while it is true. - .
This property is in the context menu and is saved.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.AutoSizeWrapWidth
member.summary: When is true, this is the preferred width at which buttons are moved to the next row. Unlimited if 0.
member.remarks: This property is updated when the user resizes the toolbar while is true. It is saved. If flow direction is vertical, this is the preferred height at which buttons are moved to the next column.

member.name: M:Au.AToolbar.AutoSizeNow
member.summary: If true, resizes the toolbar now if need. Call after changing toolbar buttons etc at run time.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.MiscFlags
member.summary: Miscellaneous options.
member.remarks: This property is in the context menu (submenu "More") and is saved.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Transparency
member.summary: Opacity and transparent color.

example.code: t.Transparency = (64, null);

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.NoMenu
member.summary: Hides some context menu items or menu itself.
member.remarks: This property isn't saved.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.Satellite
member.summary: A toolbar attached to this toolbar. Can be null.
member.exception: The 'set' function throws if the satellite toolbar was attached to another toolbar or was shown as non-satellite toolbar.
member.remarks: The satellite toolbar is shown when mouse enters its owner toolbar and hidden when mouse leaves it and its owner. Like an "auto hide" feature. A toolbar can have multiple satellite toolbars at different times. A satellite toolbar can be attached/detached multiple times to the same toolbar.

member.name: P:Au.AToolbar.SatelliteOwner
member.summary: If this is a sattellite toolbar (), gets its owner toolbar. Else null.

member.name: T:Au.AFile
member.summary: File system functions.
member.remarks: Works with files and directories. Disk drives like @"C:\" or "C:" are directories too. Extends .NET file system classes such as and . Most functions support only full path. Most of them throw ArgumentException if passed a filename or relative path, ie in "current directory". Using current directory is unsafe. Most functions support extended-length paths (longer than 259). Such local paths should have @"\\?\" prefix, like @"\\?\C:\...". Such network path should be like @"\\?\UNC\server\share\...". See , . Many functions support long paths even without prefix.
member.summary: This class contains static functions to execute or open programs, other files, folders, web pages, etc.

member.name: M:Au.AFile.Enumerate(System.String,Au.Types.FEFlags,System.Func{Au.Types.FEFile,System.Boolean},System.Action{System.String})
member.summary: Gets names and other info of files and subdirectories in the specified directory. Returns an enumerable collection of objects containing the info.
member.param: Full path of the directory.

Callback function. Called for each file and subdirectory. If returns false, the file/subdirectory is not included in results. Can be useful when Enumerate is called indirectly, for example by the method. If you call it directly, you can instead skip the file in your foreach loop. Example: filter: k => k.IsDirectory || k.Name.Ends(".png", true). See .

Callback function. Called when fails to get children of a subdirectory, when using flag . Receives the subdirectory path. Can call .Code and throw an exception. If does not throw, the enumeration continues as if the directory is empty. If errorHandler not used, then Enumerate throws exception. See also: flag .
member.exception: directoryPath is invalid path or not full path.
Failed to get children of directoryPath or of a subdirectory.
member.remarks:
Uses API FindFirstFile.
By default gets only direct children. Use flag to get all descendants.
The paths that this function gets are normalized, ie may not start with exact directoryPath string. Expanded environment variables (see ), "..", DOS path etc. Paths longer than have @"\\?\" prefix (see ).
For symbolic links and mounted folders, gets info of the link/folder and not of its target.
These errors are ignored: 1. Missing target directory of a symbolic link or mounted folder. 2. If used flag - access denied.
When an error is ignored, the function works as if that [sub]directory is empty; does not throw exception and does not call errorHandler.
Enumeration of a subdirectory starts immediately after the subdirectory itself is retrieved.

member.name: M:Au.AFile.Delete(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Deletes file or directory. Does nothing if it does not exist (no exception).
member.param: Full path.

Send to the Recycle Bin. If not possible, delete anyway. Why could be not possible: 1. The file is in a removable drive (most removables don't have a recycle bin). 2. The file is too large. 3. The path is too long. 4. The Recycle Bin is not used on that drive (it can be set in the Recycle Bin Properties dialog). 5. This process is non-UI-interactive, eg a service. 6. Unknown reasons. Note: it is much slower. To delete multiple, use .
member.remarks:
If directory, also deletes all its files and subdirectories. If fails to delete some, tries to delete as many as possible. Deletes read-only files too. Does not show any message boxes etc (confirmation, error, UAC consent, progress).
Some reasons why this function can fail: 1. The file is open (in any process). Or a file in the directory is open. 2. This process does not have security permissions to access or delete the file or directory or some of its descendants. 3. The directory is (or contains) the "current directory" (in any process).

member.returns: Returns the return value of the lambda f.

example.code:
File.WriteAllText(file, "TEXT"); //unsafe. Exception if the file is locked.
AFile.WaitIfLocked(() => File.WriteAllText(file, "TEXT")); //safe. Waits while the file is locked.

member.name: M:Au.AFile.Save(System.String,System.Action{System.String},System.Boolean,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes any data to a file in a safe way, using a callback function.
member.param: File. Must be full path. Can contain environment variables etc, see . The file can exist or not; this function overwrites it. If the directory does not exist, this function creates it.

Callback function (lambda etc) that creates/writes/closes a temporary file. Its parameter is the full path of the temporary file, which normally does not exist. May be called multiple times, because this function retries if the file is locked or if the directory does not exist (if writer throws DirectoryNotFoundException exception).
Create backup file named file + "~backup".

Directory for backup file and temporary file. If null or "" - file's directory. Can contain environment variales etc. Must be in the same drive as file. If the directory does not exist, this function creates it.
If cannot open file because it is open by another process etc, wait max this number of milliseconds. Can be (-1).
member.exception: Failed to replace file. The writer function also can thow it.
member.remarks:
The file-write functions provided by .NET and Windows API are less reliable, because: 1. Fails if the file is temporarily open by another process or thread without sharing. 2. Can corrupt file data. If this thread, process, PC or disk dies while writing, may write only part of data or just make empty file. Usually it happens when PC is turned off incorrectly.
To protect from 1, this functions waits/retries if the file is temporarily open/locked, like . To protect from 2, this function writes to a temporary file and renames/replaces the specified file using API ReplaceFile. Although not completely atomic, it ensures that file data is not corrupt; if cannot write all data, does not change existing file data. Also this function auto-creates directory if does not exist.
This function is slower. Speed can be important when saving many files.

member.name: M:Au.AFile.More.LoadDll64or32Bit(System.String)
member.summary: Loads an unmanaged dll from subfolder "64" or "32" depending on whether this process is 64-bit or 32-bit.
member.param: Dll file name like "name.dll".
member.remarks:
If your program uses an unmanaged dll and can run as either 64-bit or 32-bit process, you need 2 versions of the dll - 64-bit and 32-bit. Let they live in subfolders "64" and "32" of your program folder. They must have same name. This function loads correct dll version. Then [DllImport("dll")] will use the loaded dll. Don't need two different DllImport for functions ([DllImport("dll64")] and [DllImport("dll32")]).
If the dll does not exist in these folders, this function also looks in: - subfolder "64" or "32" of folder specified in environment variable "Au.Path". For example the dll is unavailable if used in an assembly (managed dll) loaded in a nonstandard environment, eg VS forms designer or VS C# Interactive (then AFolders.ThisApp is "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\..."). Workaround: set %Au.Path% = the main Au directory and restart Windows. - subfolder "64" or "32" of . For example the dll may be extracted there from resources.

member.name: M:Au.AFile.Run(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.RFlags,Au.Types.ROptions)
member.summary: Runs/opens a program, document, directory (folder), URL, new email, Control Panel item etc. The returned variable contains some process info - process id etc.
member.param: Examples: - @"C:\file.txt" - AFolders.Documents - AFolders.System + "notepad.exe" - @"%AFolders.System%\notepad.exe" - @"%TMP%\file.txt" - "notepad.exe" - @"..\folder\x.exe" - "http://a.b.c/d" - "file:///path" - "mailto:a@b.c" - ":: ITEMIDLIST" - @"::{CLSID}" - @"shell:AppsFolder\Microsoft.WindowsCalculator_8wekyb3d8bbwe!App".
Command line arguments. This function expands environment variables if starts with "%" or "\"%".
Allows to specify more parameters: current directory, verb, etc. If string, it sets initial current directory for the new process. If "", gets it from file. More info: .
member.exception: Failed. For example, the file does not exist.
member.remarks:
It works like when you double-click a file icon. It may start new process or not. For example it may just activate window if the program is already running. Uses API ShellExecuteEx. Similar to .
The file parameter can be: - Full path of a file or directory. Examples: @"C:\file.txt", AFolders.Documents, AFolders.System + "notepad.exe", @"%AFolders.System%\notepad.exe". - Filename of a file or directory, like "notepad.exe". The function calls . - Path relative to . Examples: "x.exe", @"subfolder\x.exe", @".\subfolder\x.exe", @"..\another folder\x.exe". - URL. Examples: "http://a.b.c/d", "file:///path". - Email, like "mailto:a@b.c". Subject, body etc also can be specified, and Google knows how. - Shell object's ITEMIDLIST like ":: ITEMIDLIST". See , . Can be used to open virtual folders and items like Control Panel. - Shell object's parsing name, like @"::{CLSID}". See , . Can be used to open virtual folders and items like Control Panel. - To run a Windows Store App, use @"shell:AppsFolder\WinStoreAppId" format. Examples: @"shell:AppsFolder\Microsoft.WindowsCalculator_8wekyb3d8bbwe!App", @"shell:AppsFolder\windows.immersivecontrolpanel_cw5n1h2txyewy!microsoft.windows.immersivecontrolpanel". To discover the string use or Google.
Supports environment variables, like @"%TMP%\file.txt". See .

member.summary: Calls and handles exceptions. All parameters are the same. If Run throws exception, writes it to the output as warning and returns null.
member.remarks: This is useful when you don't care whether Run succeeded and don't want to use try/catch. Handles only exception of type AuException. It is thrown when fails, usually when the file does not exist.

member.summary: Runs a console program, waits until its process ends, and gets its output text. This overload writes text lines to the output in real time.
member.param:
Path or name of an .exe or .bat file. Can be: - Full path. Examples: @"C:\folder\x.exe", AFolders.System + "x.exe", @"%AFolders.System%\x.exe". - Filename, like "x.exe". This function calls . - Path relative to . Examples: "x.exe", @"subfolder\x.exe", @".\subfolder\x.exe", @"..\folder\x.exe".
Supports environment variables, like @"%TMP%\x.bat". See .
null or command line arguments.
Initial current directory of the new process. - If null, uses Directory.GetCurrentDirectory(). - Else if "", calls APath.GetDirectory(exe). - Else calls .
Console's text encoding. If null (default), uses the default console text encoding (API GetOEMCP); it is not Unicode. Programs that display Unicode text use .
member.returns: The process exit code. Usually a non-0 value means error.
member.exception: Failed, for example file not found.
member.remarks:
The console window is hidden. The text that would be displayed in it is redirected to this function.
Console programs have two output text streams - standard output and standard error. This function gets both. Alternatively use . It gets the output and error streams separately, and some lines may be received in incorrect order in time.

member.summary: Opens parent folder in Explorer and selects the specified file. Returns null if fails, for example if the file does not exist.

member.name: T:Au.AFolders
member.summary: Gets known/special folder paths (Desktop, Temp, etc).
member.remarks:
Most functions return , not string. It is implicitly convertible to string. Its operator + appends a filename or relative path string, with \ separator if need. Example: string s = AFolders.Desktop + "file.txt"; //C:\Users\Name\Desktop\file.txt If a function cannot get folder path, the return value contains null string. Then the + operator would throw .
Some folders are known only on newer Windows versions or only on some computers. Some functions have a suffix like _Win8 which means that the folder is unavailable on older Windows. Some known folders, although supported and registerd, may be still not created.
Some folders are virtual, for example Control Panel. They don't have a file system path, but can be identified by a data structure called "ITEMIDLIST" or "PIDL". Functions of the nested class return it as . Functions of the nested class return it as string ":: ITEMIDLIST" that can be used with some functions of this library (of classes AFile, APidl, AIcon) but not with .NET or native functions.
Most functions use Windows "Known Folders" API, such as SHGetKnownFolderPath. The list of Windows predefined known folders: KNOWNFOLDERID. Names of folders specific to current process have prefix This, like ThisApp.
Some paths depend on the bitness (32 or 64 bit) of the OS and this process.
32-bit Windows
System, SystemX86, SystemX64: @"C:\WINDOWS\system32"
ProgramFiles, ProgramFilesX86, ProgramFilesX64: @"C:\Program Files"
ProgramFilesCommon, ProgramFilesCommonX86, ProgramFilesCommonX64: @"C:\Program Files\Common Files"
64-bit Windows, 64-bit process
System, SystemX64: @"C:\WINDOWS\system32"
SystemX86: @"C:\WINDOWS\SysWOW64"
ProgramFiles, ProgramFilesX64: @"C:\Program Files"
ProgramFilesX86: @"C:\Program Files (x86)"
ProgramFilesCommon, ProgramFilesCommonX64: @"C:\Program Files\Common Files"
ProgramFilesCommonX86: @"C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files"
64-bit Windows, 32-bit process
System: @"C:\WINDOWS\system32". However the OS in most cases redirects this path to @"C:\WINDOWS\SysWOW64".
SystemX86: @"C:\WINDOWS\SysWOW64"
SystemX64: @"C:\WINDOWS\Sysnative". The OS redirects it to the true @"C:\WINDOWS\system32". It is a special path that you don't see in Explorer.
ProgramFiles, ProgramFilesX86: @"C:\Program Files (x86)"
ProgramFilesX64: @"C:\Program Files"
ProgramFilesCommon, ProgramFilesCommonX86: @"C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files"
ProgramFilesCommonX64: @"C:\Program Files\Common Files"

member.name: P:Au.AFolders.SystemX64

member.summary: Gets icons of files etc as Bitmap. Uses 2-level cache - memory and file.

member.summary: Saves to the cache file now, if need. Automatically called on process exit.
