member.summary: Clears the memory cache and deletes the cache file.

member.name: M:Au.AIconCache.GetImage(System.String,System.Boolean,Au.Types.IconGetFlags,System.Action{System.Drawing.Bitmap,System.Object},System.Object)
member.summary: Gets file icon as Bitmap. Returns null if the icon is not cached and failed to get it, eg file does not exist.
member.param: Any file or folder.

Get file type icon, depending on filename extension. Use this to avoid getting separate image object for each file of same type. This is ignored if filename extension is ".ico" or ".exe" or starts with ".exe," or ".dll,".
Flags for .

If not null, the cached image will be auto-updated when changed. Then will be called this function. It can update the image in UI. How it works: If this function finds cached image, it sets timer that after ~50 ms loads that icon/image from file again and compares with the cached image. If different, updates the cache. Does it once, not periodically. Use only in UI threads. Does not work if this thread does not retrieve/dispatch posted messages.
Something to pass to the autoUpdate callback function.
member.remarks: If the icon is in the memory cache, gets it from there. Else if it is in the file cache, gets it from there and adds to the memory cache. Else gets from file (uses and adds to the file cache and to the memory cache.

member.name: M:Au.AIconCache.GetImage(System.String,System.Func{System.Drawing.Bitmap},System.Action{System.Drawing.Bitmap,System.Object},System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets any icon or image using callback function. Returns null if the icon is not cached and the callback function returns null.
member.param: Some unique name. It is used to identify this image in cache.
Called to get image. To convert icon handle to image, use .
If true (default), auto-updating can dispose unused image returned by callback.
member.remarks: If the icon is in the memory cache, gets it from there. Else if it is in the file cache, gets it from there and adds to the memory cache. Else calls callback function, which should return image, and adds to the file cache and to the memory cache.

member.name: T:Au.APath
member.summary: Extends .

member.name: M:Au.APath.ExpandEnvVar(System.String)
member.summary: If path starts with "%" or "\"%", expands environment variables enclosed in %, else just returns path. Also supports known folder names, like "%AFolders.Documents%". More info in Remarks.
member.param: Any string. Can be null.
member.remarks:
Supports known folder names. See . Example: @"%AFolders.Documents%\file.txt". Example: @"%AFolders.Virtual.ControlPanel%" //gets ":: ITEMIDLIST". Usually known folders are used like string path = AFolders.Documents + "file.txt". However it cannot be used when you want to store paths in text files, registry, etc. Then this feature is useful. To get known folder path, this function calls .
This function is called by many functions of classes APath, AFile, AIcon, some others, therefore all they support environment variables and known folders in path string.

member.name: M:Au.APath.GetEnvVar_(System.String)
member.summary: Gets environment variable's value. Returns "" if variable not found. Does not support AFolders.X.
member.param: Case-insensitive name. Without %.
member.remarks: Environment variable values cannot be "" or null. Setting empty value removes the variable.

member.name: M:Au.APath.EnvVarExists_(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if environment variable exists.
member.param: Case-insensitive name.

member.name: M:Au.APath.IsFullPath(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the string is full path, like @"C:\a\b.txt" or @"C:" or @"\\server\share\...":
member.param: Any string. Can be null.
member.remarks:
Returns true if path matches one of these wildcard patterns: - @"?:\*" - local path, like @"C:\a\b.txt". Here ? is A-Z, a-z. - @"?:" - drive name, like @"C:". Here ? is A-Z, a-z. - @"\\*" - network path, like @"\\server\share\...". Or has prefix @"\\?\".
Supports '/' characters too.
Supports only file-system paths. Returns false if path is URL () or starts with "::".
If path starts with "%environmentVariable%", shows warning and returns false. You should at first expand environment variables with or instead use .

member.name: M:Au.APath.IsFullPathExpandEnvVar(System.String@)
member.summary: Expands environment variables and calls . Returns true if the string is full path, like @"C:\a\b.txt" or @"C:" or @"\\server\share\...":
member.param: Any string. Can be null. If starts with '%' character, calls with expanded environment variables (). If it returns true, replaces the passed variable with the expanded path string.
member.remarks: Returns true if path matches one of these wildcard patterns: - @"?:\*" - local path, like @"C:\a\b.txt". Here ? is A-Z, a-z. - @"?:" - drive name, like @"C:". Here ? is A-Z, a-z. - @"\\*" - network path, like @"\\server\share\...". Or has prefix @"\\?\". Supports '/' characters too. Supports only file-system paths. Returns false if path is URL () or starts with "::".

member.name: M:Au.APath.GetRootLength(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the length of the drive or network folder part in path, including its separator if any. If the string does not start with a drive or network folder path, returns 0 or prefix length (@"\\?\" or @"\\?\UNC\").
member.param: Full path or any string. Can be null. Should not be @"%environmentVariable%\...".
member.remarks: Supports prefixes @"\\?\" and @"\\?\UNC\". Supports separators '\\' and '/'.

member.name: M:Au.APath.GetUrlProtocolLength(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the length of the URL protocol name (also known as URI scheme) in string, including ':'. If the string does not start with a protocol name, returns 0.
member.param: A URL or path or any string. Can be null.
member.remarks:
URL examples: "http:" (returns 5), "http://www.x.com" (returns 5), "file:///path" (returns 5), "shell:etc" (returns 6).
The protocol can be unknown. The function just checks string format, which is an ASCII alpha character followed by one or more ASCII alpha-numeric, '.', '-', '+' characters, followed by ':' character.

member.name: M:Au.APath.IsUrl(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the string starts with a URL protocol name (existing or not) and ':' character. Calls and returns true if it's not 0.
member.param: A URL or path or any string. Can be null.
member.remarks: URL examples: "http:", "http://www.x.com", "file:///path", "shell:etc".

member.name: M:Au.APath.Combine(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Combines two path parts using character '\\'. For example directory path and file name.
member.param: First part. Usually a directory.
Second part. Usually a filename or relative path.
s2 can be full path. If it is, ignore s1 and return s2 with expanded environment variables. If false (default), simply combines s1 and s2.
Call which may prepend @"\\?\" if the result path is very long. Default true.
member.remarks: If s1 and s2 are null or "", returns "". Else if s1 is null or "", returns s2. Else if s2 is null or "", returns s1. Does not expand environment variables. For it use before, or instead. Path that starts with an environment variable here is considerd not full path. Similar to . Main differences: has some options; supports null arguments.

member.name: M:Au.APath.Combine_(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Combines two path parts. Unlike , fails if some part is empty or @"\" or if s2 is @"\\". Also does not check s2 full path. If fails, throws exception or returns null (if noException).

member.name: M:Au.APath.IsSepChar_(System.Char)
member.summary: Returns true if character c == '\\' || c == '/'.

member.name: M:Au.APath._EndsWithDriveWithoutSep(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true if ends with ':' preceded by a drive letter, like "C:" or "more\C:", but not like "moreC:".
member.param: Can be null.
Use when want to check drive at a middle, not at the end. Eg returns true if s is @"C:\more" and length is 2.

member.name: M:Au.APath._AddRemoveSep(System.String)
member.summary: Ensures that s either ends with a valid drive path (eg @"C:\" but not "C:") or does not end with '\\' or '/' (unless would become empty if removed).
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.APath.Normalize(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.PNFlags)
member.summary: Makes normal full path from path that can contain special substrings etc.
member.param: Any path.
If path is not full path, combine it with defaultParentDirectory to make full path.
member.exception: path is not full path, and defaultParentDirectory is not used or does not make it full path.
member.remarks:
The sequence of actions: 1. If path starts with '%' character, expands environment variables and special folder names. See . 2. If path is not full path but looks like URL, and used flag CanBeUrl, returns path. 3. If path is not full path, and defaultParentDirectory is not null/"", combines path with ExpandEnvVar(defaultParentDirectory). 4. If path is not full path, throws exception. 5. Calls API GetFullPathName. It replaces '/' with '\\', replaces multiple '\\' with single (where need), processes @"\.." etc, trims spaces, etc. 6. If no flag DontExpandDosPath, if path looks like a short DOS path version (contains '~' etc), calls API GetLongPathName. It converts short DOS path to normal path, if possible, for example @"c:\progra~1" to @"c:\program files". It is slow. It converts path only if the file exists. 7. If no flag DontRemoveEndSeparator, removes '\\' character at the end, unless it is like @"C:\". 8. Appends '\\' character if ends with a drive name (eg "C:" -> @"C:\"). 9. If no flag DontPrefixLongPath, calls , which adds @"\\?\" etc prefix if path is very long.
Similar to . Main differences: this function expands environment variables, does not support relative paths, trims '\\' at the end if need.

member.name: M:Au.APath.Normalize_(System.String,Au.Types.PNFlags,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Same as , but skips full-path checking. s should be full path. If not full and not null/"", combines with current directory.

member.name: M:Au.APath.NormalizeMinimally_(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Prepares path for passing to API that support "..", DOS path etc. Calls ExpandEnvVar, _AddRemoveSep, PrefixLongPathIfNeed. Optionally throws if !IsFullPath(path).
member.exception: Not full path (only if throwIfNotFullPath is true).

member.name: M:Au.APath.NormalizeForNET_(System.String)
member.summary: Prepares path for passing to .NET file functions. Calls ExpandEnvVar, _AddRemoveSep. Throws if !IsFullPath(path).

member.name: M:Au.APath.ExpandDosPath_(System.String)
member.summary: Calls API GetLongPathName. Does not check whether s contains '~' character etc. Note: the API is slow.
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.APath.IsPossiblyDos_(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if pathOrFilename looks like a DOS filename or path. Examples: "abcde~12", "abcde~12.txt", @"c:\path\abcde~12.txt", "c:\abcde~12\path".
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.APath.IsShellPath_(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if starts with "::".
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.APath.PrefixLongPath(System.String)
member.summary: If path is full path (see ) and does not start with @"\\?\", prepends @"\\?\". If path is network path (like @"\\computer\folder\..."), makes like @"\\?\UNC\computer\folder\...".
member.param: Path. Can be null. Must not start with "%environmentVariable%". This function does not expand it. See .
member.remarks: Windows API kernel functions support extended-length paths, ie longer than 259 characters. But the path must have this prefix. Windows API shell functions don't support it.

member.name: M:Au.APath.PrefixLongPathIfNeed(System.String)
member.summary: Calls if path is longer than (247).
member.param: Path. Can be null. Must not start with "%environmentVariable%". This function does not expand it. See .

member.name: M:Au.APath.UnprefixLongPath(System.String)
member.summary: If path starts with @"\\?\" prefix, removes it. If path starts with @"\\?\UNC\" prefix, removes @"?\UNC\".
member.param: Path. Can be null. Must not start with "%environmentVariable%". This function does not expand it. See .

member.name: M:Au.APath._GetPrefixLength(System.String)
member.summary: If s starts with @"\\?\UNC\", returns 8. Else if starts with @"\\?\", returns 4. Else returns 0.
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: F:Au.APath.MaxFilePathLength
member.summary: Maximal file (not directory) path length supported by all functions (native, .NET and this library). For longer paths need @"\\?\" prefix. It is supported by: most native kernel API (but not shell API), most functions of this library, some .NET functions.

member.name: F:Au.APath.MaxDirectoryPathLength
member.summary: Maximal directory path length supported by all functions (native, .NET and this library). For longer paths need @"\\?\" prefix. It is supported by: most native kernel API (but not shell API), most functions of this library, some .NET functions.

member.name: M:Au.APath.CorrectName(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Replaces characters that cannot be used in file names.
member.param: Initial filename.
A string that will replace each invalid character. Default "-".
member.remarks: Also corrects other forms of invalid or problematic filename: trims spaces and other blank characters; replaces "." at the end; prepends "@" if a reserved name like "CON" or "CON.txt"; returns "-" if name is null/empty/whitespace. Usually returns valid filename, however it can be too long (itself or when combined with a directory path).

member.name: M:Au.APath.IsInvalidName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if name cannot be used for a file name, eg contains '\\' etc characters or is empty. More info: .
member.param: Any string. Example: "name.txt". Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.APath.GetName(System.String)
member.summary: Gets filename from path. Does not remove extension. Returns "" if there is no filename. Returns null if path is null.
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
member.remarks:
Similar to . Some differences: if ends with '\\' or '/', gets part before it, eg "B" from @"C:\A\B\".
Supports separators '\\' and '/'. Also supports URL and shell parsing names like @"::{CLSID-1}\0\::{CLSID-2}".
Examples:
| path | result | - | - | @"C:\A\B\file.txt" | "file.txt" | "file.txt" | "file.txt" | "file" | "file" | @"C:\A\B" | "B" | @"C:\A\B\" | "B" | @"C:\A\/B\/" | "B" | @"C:\" | "" | @"C:" | "" | @"\\network\share" | "share" | @"C:\aa\file.txt:alt.stream" | "file.txt:alt.stream" | "http://a.b.c" | "a.b.c" | "::{A}\::{B}" | "::{B}" | "" | "" | null | null

member.name: M:Au.APath.GetNameNoExt(System.String)
member.summary: Gets filename without extension. Returns "" if there is no filename. Returns null if path is null.
member.param: Path or filename (then just removes extension). Can be null.
member.remarks:
The same as , just removes extension. Similar to . Some differences: if ends with '\\' or '/', gets part before it, eg "B" from @"C:\A\B\".
Supports separators '\\' and '/'. Also supports URL and shell parsing names like @"::{CLSID-1}\0\::{CLSID-2}".
Examples:
| path | result | - | - | @"C:\A\B\file.txt" | "file" | "file.txt" | "file" | "file" | "file" | @"C:\A\B" | "B" | @"C:\A\B\" | "B" | @"C:\A\B.B\" | "B.B" | @"C:\aa\file.txt:alt.stream" | "file.txt:alt" | "http://a.b.c" | "a.b"

member.name: M:Au.APath.GetExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Gets filename extension, like ".txt". Returns "" if there is no extension. Returns null if path is null.
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
member.remarks: Supports separators '\\' and '/'.

member.name: M:Au.APath.GetExtension(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets filename extension and path part without the extension. More info: .
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
Receives path part without the extension. Can be the same variable as path.

member.name: M:Au.APath.FindExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Finds filename extension, like ".txt". Returns '.' character index, or -1 if there is no extension.
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
member.remarks: Returns -1 if '.' is before '\\' or '/'.

member.name: M:Au.APath.GetDirectory(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Removes filename part from path. By default also removes separator ('\\' or '/') if it is not after drive name (eg "C:"). Returns "" if the string is a filename. Returns null if the string is null or a root (like @"C:\" or "C:" or @"\\server\share" or "http:").
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
Don't remove separator character(s) ('\\' or '/'). See examples.
member.remarks:
Similar to . Some differences: skips '\\' or '/' at the end (eg from @"C:\A\B\" gets @"C:\A", not @"C:\A\B"); does not replace / with \.
Parses raw string. You may want to it at first.
Supports separators '\\' and '/'. Also supports URL and shell parsing names like @"::{CLSID-1}\0\::{CLSID-2}".
Examples:
| path | result | - | - | @"C:\A\B\file.txt" | @"C:\A\B" | "file.txt" | "" | @"C:\A\B\" | @"C:\A" | @"C:\A\/B\/" | @"C:\A" | @"C:\" | null | @"\\network\share" | null | "http:" | null | @"C:\aa\file.txt:alt.stream" | "C:\aa" | "http://a.b.c" | "http:" | "::{A}\::{B}" | "::{A}" | "" | "" | null | null
Examples when withSeparator true:
| path | result | - | - | @"C:\A\B" | @"C:\A\" (not @"C:\A") | "http://x.y" | "http://" (not "http:")

member.name: M:Au.APath.IsExtension_(System.String)

member.name: M:Au.APath.MakeUnique(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets path with unique filename for a new file or directory. If the specified path is of an existing file or directory, returns path where the filename part is modified like "file 2.txt", "file 3.txt" etc. Else returns unchanged path.
member.param: Suggested full path.
The path is for a directory. The number is always appended at the very end, not before .extension.

member.name: T:Au.APidl
member.summary: Manages an ITEMIDLIST structure that is used to identify files and other shell objects instead of a file-system path.
member.remarks:
Wraps an ITEMIDLIST*, also known as PIDL or LPITEMIDLIST.
When calling native shell API, virtual objects can be identified only by ITEMIDLIST*. Some API also support "parsing name", which may look like "::{CLSID-1}\::{CLSID-2}". File-system objects can be identified by path as well as by ITEMIDLIST*. URLs can be identified by URL as well as by ITEMIDLIST*.
The ITEMIDLIST structure is in unmanaged memory. You can dispose APidl variables, or GC will do it later.
This class has only ITEMIDLIST functions that are used in this library. Look for other functions in the MSDN library. Many of them are named with IL prefix, like ILClone, ILGetSize, ILFindLastID.

member.name: P:Au.APidl.UnsafePtr
member.summary: Gets the ITEMIDLIST* (PIDL).
member.remarks: The ITEMIDLIST memory is managed by this variable and will be freed when disposing or GC-collecting it. Use where need.

member.name: P:Au.APidl.HandleRef
member.summary: Gets the ITEMIDLIST* (PIDL).
member.remarks: Use to pass to API where the parameter type is HandleRef. It is safer than because ensures that this variable will not be GC-collected during API call even if not referenced after the call.

member.name: P:Au.APidl.IsNull
member.summary: Returns true if the PIDL is null.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.#ctor(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Assigns an ITEMIDLIST to this variable.
member.param: ITEMIDLIST* (PIDL). It can be created by any API that creates ITEMIDLIST. They allocate the memory with API CoTaskMemAlloc. This variable will finally free it with Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem which calls API CoTaskMemFree.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.#ctor(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Combines two ITEMIDLIST (parent and child) and assigns the result to this variable.
member.param: Absolute PIDL (parent folder).
Relative PIDL (child object).
member.remarks: Does not free pidlAbsolute and pidlRelative.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.Dispose
member.summary: Frees the ITEMIDLIST with Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem and clears this variable.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.Detach
member.summary: Gets the ITEMIDLIST and clears this variable so that it cannot be used and will not free the ITEMIDLIST memory. To free it use Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.FromString(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts string to ITEMIDLIST and creates new APidl variable that holds it. Returns null if failed.
member.param: A file-system path or URL or shell object parsing name (see ) or ":: ITEMIDLIST" (see ). Supports environment variables (see ).
Throw exception if failed.
member.exception: Failed, and throwIfFailed is true. Probably invalid s.
member.remarks: Calls SHParseDisplayName, except when string is ":: ITEMIDLIST". When ":: ITEMIDLIST", does not check whether the shell object exists. Note: APidl is disposable.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.FromString_(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The same as , but returns unmanaged ITEMIDLIST*. Later need to free it with Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem.

member.name: M:Au.APidl._Normalize(System.String)
member.summary: The same as (CanBeUrlOrShell|DontPrefixLongPath), but ignores non-full path (returns s).
member.param: File-system path or URL or "::...".

member.name: M:Au.APidl.ToShellString(Au.Types.Native.SIGDN,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts the ITEMIDLIST to file path or URL or shell object parsing name or display name, depending on stringType argument. Returns null if this variable does not have an ITEMIDLIST (eg disposed or detached). If failed, returns null or throws exception.
member.param: String format. API SIGDN. Often used: - Native.SIGDN.NORMALDISPLAY - returns object name without path. It is best to display in UI but cannot be parsed to create ITEMIDLIST again. - Native.SIGDN.FILESYSPATH - returns path if the ITEMIDLIST identifies a file system object (file or directory). Else returns null. - Native.SIGDN.URL - if URL, returns URL. If file system object, returns its path like "file:///C:/a/b.txt". Else returns null. - Native.SIGDN.DESKTOPABSOLUTEPARSING - returns path (if file system object) or URL (if URL) or shell object parsing name (if virtual object eg Control Panel). Note: not all returned parsing names can actually be parsed to create ITEMIDLIST again, therefore usually it's better to use instead.
If failed, throw AuException.
member.remarks: Calls SHGetNameFromIDList.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.ToShellString(System.IntPtr,Au.Types.Native.SIGDN,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This overload uses an ITEMIDLIST* that is not stored in an APidl variable.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.ToString
member.summary: Converts the ITEMIDLIST to string. If it identifies an existing file-system object (file or directory), returns path. If URL, returns URL. Else returns ":: ITEMIDLIST" (see ). Returns null if this variable does not have an ITEMIDLIST (eg disposed or detached).

member.name: M:Au.APidl.ToString(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: This overload uses an ITEMIDLIST* that is not stored in an APidl variable.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.ToBase64String
member.summary: Returns string ":: ITEMIDLIST". Returns null if this variable does not have an ITEMIDLIST (eg disposed or detached).
member.remarks: The string can be used with some functions of this library, mostly of classes AFile, APidl and AIcon. Cannot be used with native and .NET functions.

member.name: M:Au.APidl.ToBase64String(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: This overload uses an ITEMIDLIST* that is not stored in an APidl variable.

member.summary: Allocates, writes and reads memory in other process.
member.remarks: Must be disposed. Example: using(var pm=new AProcessMemory(...)) { ... }.

member.summary: Process handle. Opened with access PROCESS_VM_OPERATION | PROCESS_VM_READ | PROCESS_VM_WRITE.

member.summary: Address of memory allocated in that process.

member.name: M:Au.AProcessMemory.SetMem(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets an address of memory in that process that is to be used by the read and write functions.
member.param: A memory address in that process.

Let the Dispose method (or finalizer) call API VirtualFreeEx to free mem. The memory must be allocated with API VirtualAllocEx (by any process) or VirtualAlloc (by that process). If false, mem can be any memory in that process, and this variable will not free it. Alternatively you can use and .
member.exception: This variable already has Mem, unless it was set by this function with freeWhenDisposing = false.
member.remarks: This function can be used if this variable was created with nBytes = 0. Else exception. Also exception if this function previously called with freeWhenDisposing = true.

If not 0, allocates this number of bytes of memory in that process.

member.exception: Failed to open process handle (usually because of UAC) or allocate memory.

member.name: M:Au.AProcessMemory.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens window's process handle and optionally allocates memory in that process.

member.name: M:Au.AProcessMemory.WriteUnicodeString(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies a string from this process to the memory allocated in that process by the constructor. In that process the string is written as '\0'-terminated UTF-16 string. For it is used (s.Length+1)*2 bytes of memory in that process (+1 for the '\0', *2 because UTF-16 character size is 2 bytes). Returns false if fails.
member.param: A string in this process.
Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.

member.name: M:Au.AProcessMemory.WriteAnsiString(System.String,System.Int32,System.Text.Encoding)

member.param: A string in this process. Normal C# string (UTF-16), not ANSI.
Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.
If null, uses system's default ANSI encoding.

member.name: M:Au.AProcessMemory.ReadUnicodeString(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Copies a string from the memory in that process allocated by the constructor to this process. Returns the copied string, or null if fails. In that process the string must be in Unicode UTF-16 format (ie not ANSI).
member.param: Number of characters to copy. In both processes a character is 2 bytes.
Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.
Find true string length by searching for '\0' character in nChars range. If false, the returned string is of nChars length even if contains '\0' characters.

member.name: M:Au.AProcessMemory.ReadAnsiString(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Copies a string from the memory in that process allocated by the constructor to this process. Returns the copies string, or null if fails. In that process the string must be in ANSI format (ie not Unicode UTF-16).
member.param: Number bytes to copy. In that process a character is 1 or more bytes (depending on encoding). In this process will be 2 bytes (normal C# string).
Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.
Find true string length by searching for '\0' character in nBytes range of the ANSI string.
If null, uses system's default ANSI encoding.

member.name: T:Au.ARegistry
member.summary: Registry functions. Extends .

member.name: F:Au.ARegistry.AuKey
member.summary: Default registry key, used when the key argument is null or @"\" or starts with @"\".

member.name: M:Au.ARegistry.ParseKeyString(System.String@)
member.summary: Parses registry key string and returns hive as RegistryKey. If key starts with "HKEY_", removes hive name from it and returns that hive. For example, if key is @"HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Test", sets key=@"Software\Test" and returns HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE. Else if key is null or @"\", sets key=ARegistry.AuKey (@"Software\Au") and returns HKEY_CURRENT_USER. Else if key starts with @"\", prepends ARegistry.AuKey (@"Software\Au") and returns HKEY_CURRENT_USER. Else just returns HKEY_CURRENT_USER. Valid hive names: "HKEY_CURRENT_USER", "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE", "HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT", "HKEY_USERS", "HKEY_PERFORMANCE_DATA" or "HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG".
member.param: Registry key. Can start with a hive name.
member.exception: key starts with "HKEY_" but it is an invalid hive name.

member.name: M:Au.ARegistry.Open(System.String,Microsoft.Win32.RegistryKey)
member.summary: Opens a key for read access. Returns null if the key does not exist. Uses .
member.param: Registry key. See
If not null, the 'key' argument is a subkey of this key or hive; if the 'key' argument is null or "", the function just returns parentKeyOrHive.
member.exception: 'key' starts with "HKEY_" but it is an invalid hive name.
The user does not have the permissions required to read the registry key.

The user does not have the permissions required to create or open the registry key.
parentKeyOrHive was not opened with write access.

member.name: T:Au.ASqlite
member.summary: A SQLite database connection. Creates/opens/closes database file or in-memory database. Executes SQL, etc.
member.remarks:
This class wraps a SQLite API object sqlite3* and related sqlite3_x functions. They are documented perfectly in the SQLite website. Uses this unmanaged dll: AFolders.ThisApp + @"64\sqlite3.dll". In 32-bit process - "32" instead of "64".
To correctly close the database file, at first need to dipose all child objects, such as , then dispose the ASqlite object. To dispose a static ASlite variable, you may want to use event. Although this class has a finalizer that disposes the object (closes database), you should always dispose explicitly. Finalizers don't run on process exit.

member.name: M:Au.ASqlite.#ctor(System.String,Au.Types.SLFlags,System.String)
member.summary: Opens or creates a database file.
member.param: Database file. Can be: - Full path. Supports environment variables etc, see - ":memory:" - create a private, temporary in-memory database. - "" - create a private, temporary on-disk database. - Starts with "file:" - see sqlite3_open_v2 documentation in SQLite website.
sqlite3_open_v2 flags, documanted in SQLite website. Default: read-write, create file if does not exist (and parent directory).

SQL to execute. For example, one or more ;-separated PRAGMA statements to configure the database connection. Or even "CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS ...". This function also always executes "PRAGMA foreign_keys=ON;PRAGMA secure_delete=ON;".
member.exception: Failed to open database or execute sql.
member.remarks: Calls sqlite3_open_v2. If a variable of this class is used by multiple threads, use lock(variable) { } where need.

member.name: M:Au.ASqlite.Dispose
member.summary: Calls sqlite3_close_v2. If fails, writes warning to the output.

SQL statement.

The Get(out long, ...) overload also can be used to get ulong, 64-bit enum, maybe DateTime. The Get(out double, ...) overload also can be used to get float. Use for other value types - decimal, Guid, Rect, etc.

member.summary: Calls sqlite3_bind_null. Returns self.
member.remarks: Usually don't need to call this function. Unset parameter values are null. The Bind(string/void*/Array/List) functions set null too if the value is null.

member.name: M:Au.ASqliteStatement.BindObject(System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Used by .

member.name: M:Au.ASqliteStatement.BindAll(System.Object[])
member.summary: Binds multiple values of any supported types. Returns self.
member.param: Values that will replace ? characters in sql. Read about SQL parameters in SQLite website. Example: . Supported types: - int, uint, byte, sbyte, short, ushort - calls sqlite3_bind_int. - bool - calls sqlite3_bind_int(true?1:0). - long, ulong - calls sqlite3_bind_int64. - double, float - calls sqlite3_bind_double. - string - calls sqlite3_bind_text16. - decimal - calls sqlite3_bind_blob64. - Guid - calls sqlite3_bind_blob64. - An enum type - calls sqlite3_bind_int or sqlite3_bind_int64.
member.exception: A value is of an unsupported type.
member.remarks: For each parameter calls a sqlite3_bind_x function depending on type. Uses index 1, 2 and so on. This function is an alternative to calling BindX functions for each parameter. However it supports less types and adds boxing overhead. Does not call sqlite3_reset and sqlite3_clear_bindings. If need, call before.

member.name: T:Au.AUac
member.summary: Holds an access token (security info) of a process and provides various security info, eg [](xref:uac) integrity level.

member.name: P:Au.AUac.UnsafeTokenHandle
member.summary: The access token handle.
member.remarks: The handle is managed by this variable and will be closed when disposing or GC-collecting it. Use where need.

member.name: P:Au.AUac.Failed
member.summary: Returns true if the last called property function failed. Normally it should never fail. Only can fail (then it returns null).

member.name: P:Au.AUac.Elevation
member.summary: Gets the [](xref:uac) elevation type of the process.

member.name: P:Au.AUac.IsUIAccess
member.summary: Returns true if the process has [](xref:uac) uiAccess property. A uiAccess process can access/automate all windows of processes running in the same user session.
member.remarks: Most processes don't have this property. They cannot access/automate windows of higher integrity level (High, System, uiAccess) processes and Windows 8 store apps. For example, cannot send keys and Windows messages. Note: High IL (admin) processes also can have this property, therefore IsUIAccess is not the same as IntegrityLevel==IL.UIAccess ( returns UIAccess only for Medium+uiAccess processes; for High+uiAccess processes it returns High). Some Windows API work slightly differently with uiAccess and non-uiAccess admin processes. This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Au.AUac.IntegrityLevel
member.summary: Gets the [](xref:uac) integrity level (IL) of the process.
member.remarks: IL from lowest to highest value: Untrusted, Low, Medium, UIAccess, High, System, Protected, Unknown. The IL enum member values can be used like if(x.IntegrityLevel > IL.Medium) ... . If UAC is turned off, most non-service processes on administrator account have High IL; on non-administrator - Medium.

member.name: M:Au.AUac.OfProcess(System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens process access token and creates/returns new variable that holds it. Then you can use its properties. Returns null if failed. For example fails for services and some other processes if current process is not administrator.
member.param: Process id. If you have a window, use .
member.remarks: To get AUac of this process, use .

member.name: P:Au.AUac.OfThisProcess
member.summary: Gets variable for this process.

member.name: P:Au.AUac.IsAdmin
member.summary: Returns true if this process is running as administrator, ie if the user belongs to the local Administrators group and the process is not limited by [](xref:uac). This function for example can be used to check whether you can write to protected locations in the file system and registry.

member.name: P:Au.AUac.IsUacDisabled
member.summary: Returns true if [](xref:uac) is disabled (turned off) completely (not just disabled UAC consent screeen/dialog).

member.name: T:Au.AClipboard
member.summary: Clipboard functions: copy, paste, get and set clipboard text and other data.
member.remarks:
This class is similar to the .NET class, which uses OLE API, works only in STA threads and does not work well in automation scripts. This class uses non-OLE API and works well in automation scripts and any threads.
To set/get clipboard data of non-text formats, use class ; to paste, use it with ; to copy (get from the active app), use it with .
Don't copy/paste in windows of own thread. Call it from another thread. Example in .

member.name: M:Au.AClipboard.Clear
member.summary: Clears the clipboard.

member.name: M:Au.AClipboard._SetClipboardData_ClipboardViewerIgnore
member.summary: Calls API SetClipboardData("Clipboard Viewer Ignore"). Clipboard must be open. Then clipboard manager/viewer/etc programs that are aware of this convention don't try to get our clipboard data while we are pasting. Tested apps that support it: Ditto, Clipdiary. Other 5 tested apps don't. Windows 10 Clipboard History doesn't.

member.name: M:Au.AClipboard.Copy(System.Boolean,Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Gets the selected text from the focused app using the clipboard.
member.param: Use Ctrl+X.
Options. If null (default), uses . Uses , , . Does not use .
member.remarks: Also can get file paths, as multiline text. Sends keys Ctrl+C, waits until the focused app sets clipboard data, gets it, finally restores clipboard data. Fails (exception) if the focused app does not set clipboard text or file paths, for example if there is no selected text/files. Works with console windows too, even if they don't support Ctrl+C.

member.name: M:Au.AClipboard.CopyData(System.Action,System.Boolean,Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Gets data of any formats from the focused app using the clipboard and a callback function.
member.param: Callback function. It can get clipboard data of any formats. It can use any clipboard functions, for example the class or the .NET class. Don't call copy/paste functions.
Use Ctrl+X.
See .
member.exception: Exceptions thrown by the callback function.
member.remarks: Sends keys Ctrl+C, waits until the focused app sets clipboard data, calls callback function that gets it, finally restores clipboard data. Fails (exception) if the focused app does not set clipboard data. Works with console windows too, even if they don't support Ctrl+C.

member.name: M:Au.AClipboard.Paste(System.String,Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Pastes text into the focused app using the clipboard.
member.param: Text.
Options. If null (default), uses . Uses , , , , , .
member.remarks: Adds to the clipboard, sends keys Ctrl+V, waits until the focused app gets clipboard data, finally restores clipboard data. Fails (exception) if nothing gets clipboard data in several seconds. Works with console windows too, even if they don't support Ctrl+V. A clipboard viewer/manager program can make this function slower and less reliable, unless it supports or gets clipboard data with a delay. Possible problems with some virtual PC programs. Either pasting does not work in their windows, or they use a hidden clipboard viewer that makes this function slower and less reliable.

example.code: AClipboard.PasteText("Example\r\n");

member.name: M:Au.AClipboard.PasteData(Au.AClipboardData,Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Pastes data added to an variable into the focused app using the clipboard. More info: .
member.example: Paste data of two formats: HTML and text. AClipboard.PasteData(new AClipboardData().AddHtml("text").AddText("text"));

member.name: T:Au.AHookWin
member.summary: Wraps API SetWindowsHookEx.
member.remarks:
Hooks are used to receive notifications about various system events. Keyboard and mouse input, window messages, various window events.
Threads that use hooks must process Windows messages. For example have a window/dialog/messagebox, or use a 'wait-for' function that dispatches messages or has such option (see ).
The variable must be disposed, either explicitly (call Dispose or Unhook in the same thread) or with the 'using' pattern. Else this process may crash.
Avoid many hooks. Each low-level keyboard or mouse hook makes the computer slower, even if the hook procedure is fast. On each input event (key down, key up, mouse move, click, wheel) Windows sends a message to your thread.
To handle hook events is used a callback functions, aka hook procedure. Hook procedures of some hook types can block some events. Blocked events are not sent to apps and older hooks.
Accessible object functions may fail in hook procedures of low-level keyboard and mouse hooks. Workarounds exist.
Exists an alternative way to monitor keyboard or mouse events - raw input API. Good: less overhead; can detect from which device the input event came. Bad: cannot block events; incompatible with low-level keyboard hooks. This library does not have functions to make the API easier to use.

member.name: M:Au.AHookWin.Keyboard(System.Action{Au.Types.HookData.Keyboard},System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a low-level keyboard hook (WH_KEYBOARD_LL). See API SetWindowsHookEx.
member.returns: Returns a new object that manages the hook.
member.param: The hook procedure (function that handles hook events). Must return as soon as possible. More info: . If calls or (true), the event is not sent to apps and other hooks. Event data cannot be modified. When the hook procedure returns, the parameter variable becomes invalid and unsafe to use. If you need the data for later use, copy its properties and not whole variable.
Don't call the hook procedure for events sent by functions of this library. Default true.
Set hook now. Default true.

member.name: M:Au.AHookWin.Mouse(System.Action{Au.Types.HookData.Mouse},System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a low-level mouse hook (WH_MOUSE_LL). See API SetWindowsHookEx.
member.returns: Returns a new object that manages the hook.
member.param: The hook procedure (function that handles hook events). Must return as soon as possible. More info: . If calls or (true), the event is not sent to apps and other hooks. Event data cannot be modified. When the hook procedure returns, the parameter variable becomes invalid and unsafe to use. If you need the data for later use, copy its properties and not whole variable.
Don't call the hook procedure for events sent by functions of this library. Default true.
Set hook now. Default true.

member.name: M:Au.AHookWin.ThreadCbt(System.Func{Au.Types.HookData.ThreadCbt,System.Boolean},System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a WH_CBT hook for a thread of this process. See API SetWindowsHookEx.
member.returns: Returns a new object that manages the hook.
member.param: Hook procedure (function that handles hook events). Must return as soon as possible. If returns true, the event is cancelled. For some events you can modify some fields of event data. When the hook procedure returns, the parameter variable becomes invalid and unsafe to use. If you need the data for later use, copy its properties and not the variable.
Native thread id, or 0 for this thread. The thread must belong to this process.
Set hook now. Default true.

member.name: M:Au.AHookWin.ThreadGetMessage(System.Action{Au.Types.HookData.ThreadGetMessage},System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a WH_GETMESSAGE hook for a thread of this process. See API SetWindowsHookEx.
member.returns: Returns a new object that manages the hook.
member.param: The hook procedure (function that handles hook events). Must return as soon as possible. The event cannot be cancelled. As a workaround, you can set msg->message=0. Also can modify other fields. When the hook procedure returns, the pointer field of the parameter variable becomes invalid and unsafe to use.
Native thread id, or 0 for this thread. The thread must belong to this process.
Set hook now. Default true.

member.summary: Sets a WH_GETMESSAGE hook for a thread of this process. See API SetWindowsHookEx.
member.returns: Returns a new object that manages the hook.
member.param: The hook procedure (function that handles hook events). Must return as soon as possible. If returns true, the event is cancelled.
Native thread id, or 0 for this thread. The thread must belong to this process.

member.name: P:Au.AHookWin.LowLevelHooksTimeout
member.summary: Gets the max time in milliseconds allowed by Windows for low-level keyboard and mouse hook procedures.
member.remarks:
Gets registry value HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Control Panel\Desktop:LowLevelHooksTimeout. If it is missing, returns 300; it is the default value used by Windows. If greater than 1000, returns 1000, because Windows 10 ignores bigger values.
If a hook procedure takes more time, Windows does not wait. Then its return value is ignored, and the event is passed to other apps, hooks, etc. After several such cases Windows may fully or partially disable the hook. This class detects such cases; then restores the hook and writes a warning to the output. If the warning is rare, you can ignore it. If frequent, it means your hook procedure is too slow.
Callback functions of keyboard and mouse triggers are called in a hook procedure, therefore must be as fast as possible. More info: .
More info: registry LowLevelHooksTimeout.
Note: After changing the timeout in registry, it is not applied immediately. Need to log off/on.

member.name: M:Au.AHookWin.IgnoreModInOtherHooks_(System.Int64)
member.summary: Let other hooks (in all processes) ignore modifier keys for timeMS milliseconds. If 0 - restore. Used by mouse triggers. Returns the timeout time (ATime.WinMilliseconds + timeMS) or 0.

member.name: M:Au.AHookWin.IgnoreLShiftCaps_(System.Int64)
member.summary: Let all hooks (in all processes) ignore LShift and CapsLock for timeMS milliseconds. If 0 - restore. Returns the timeout time (ATime.WinMilliseconds + timeMS) or 0. Used when turning off CapsLock with Shift.

member.name: T:Au.AInputBlocker
member.summary: Blocks keyboard and/or mouse input events from reaching applications.
member.remarks:
Uses keyboard and/or mouse hooks. Does not use API BlockInput, it does not work on current Windows versions. Blocks hardware-generated events and software-generated events, except generated by functions of this library. Functions of this library that send keys or text use this class internally, to block user-pressed keys and resend them afterwards (see ). Does not block: - In windows of the same thread that started blocking. For example, if your script shows a message box, the user can click its buttons. - In windows of higher [](xref:uac) integrity level (IL) processes, unless this process has uiAccess IL. - In special desktops/screens, such as when you press Ctrl+Alt+Delete or launch an admin program that requires UAC elevation. See also . - Some Windows hotkeys, such as Ctrl+Alt+Delete and Win+L. - Keyboard hooks don't work in windows of this process if this process uses direct input or raw input API.
To stop blocking, can be used the 'using' pattern, like in the example. Or the 'try/finally' pattern, where the finally block calls or . Also automatically stops when this thread ends. Users can stop with Ctrl+Alt+Delete.

member.remarks: Will not play back if: 1. The blocking time is > 10 seconds; then plays back only key-up events. 2. Detected Ctrl+Alt+Delete, [](xref:uac) consent or some other special screen. 3. Called .

member.remarks: The 'set' function is much faster than /. Does not remove hooks etc. Discards blocked keys.

member.name: T:Au.AKeys
member.summary: Keyboard functions: send virtual keystrokes and text to the active window, get key states.
member.remarks: The main function is . Most documentation is there. See also . These functions use . Alternatively can be used AKeys variables, see .

example.code:
AKeys.Key("Ctrl+Shift+Left"); //press Ctrl+Shift+Left
AOpt.Key.KeySpeed = 300; //set options for static functions AKeys.Key("Ctrl+A Del Tab*3", (KText)"text", "Enter", 500); //press Ctrl+A, Del, Tab 3 times, send text, Enter, wait 500 ms
AKeys.Text("text\r\n"); //send text that ends with newline

member.name: T:Au.AKeys.UI
member.summary: Gets key states for using in UI code (forms, WPF).
member.remarks:
Use functions of this class when processing user input events in user interface code (forms, WPF). In other code (automation scrits, etc) usually it's better to use functions of class. Functions of this class are similar to .NET's Control.ModifierKeys, Keyboard.Modifiers etc, but may be easier to use.
In Windows there are two API to get key state (down or up) - GetKeyState and GetAsyncKeyState. In most cases they return the same result, but not always.
API GetAsyncKeyState is used by class and not by this class (AKeys.UI). When the user (or some software) presses or releases a key, GetAsyncKeyState sees the change immediately. It is good in automation scripts, but not good in UI code because the state is not synchronized with the message queue.
This class (AKeys.UI) uses API GetKeyState. In the foreground thread (of the active window), it sees key state changes not immediately but after the thread reads key messages from its queue. It is good in UI threads. In background threads this API usually works like GetAsyncKeyState, but it depends on API AttachThreadInput and in some cases is less reliable, for example may be unaware of keys pressed before the thread started.
The key state returned by these API is not always the same as of the physical keyboard. There is no API to get physical state. The two most common cases when it is different: 1. When the key is pressed or released by software, such as the function of this library. 2. When the key is blocked by a low-level hook. For example, hotkey triggers of this library use hooks.
Also there is API GetKeyboardState. It gets states of all keys in single call. Works like GetKeyState.

member.name: M:Au.AKeys.UI.GetKeyState(Au.Types.KKey)
member.summary: Calls API GetKeyState and returns its return value.
member.remarks: If returns < 0, the key is down (pressed). If the low-order bit is 1, the key is toggled; it works only with CapsLock, NumLock, ScrollLock and several other keys, as well as mouse buttons. Can be used for mouse buttons too, for example AKeys.UI.GetKeyState(KKey.MouseLeft). When mouse left and right buttons are swapped, gets logical state, not physical.

member.name: M:Au.AKeys.UI.IsPressed(Au.Types.KKey)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified key or mouse button is down (pressed).
member.remarks: Can be used for mouse buttons too, for example AKeys.UI.IsPressed(KKey.MouseLeft). When mouse left and right buttons are swapped, gets logical state, not physical.

member.name: M:Au.AKeys.UI.IsToggled(Au.Types.KKey)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified key or mouse button is toggled.
member.remarks: Works only with CapsLock, NumLock, ScrollLock and several other keys, as well as mouse buttons.

member.name: M:Au.AKeys.WaitForKey(System.Double,Au.Types.KKey,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for key-down or key-up event of the specified key.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
Wait for this key.
Wait for key-up event.
Make the event invisible for other apps. If up is true, makes the down event invisible too, if it comes while waiting for the up event.
member.remarks: Unlike , waits for key event, not for key state. Uses low-level keyboard hook. Can wait for any single key. See also . Ignores key events injected by functions of this library.

example.code: AKeys.WaitForKey(0, KKey.Ctrl, up: false, block: true); AOutput.Write("Ctrl");

member.name: M:Au.AKeys.WaitForKey(System.Double,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for key-down or key-up event of the specified key.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.param: Wait for this key. A single-key string like with .

example.code: AKeys.WaitForKey(0, "Ctrl", up: false, block: true); AOutput.Write("Ctrl");

member.name: M:Au.AKeys.WaitForKey(System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for key-down or key-up event of any key, and gets the key code.
member.returns: Returns the key code. On timeout returns 0 if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception. For modifier keys returns the left or right key code, for example LCtrl/RCtrl, not Ctrl.

example.code: var key = AKeys.WaitForKey(0, up: true, block: true); AOutput.Write(key);

member.name: M:Au.AKeys.Key(Au.Types.KKeysEtc[])
member.summary: Generates virtual keystrokes (keys, text).
member.param:
Arguments of these types:
string - keys. Key names separated by spaces or operators, like "Enter A Ctrl+A" .
Tip: in "" string press Ctrl+Space to open a tool window.
- literal text, like function .
Example: AKeys.Key((KText)"user", "Tab", (KText)"password", "Enter");
- a single key.
Example: AKeys.Key("Shift+", KKey.Left, "*3"); is the same as AKeys.Key("Shift+Left*3");.
int - sleep milliseconds. Max 10000.
Example: AKeys.Key("Left", 500, "Right");
- callback function.
Example: Action click = () => AMouse.Click(); AKeys.Key("Shift+", click);
(int, bool) - a single key, specified using scan code and extended-key flag.
Example: AKeys.Key((0x3B, false)); //key F1
(KKey, int, bool) - a single key, specified using and/or scan code and extended-key flag.
Example: AKeys.Key((KKey.Enter, 0, true)); //numpad Enter
member.exception: An invalid value, for example an unknown key name.
member.remarks:
Usually keys are specified in string, like in this example: AKeys.Key("A F2 Ctrl+Shift+A Enter*2"); //keys A, F2, Ctrl+Shift+A, Enter Enter
Key names:
Group Keys Info
Named keys
Modifier: Alt, Ctrl, Shift, Win, RAlt, RCtrl, RShift, RWin
Navigate: Esc, End, Home, PgDn, PgUp, Down, Left, Right, Up
Other: Back, Del, Enter, Menu, Pause, PrtSc, Space, Tab
Function: F1-F24
Lock: CapsLock, NumLock, ScrollLock, Ins
Start with an uppercase character. Only the first 3 characters are significant; others can be any ASCII letters. For example, can be "Back", "Bac", "Backspace" or "BACK", but not "back" or "Ba" or "Back5".
Alias: AltGr (RAlt), App (Menu), PageDown or PD (PgDn), PageUp or PU (PgUp), PrintScreen or PS (PrtSc), BS (Back), PB (Pause/Break), CL (CapsLock), NL (NumLock), SL (ScrollLock), HM (Home).
Text keys
Alphabetic: A-Z (or a-z)
Number: 0-9
Numeric keypad: #/ #* #- #+ #. #0-#9
Other: ` - = [ ] \ ; ' , . /
Spaces between keys are optional, except for uppercase A-Z. For example, can be "A B", "a b", "A b" or "ab", but not "AB" or "Ab".
For ` - [ ] \ ; ' , . / also can be used ~ _ { } | : " < > ?.
Other keys Names of enum members. Example: AKeys.Key("BrowserBack");
Other keys Virtual-key codes. Start with VK or Vk. Example: AKeys.Key("VK65 VK0x42");
Forbidden Fn, Ctrl+Alt+Del, Win+L, some other. Programs cannot press these keys.
Special characters
Operator: + * ( ) $
Numpad key prefix: #
Reserved: ! @ % ^ &
These characters cannot be used as keys. Use = 8 9 0 4 3 1 2 5 6 7.
Operators:
Operator Examples Description
*n "Left*3" Press key n times, like "Left Left Left".
See .
*down "Ctrl*down" Press key and don't release.
*up "Ctrl*up" Release key.
+ "Ctrl+Shift+A"
"Alt+E+P" The same as "Ctrl*down Shift*down A Shift*up Ctrl*up" and "Alt*down E*down P E*up Alt*up".
+() "Alt+(E P)" The same as "Alt*down E P Alt*up".
Inside () cannot be used + and +().
$ "$text" $ is the same as Shift+.
Operators and related keys can be in separate arguments. Examples: AKeys.Key("Shift+", KKey.A); AKeys.Key(KKey.A, "*3");.
Uses :
Option Default Changed
false. Blocks user-pressed keys. Sends them afterwards.
If the last argument is 'sleep', stops blocking before executing it; else stops blocking after executing all arguments. true. Does not block user-pressed keys.
false. If the CapsLock key is toggled, untoggles it temporarily (presses it before and after). true. Does not touch the CapsLock key.
Alphabetic keys of "keys" arguments can depend on CapsLock. Text of "text" arguments doesn't depend on CapsLock, unless is .
false. Releases modifier keys (Alt, Ctrl, Shift, Win).
Does it only at the start; later they cannot interfere, unless is true. true. Does not touch modifier keys.
0 ms. 0 - 1000. Changes the speed for "text" arguments (makes slower).
1 ms. 0 - 1000. Changes the speed for "keys" arguments (makes slower if >1).
5 ms. 0 - 1000. Changes the speed of Ctrl+V keys when text is pasted using the clipboard.
10 ms. 0 - 10000.
Tip: to sleep finally, also can be used code like this: AKeys.Key("keys", 1000);.
(send keys and Shift) or (use clipboard).
300.
This option is used for "text" arguments. If text length >= this value, uses the clipboard. >=0.
false.
This option is used for "text" arguments when using the clipboard.
true.
true. Restore clipboard data (by default only text).
This option is used for "text" arguments when using the clipboard. false. Don't restore clipboard data.
null. Callback function that can modify options depending on active window etc.
This function does not wait until the target app receives and processes sent keystrokes and text; there is no reliable way to know it. It just adds small delays depending on options ( etc). If need, change options or add 'sleep' arguments or wait after calling this function. Sending text through the clipboard normally does not have these problems.
Don't use this function to automate windows of own thread. Call it from another thread. See the last example.
Administrator and uiAccess processes don't receive keystrokes sent by standard user processes. See [](xref:uac).
Mouse button codes/names (eg ) cannot be used to click. Instead use callback, like in the "Ctrl+click" example.
When you don't want to use or modify , you can use an variable instead of this function. Example: new AKeys(null).Add("keys", (KText)"text").Send();. More examples in topic.
This function calls , which calls these functions depending on argument type: , , , , , , . Then calls .
Uses API SendInput.

Uses : , , .
May fail to move the cursor to the specified x y. Some reasons: - Another thread blocks or modifies mouse input (API BlockInput, mouse hooks, frequent API SendInput etc). - The active window belongs to a process of higher [](xref:uac) integrity level. - Some application called API ClipCursor. No exception if option Relaxed is true (then final cursor position is undefined).

member.name: M:Au.AMouse.ClickEx(Au.Types.MButton,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Clicks, double-clicks, presses or releases a mouse button. By default does not move the mouse cursor.
member.returns: The return value can be used to auto-release the pressed button. Example: .
member.param: Button and action. Default: left click.

Use . It is the mouse cursor position set by the most recent 'mouse move' or 'mouse click' function called in this thread. Use this option for reliability. Example: AMouse.Move(100, 100); AMouse.ClickEx(..., true);. The click is always at 100 100, even if somebody changes cursor position between AMouse.Move sets it and AMouse.ClickEx uses it. In such case this option atomically moves the cursor to LastXY. This movement is instant and does not use . If false (default), clicks at the current cursor position (does not move it).
member.exception: Invalid button flags (multiple buttons or actions specified).
member.remarks: Uses : , .

member.name: M:Au.AMouse.WaitForClick(System.Double,Au.Types.MButtons,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for button-down or button-up event of the specified mouse button or buttons.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
Mouse button. If several buttons specified, waits for any of them.
Wait for button-up event.
Make the event invisible for other apps. If up is true, makes the down event invisible too, if it comes while waiting for the up event.
member.remarks: Unlike , waits for down or up event, not for button state. Uses low-level mouse hook. Ignores mouse events injected by functions of this library.

example.code: AMouse.WaitForClick(0, MButtons.Left, up: true, block: false); AOutput.Write("click");

member.name: M:Au.AMouse.WaitForClick(System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for button-down or button-up event of any mouse button, and gets the button code.
member.returns: Returns the button code. On timeout returns 0 if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.

example.code: var button = AMouse.WaitForClick(0, up: true, block: true); AOutput.Write(button);

member.name: T:Au.ARegisteredHotkey
member.summary: Registers a hotkey using API RegisterHotKey. Unregisters when disposing.
member.remarks:
Can be used as a lightweight alternative to hotkey triggers.
The variable must be disposed, either explicitly (call Dispose or Unregister) or with the 'using' pattern.

member.name: M:Au.ARegisteredHotkey.Register(System.Int32,Au.Types.KHotkey,Au.Types.AnyWnd)
member.summary: Registers a hotkey using API RegisterHotKey. Returns false if fails. Supports .
member.param: Hotkey id. Must be 0 to 0xBFFF. It will be wParam of the WM_HOTKEY message.
Hotkey. Can be: string like "Ctrl+Shift+Alt+Win+K", tuple (KMod, KKey), enum KKey, enum Keys, struct KHotkey.
Window/form that will receive the WM_HOTKEY message. Must be of this thread. If default, the message must be retrieved in the message loop of this thread.
member.exception: This variable already registered a hotkey.
member.remarks: Fails if the hotkey is currently registered by this or another application or used by Windows. Also if F12. A single variable cannot register multiple hotkeys simultaneously. Use multiple variables, for example array.
member.example: See .

member.name: M:Au.ARegisteredHotkey.Unregister
member.summary: Unregisters the hotkey.
member.remarks: Called implicitly when disposing this variable. Must be called from the same thread as when registering, and the window must be still alive. If fails, calls .

member.summary: Calls .

member.name: T:Au.ADebug
member.summary: Functions useful to debug code.
member.remarks: The ADebug.PrintX functions write to the same output as , not to the trace listeners like etc do. Also they add caller's name, file and line number. Functions Print, PrintIf, PrintFunc and Dialog work only if DEBUG is defined, which normally is when the caller project is in Debug configuration. Else they are not called, and arguments not evaluated at run time. This is because they have [("DEBUG")]. Note: when used in a library, the above functions depend on DEBUG of the library project and not on DEBUG of the consumer project of the library. For example, the library may be in Release configuration even if its consumer project is in Debug configuration. If your library wants to show some info only if its consumer project is in Debug config, instead you can use code like if(AOpt.Warnings.Verbose) AWarning.Write("text");; see , AOpt.Warnings..

member.name: M:Au.ADebug.Print(System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Calls to show some debug info. Also shows current function name/file/line. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The 3 optional arguments are not used explicitly. If text starts with "<>", it can contain Print tags.

member.name: M:Au.ADebug.PrintIf(System.Boolean,System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: If condition is true, calls to show some debug info. Also shows current function name/file/line. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The 3 optional arguments are not used explicitly. If text starts with "<>", it can contain Print tags.

member.name: M:Au.ADebug.PrintFunc(System.String)
member.summary: Calls with current function name. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The optional argument is not used explicitly.

member.name: M:Au.ADebug.PrintNativeError_(System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: In DEBUG config prints ALastError.Message.

member.name: M:Au.ADebug.PrintNativeError_(System.Int32,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: In DEBUG config prints ALastError.MessageFor(code).

member.name: M:Au.ADebug.Dialog(System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Calls to show some debug info. Works only if DEBUG is defined. Read more in class help. The 3 optional arguments are not used explicitly.

member.remarks: Can be used in functions that have an enum flags parameter but not all passed flags are valid for that function or object state. Does nothing if AOpt.Warnings. == false. When flags are valid, this function is fast.

member.summary: Creates uint by placing (ushort)loWord in bits 1-16 and (ushort)hiWord in bits 17-32. Like C macro MAKELONG, MAKEWPARAM, MAKELPARAM, MAKELRESULT.

Alignment. Must be a power of two (2, 4, 8, 16...).

member.name: M:Au.AOutput.Write(System.String)
member.summary: Writes text + "\r\n" to the output.
member.param: Text. If "" or null, writes empty line. To write "null" if variable s is null, use code AOutput.Write((object)s);.
member.remarks:
Can display links, colors, images, etc. More info: [](xref:output_tags).
Where the text goes: - If redirected, to wherever it is redirected. See . - Else if using log file ( not null), writes to the file. - Else if using console ( returns true), writes to console. - Else if using local (in this process), writes to it. - Else if exists global (in any process), writes to it. - Else nowhere.

Calls and . If the type is unsigned integer (uint, ulong, ushort, byte), writes in hexadecimal format with prefix "0x".
This overload is used for all types except: strings, arrays, generic collections. They have own overloads; to use this function need to cast to object. For ref struct types use AOutput.Write(x.ToString());.

member.name: T:Au.AOutputServer
member.summary: Receives messages sent by .
member.remarks:
If server is global, clients can be multiple processes, including this. Else only this process. Works asynchronously, to make writing messages faster. When a client writes a message, the message arrives to the server with some delay and is placed in a queue. You then can get/remove messages from the queue (call ) and display them in a window (for example). You can be notified about new messages.
Recommended setup (see example): 1. When your application starts, create an AOutputServer instance and assign to a static variable. Call . 2. When your application creates its output window, call to register callback function. 3. In the callback function get/remove/display all new messages. 4. Call when closing the window.

member.name: M:Au.AOutputServer.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.param: If true, will receive output from all processes that don't have local server.

member.name: M:Au.AOutputServer.Start
member.summary: Starts server. Returns false if server already exists (if global - in any process).

member.summary: Stops server.

member.summary: Calls Stop.

member.summary: Sets callback function, to be notified about server events.
member.param: Callback function's delegate. Called when one or more messages are available. It should call until it returns false. See example in class help.
A control or form. The callback function will be called in its thread. If null, the callback function will be called in other thread.

member.name: T:Au.AScreen
member.summary: Gets screens from index/window/point/etc and their properties such as bounds.
member.remarks:
A computer can have one or more screens (aka display devices, monitors) attached that extend desktop space. One of them is the primary screen; its top-left coordinate is 0 0. To show or find a window or some object in a particular screen, need to identify the screen somehow. At Windows API level each screen has a unique int identifier, known as screen handle or HMONITOR. But it is a random variable value and therefore cannot be specified directly in script. In script instead is used screen index or some object on that screen (window, point, rectangle).
There are two types (both are struct): - an AScreen.ScreenHandle variable contains a screen handle, aka HMONITOR. Its functions are used to quickly get properties of that screen, eg bounds. - an AScreen variable contains a value that is used to get screen handle. It can be screen index, window, point, etc, and even a callback function.
AScreen is used mostly in two ways: - the static functions are used to get a screen handle as using screen index, window, point, etc. Then the ScreenHandle gets screen properties. Example: RECT r = AScreen.Of(AWnd.Active).Bounds; //get rectangle of screen that contains the active window - if a function parameter or some property etc is of AScreen type, callers can specify screen index, window, point, etc. Index can be passed directly; for other types use code like new AScreen(window). The AScreen variable holds the specified value. When the function needs screen properties, it calls to get corresponding that value at that time.
Why need two types? Why AScreen doesn't just get and store screen handle immediately when the variable is created. Because a handle cannot be reliably used for a long time. Reasons: - screen handles may change when changing the configuration of multiple screens. - the window etc that identifies the screen later may move to another screen.

member.name: P:Au.AScreen.Value
member.summary: Gets the value as object.

member.name: P:Au.AScreen.IsNull
member.summary: true if this variable does not have a value.

member.summary: Creates variable that holds screen index. Later will be called . Alternatively use implicit conversion from int, for example 1 instead of new AScreen(1).
member.param: 0 primary screen, 1 first nonprimary, and so on. Does not match those in Windows Settings.

member.name: M:Au.AWinImage.Find(Au.Types.WIArea,Au.Types.WIImage,Au.Types.WIFlags,System.Int32,System.Func{Au.AWinImage,Au.Types.WIAlso})
member.summary: Finds image(s) or color(s) displayed in a window or other area.
member.returns: Returns an object that contains the rectangle of the found image and can click it etc. Returns null if not found. See example.
member.param: Where to search: - - window or control. The search area is its client area. - - accessible object. - - another image. - - a rectangle area in screen. - - can contain AWnd, AAcc or Bitmap. Also allows to specify a rectangle in it, which makes the search area smaller and the function faster. Example: AWinImage.Find((w, (left, top, width, height)), "image.png");.
Image or color to find. Or array of them. More info: .

Maximal allowed color difference. Use to to find images that have slightly different colors than the specified image. Can be 0 - 250, but should be as small as possible. Applied to each color component (red, green, blue) of each pixel.

Callback function. Called for each found image instance and receives its rectangle, match index and list index. Can return one of values.
Examples: - Skip some matching images if some condition if false: also: o => condition ? WIAlso.OkReturn : WIAlso.FindOther - Skip n matching images: also: o => o.Skip(n) - Get rectangles etc of all matching images: also: o => { list.Add(o); return false; }. Don't use this code in 'wait' functions. - Get rectangles etc of all matching images and stop waiting: also: o => { list.Add(o); o.Found = true; return false; } - Do different actions depending on which list images found: var found = new BitArray(images.Length); AWinImage.Find(w, images, also: o => { found[o.ListIndex] = true; return WIAlso.OkFindMoreOfList; }); if(found[0]) AOutput.Write(0); if(found[1]) AOutput.Write(1);
member.exception: An argument is/contains a null/invalid value.
member.remarks:
To create code for this function, use dialog "Find image or color in window". It is form Au.Tools.FormAWinImage in Au.Tools.dll.
The speed mostly depends on: 1. The size of the search area. Use the smallest possible area (control or accessible object or rectangle in window like (w, rectangle)). 2. Flags (makes faster), . The speed depends on window. 3. Video driver. Can be much slower if incorrect, generic or virtual PC driver is used. The above flags should help. 4. colorDiff. Should be as small as possible.
If flag or not used, the search area must be visible on the screen, because this function then gets pixels from the screen.
Can find only images that exactly match the specified image. With colorDiff can find images with slightly different colors and brightness. Cannot find images with different shapes.
Transparent and partially transparent pixels are ignored. For example, when you capture a non-rectangular area image, the image actually is rectangular, but pixels outside of its captured area are transparent and therefore not compared. Also you can draw transparent areas with an image editor that supports it, for example Paint.NET.
This function is not the best way to find objects when the script is intended for long use or for use on multiple computers or must be very reliable. Because it may fail to find the image after are changed some settings - system theme, application theme, text size (DPI), font smoothing (if the image contains text), etc. Also are possible various unexpected temporary conditions that may distort or hide the image, for example adjacent window shadow, a tooltip or some temporary window. If possible, in such scripts instead use other functions, eg find control or accessible object.
Flags and cannot be used if area is Bitmap or RECT.

member.name: M:Au.AWinImage.Wait(System.Double,Au.Types.WIArea,Au.Types.WIImage,Au.Types.WIFlags,System.Int32,System.Func{Au.AWinImage,Au.Types.WIAlso})
member.summary: Finds image(s) or color(s) displayed in a window or other area. Waits until found. More info: .
member.returns: Returns object containing the rectangle of the found image. On timeout returns null if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
member.exception: Invalid window handle (the area argument), or the window closed while waiting.

member.summary: Waits until image(s) or color(s) is not displayed in a window or other area. More info: .
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.exception: Invalid window handle (the area argument), or the window closed while waiting.

member.summary: Waits until something visually changes in a window or other area. More info: .
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.exception: Invalid window handle (the area argument), or the window closed while waiting.
member.remarks: The same as , but instead of image parameter this function captures the area image at the beginning.

member.name: T:Au.ACsv
member.summary: Parses and composes CSV text. Stores CSV table data in memory as a List of string arrays.
member.remarks: CSV is a text format used to store a single table of data in human-readable/editable way. It is a list of lines (called rows or records) containing one or more values (called fields or cells) separated by a separator character. There is no strictly defined CSV standard. ACsv uses these rules: Fields containg separator characters (default ','), quote characters (default '"') and multiple lines are enclosed in quote characters. Example: "ab, cd". Each quote character in such fields is escaped (replaced) with two quote characters. Example: "ab ""cd"" ef". If a field value starts or ends with ASCII space or tab characters, it is enclosed in quote characters. Example: " ab ". Or use parameter trimSpaces false when parsing. Rows in CSV text can have different field count. All rows in in-memory CSV table have equal field count.

member.name: M:Au.ACsv.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes new variable that can be used to add rows. To create new variables from CSV text, file or dictionary, instead use static functions, for example .

member.name: P:Au.ACsv.Data
member.summary: Gets the internal List containing rows as string arrays.
member.remarks: It's not a copy; changing it will change the data of this variable. You can do anything with the List. For example, sort it, find rows containing certain field values, get/set field values directly, add/remove rows directly. All row arrays have Length equal to , and it must remain so; you can change Length, but then need to call ColumnCount=newLength.

example.code: x.Data.Sort((a,b) => string.CompareOrdinal(a[0], b[0]));

member.name: P:Au.ACsv.Separator
member.summary: Sets or gets the field separator character used when composing CSV text. Initially it is ','.

member.name: P:Au.ACsv.Quote
member.summary: Sets or gets the quote character used when composing CSV text. Initially it is '"'.

member.name: M:Au.ACsv.Parse(System.String,System.Char,System.Char,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Parses CSV string and creates new variable that contains all data in internal List of string arrays.
member.param: CSV text. If rows in CSV text have different field count, the longest row sets the property and lenghts of all row arrays; array elements of missing CSV fields will be null.
Field separator character used in CSV text. Default ','.
Character used in CSV text to enclose some fields. Default '"'.
Ignore ASCII space and tab characters surrounding fields in CSV text. Default true.
member.exception: Invalid CSV, eg contains incorrectly enclosed fields.

member.name: M:Au.ACsv.ToString
member.summary: Composes CSV text from the internal List of string arrays.
member.remarks: Depends on these properties: (initially ','), (initially '"').

member.name: P:Au.ACsv.ColumnCount
member.summary: Gets or sets column count. The 'get' function returns the length of all string arrays in the internal List. The 'set' function can add new columns or remove columns at the right.

member.param: 0-based row index. With the 'set' function it can be negative or equal to ; then adds new row.
0-based column index. With the 'set' function it can be >= and < 1000; then sets ColumnCount = column + 1.

member.name: T:Au.AExtString
member.summary: Adds extension methods for .
member.remarks: Some .NET methods use by default, while others use ordinal or invariant comparison. It is confusing (difficult to remember), dangerous (easy to make bugs), slower and rarely useful. Microsoft recommends to specify StringComparison.Ordinal[IgnoreCase] explicitly. See https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms973919.aspx. This class adds ordinal comparison versions of these methods. Same or similar name, for example Ends for EndsWith. This class also adds more methods. You also can find string functions in other classes of this library, including , , , , , , , .

member.remarks: Uses ordinal comparison (does not depend on current culture/locale).
