member.name: M:Au.AExtString.ToInt(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@,Au.Types.STIFlags)
member.summary: Converts part of this string to int number and gets the number end index. Returns the number, or 0 if fails to convert.
member.param: This string.
Offset in this string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in this string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.
member.remarks:
Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big.
Unlike int.Parse and Convert.ToInt32: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. The number can be decimal (like "123") or hexadecimal (like "0x1A"); don't need separate flags for each style. Faster.
The number in string can start with ASCII whitespace (spaces, newlines, etc), like " 5". The number in string can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- uint.MaxValue (0xffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than int.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to uint (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=startIndex+1.

member.summary: Converts this string or its part to double number. Returns the number, or 0 if fails to convert.
member.param: This string. Can be null.
Part of this string or null (default).
The permitted number format in the string.
member.remarks: Calls with InvariantCulture. Fails if the string is null or "" or isn't a valid floating-point number. Examples of valid numbers: "12", " -12.3 ", ".12", "12.", "12E3", "12.3e-45", "1,234.5" (with style NumberStyles.Float | NumberStyles.AllowThousands). String like "2text" is invalid, unless range is 0..1.

member.name: M:Au.AExtString.Like(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Compares this string with a string that possibly contains wildcard characters. Returns true if the strings match.
member.param: This string. If null, returns false. If "", returns true if pattern is "" or "*".
String that possibly contains wildcard characters. Cannot be null. If "", returns true if this string is "". If "*", always returns true except when this string is null.
Case-insensitive.
member.remarks:
Wildcard characters:
Character | Will match | Examples | - | - | - | | * | Zero or more of any characters. | "start*", "*end", "*middle*" | ? | Any single character. | "date ????-??-??"
There are no escape sequences for * and ? characters.
Uses ordinal comparison, ie does not depend on current culture.
Much faster than regular expression.
See also: [](xref:wildcard_expression).

member.name: M:Au.AExtString.Like(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String[])
member.summary: Calls for each wildcard pattern specified in the argument list until it returns true. Returns 1-based index of matching pattern, or 0 if none.
member.param: Case-insensitive.
One or more wildcard strings. The array and strings cannot be null.

member.name: T:Au.ARegex
member.summary: PCRE regular expression.
member.remarks:
PCRE is a regular expression library: . PCRE regular expression syntax: full, short. Some websites with tutorials and info: rexegg, regular-expressions.info.
This class is an alternative to the .NET class. The regular expression syntax is similar. PCRE has some features unavailable in .NET, and vice versa. In most cases PCRE is about 2 times faster. You can use any of these classes. Functions of class support only PCRE.
Terms used in this documentation and in names of functions and types: - regular expression - regular expression string. Also known as pattern. - subject string - the string in which to search for the regular expression. Also known as input string. - match - the part (substring) of the subject string that matches the regular expression. - groups - regular expression parts enclosed in (). Except non-capturing parts, like (?:...) and (?options). Also known as capturing group, capturing subpattern. Often term group also is used for group matches. - group match - the part (substring) of the subject string that matches the group. Also known as captured substring.
This library uses an unmanaged code dll AuCpp.dll that contains PCRE code. This class is a managed wrapper for it. The main PCRE API functions used by this class are pcre2_compile and pcre2_match. The ARegex constructor calls pcre2_compile and stores the compiled code in the variable. Other ARegex functions call pcre2_match. Compiling to native code (JIT) is not supported.
An ARegex variable can be used by multiple threads simultaneously.
Also there are several String extension methods that use this class. The string variable is the subject string. These methods create and use cached ARegex instances for speed. The ARegex constructor does not use caching.

member.name: M:Au.ARegex.#ctor(System.String,Au.Types.RXFlags)
member.summary: Compiles regular expression string.
member.param: Regular expression. Cannot be null.
Options. Default 0. Flag UTF is implicitly added if rx contains non-ASCII characters and there is no flag NEVER_UTF.
member.exception: Invalid regular expression. Or failed to compile it for some other reason (unlikely).
member.remarks:
Calls PCRE API function pcre2_compile.
PCRE regular expression syntax: full, short.
Examples in class help: .

member.name: P:Au.ARegex.Callout
member.summary: Sets callout callback function.
member.remarks: Callouts can be used to: 1. Track the matching progress. 2. Get all instances of a group that can match multiple times. 3. Evaluate and reject some matches or match parts. 4. Etc. The callback function is called by , , , , and similar functions, when they reach callout points in regular expression. To insert callout points use (?C), (?C1), (?C2), (?C'name') etc or pass flag AUTO_CALLOUT to the constructor. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout. See also:

member.name: M:Au.ARegex.GroupNumberFromName(System.String)
member.summary: Finds a named group and returns its 1-based index. Returns -1 if not found.
member.param: Group name. In regular expression, to set name of group (text), use (?<NAME>text).
member.exception: More than 1 group have this name.

member.name: M:Au.ARegex.IsMatch(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Range},Au.Types.RXMatchFlags)
member.summary: Returns true if string s matches this regular expression.
member.param: Subject string. If null, always returns false, even if the regular expression matches empty string.

Start and end offsets in the subject string. If null (default), uses whole string. Examples: i..j (from i to j), i.. (from i to the end), ..j (from 0 to j). The subject part before the start index is not ignored if regular expression starts with a lookbehind assertion or anchor, eg ^ or \b or (?<=...). Instead of ^ you can use \G. More info in PCRE documentation topic pcre2api, chapter "The string to be matched by pcre2_match()". The subject part after the end index is always ignored.
Options. The same options also can be set in ARegex constructor's flags. Constructor's flags and matchFlags are added, which means that matchFlags cannot unset flags set by constructor.
member.exception: The PCRE API function pcre2_match failed. Unlikely.
member.remarks:
If partial match, returns true too. Partial match is possible if used a PARTIAL_ flag.
This function is similar to .

member.name: M:Au.ARegex.Match(System.String,Au.Types.RXMatch@,System.Nullable{System.Range},Au.Types.RXMatchFlags)
member.summary: Returns true if string s matches this regular expression. Gets match info as .
member.param: Subject string. If null, always returns false, even if the regular expression matches empty string.
Receives match info. Read more in Remarks.
See .
See .
member.exception: The PCRE API function pcre2_match failed. Unlikely.
member.remarks:
If full match, returns true, and result contains the match and all groups that exist in the regular expressions. If partial match, returns true, and result contains the match without groups. Partial match is possible if used a PARTIAL_ flag. If no match, returns false, and result normally is null. But if a mark is available, result is an object with two valid properties - (false) and ; other properties have undefined values or throw exception.
This function is similar to .

member.param: Subject string. If null, always returns false, even if the regular expression matches empty string.

Group number (1-based index) of result. If 0 (default) - whole match. See also .
See .
See .
member.exception: The PCRE API function pcre2_match failed. Unlikely.
member.remarks: This function is a simplified version of . If full match, returns true, and result contains the match or the specifed group. If partial match, returns true too. Partial match is possible if used a PARTIAL_ flag. Then cannot get groups, therefore group should be 0. If no match, returns false, and result is empty.

member.name: M:Au.ARegex.AddReplaceFunc(System.String,System.Func{Au.Types.RXMatch,System.String})
member.summary: Adds or replaces a function that is called when a regular expression replacement string contains ${+name}.
member.param: A string used to identify the function. Can contain any characters except '}'.
Callback function's delegate, eg lambda. Called for each found match. Returns the replacement. In the callback function you can use .
member.remarks: Can be used when there is no way to use Replace overloads with a replFunc parameter. For example in Find/Replace UI.
member.example:
Create new script in the Au editor and add this code. In Properties set role editorExtension. Run. Then in the Find pane in the replacement field you can use ${+Upper} and ${+Lower}.
ARegex.AddReplaceFunc("Upper", m => m.Value.Upper()); //make uppercase ARegex.AddReplaceFunc("Lower", m => m.Value.Lower()); //make lowercase

member.summary: Returns array of substrings delimited by regular expression matches.
member.param: Subject string. Cannot be null.
The maximal count of substrings to get. The last substring contains the unsplit remainder of the subject string. If 0 (default) or negative, gets all.
See .
See .
member.exception: 1. Used a PARTIAL_ flag. 2. The regular expression contains (?=...\K).
The PCRE API function pcre2_match failed. Unlikely.
member.remarks:
Element 0 of the returned array is s substring until the first match of the regular expression, element 1 is substring between the first and second match, and so on. If no matches, the array contains single element and it is s.
This function is similar to .

member.name: M:Au.ARegex.EscapeQE(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Encloses string in \Q \E if it contains metacharacters \^$.[|()?*+{ or if always == true.
member.param: Enclose always, even if the string does not contain metacharacters. Should be true if the regular expression in which this string will be used has option "extended", because then whitespace is ignored and # is a special character too.
member.remarks: Such enclosed substring in a regular expression is interpreted as a literal string. This function also escapes \E, so that it does not end the literal string.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ADisableFsRedirection.Disable
member.summary: If , calls API Wow64DisableWow64FsRedirection, which disables file system redirection. The caller can call this without checking OS and process bitness. This function checks it and it is fast. Always call or Dispose, for example use finally or using statement. Not calling it is more dangerous than a memory leak. It is not called by GC.

member.name: T:Au.Util.AMemory
member.summary: Allocates memory from native heap of this process using heap API. Uses the common heap of this process, API GetProcessHeap. Usually slightly faster than Marshal class functions.

member.name: M:Au.Util.AMemory.Alloc(Au.Types.LPARAM,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Allocates new memory block and returns its address.
member.param: Byte count.
Set all bytes = 0.
member.exception: Failed. Probably size is too big.
member.remarks: Calls API HeapAlloc. The memory is unmanaged and will not be freed automatically. Always call when done or if need to resize it without losing data.

member.name: M:Au.Util.AMemory.ReAlloc(System.Void*,Au.Types.LPARAM,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Reallocates a memory block to make it bigger or smaller. Returns its address.
member.param: Old memory address. If null, allocates new memory like .
New byte count.
When size is growing, set all added bytes = 0.
member.exception: Failed. Probably size is too big.
member.remarks: Calls API HeapReAlloc or HeapAlloc. Preserves data in Math.Min(old size, new size) bytes of old memory (copies from old memory if need). The memory is unmanaged and will not be freed automatically. Always call when done or ReAlloc if need to resize it without losing data.

member.name: M:Au.Util.AMemory.Free(System.Void*)
member.summary: Frees a memory block. Does nothing if mem is null.
member.remarks: Calls API HeapFree.

member.name: T:Au.Util.AMemoryArray
member.summary: Allocates memory buffers that can be used with API functions and not only. Can allocate arrays of any value type - char[], byte[] etc.

member.name: M:Au.Util.AMemoryArray.Get``1(System.Int32,System.WeakReference{``0[]}@)
member.summary: Allocates new or gets "cached" array of type T of length n or more. The returned array is managed by a WeakReference<T[]> variable provided by the caller. Its contents is undefined.
member.typeparam: Any simple value type, for example char, byte, RECT.
member.param: How many elements you need. If array in the WeakReference variable is null or too small, creates new array and stores it there. For byte[] and char[] types actually allocates Math.Max(n, 300)+1 elements. The 300 is to avoid future reallocations. The +1 can be used for example for '\0' character at the end of string.

A reference to a WeakReference variable that manages the returned array. If null, this function will create it. The variable should be [ThreadStatic] static. Or can be a non-static field of a long-living object. Must not be simply static, it's not thread-safe (unless locked).
member.remarks: Used to avoid creating much garbage when array allocations are needed frequently. Also is faster than code like var b=new byte[1000] or StringBuilder. The WeakReference variable allows the array to be garbage-collected if it is not used when GC runs. It is automatic and safe. Next time this function will create new array. Actually this function is a wrapper for WeakReference<T[]> functions TryGetTarget/SetTarget. Makes it easier to use.

member.name: T:Au.Util.AMemoryArray.CharBuffer

member.summary: Converts multiple recorded mouse movements to string for .
member.param: List of x y distances from previous. The first distance is from the mouse position before the first movement; at run time it will be distance from . To create uint value from distance dx dy use this code: AMath.MakeUint(dx, dy).

recorded also contains sleep times (milliseconds) alternating with distances. It must start with a sleep time. Example: {time1, dist1, time2, dist2}. Another example: {time1, dist1, time2, dist2, time3}. This is invalid: {dist1, time1, dist2, time2}.

member.name: T:Au.Util.AWinFormsControlNames
member.summary: Gets programming names of .NET Windows Forms controls.
member.remarks: Usually each control has a unique name. It's the Control.Name property. Useful to identify controls without a classic name/text. The control id of these controls is not useful, it is not constant.

member.name: M:Au.Util.AWinFormsControlNames.#ctor(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Prepares to get control names.
member.param: Any top-level or child window of that process.
member.exception: Failed to allocate process memory (see ) needed to get control names, usually because of [](xref:uac).

member.name: M:Au.Util.AWinFormsControlNames.GetControlName(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Gets control name. Returns null if fails or the name is empty.
member.param: The control. Can be a top-level window too. Must be of the same process as the window specified in the constructor.

member.name: M:Au.Util.AWinFormsControlNames.IsWinFormsControl(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Returns true if window class name starts with "WindowsForms". Usually it means that we can get Windows Forms control name of w and its child controls.
member.param: The window. Can be top-level or control.

member.name: M:Au.Util.AWinFormsControlNames.GetSingleControlName(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Gets the programming name of a Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails.
member.param: The control. Can be top-level window too.
member.remarks: This function is easy to use and does not throw excaptions. However, when you need names of multiple controls of a single window, better create an AWinFormsControlNames instance (once) and for each control call its GetControlNameOrText method, it will be faster.

member.name: T:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1
member.summary: Like List or StringBuilder, used as a temporary variable-size array to create final fixed-size array. To avoid much garbage (and many reallocations when growing), uses native memory heap. See . Must be explicitly disposed to free the native memory. Does not have a finalizer because is struct (to avoid garbage). Does not support reference types. Does not call T.Dispose.

member.name: P:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.Ptr
member.summary: Gets array memory address (address of element 0).

member.name: P:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of elements.

member.name: P:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.ByteCount
member.summary: Gets the number of bytes in the array (Count*sizeof(T)).

member.name: P:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.Capacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the total number of elements (not bytes) the internal memory can hold without resizing.
member.exception: (the 'set' function) value less than Count. Instead use ReAlloc or Free.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.Alloc(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Allocates count elements. Sets Count=count. Frees previously allocated memory. Returns memory address (address of element 0).
member.param: Element count.
Set all bytes = 0. If false, the memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Default true. Slower when true.
Set Capacity = count. If false, allocates more if count is less thah the minimal capacity for this type.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.ReAlloc(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds or removes elements at the end. Sets Count=count. Preserves Math.Min(Count, count) existing elements. Returns memory address (address of element 0).
member.param: New element count.
Set all added bytes = 0. If false, the added memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Default true. Slower when true.
Set Capacity = count. If false, allocates more if count is less thah the minimal capacity for this type.
member.remarks: The new memory usually is at a new location. The preserved elements are copied there. Sets Count=count. To allocate more memory without changing Count, change Capacity instead.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.Free
member.summary: Frees memory. Sets Count and Capacity = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.AddR(`0@)
member.summary: Adds one element. The same as Add, but uses 'in'. Use to avoid copying values of big types.

member.summary: Adds one element.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ArrayBuilder_`1.Add
member.summary: Adds one zero-inited element and returns its reference.

member.summary: Capacity = Math.Max(_cap * 2, s_minCap).

member.name: T:Au.Util.EnsureWindowsFormsSynchronizationContext_
member.summary: Constructor ensures that current SynchronizationContext of this thread is WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext. Also sets WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.AutoInstall=false to prevent Application.DoEvents etc setting wrong context. Dispose() restores both if need. Does not restore context if was null. Example: using(new Util.EnsureWindowsFormsSynchronizationContext_()) { ... }

member.name: M:Au.Util.EnsureWindowsFormsSynchronizationContext_.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: See class help.
member.param: Do nothing if WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.AutoInstall==false. Normally WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.AutoInstall is true (default).

member.name: M:Au.Util.EnsureWindowsFormsSynchronizationContext_.EnsurePermanently
member.summary: If synchronization context of this thread is null or not WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext, makes it WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext. Use this instead of creating instance when will not need to restore previous synchronization context.
member.exception: This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null. Or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.name: T:Au.Util.IconsAsync_
member.summary: Gets file icons asynchronously.
member.remarks: Use to avoid waiting until all icons are extracted before displaying them in a UI (menu etc). Instead you show the UI without icons, and then asynchronously receive icons when they are extracted. At first call (for each file) or . Then call . Create a callback function of type and pass its delegate to GetAllAsync.

member.summary: Adds a file path to an internal collection.
member.param: File path etc. See .
Something to pass to your callback function together with icon handle for this file.

member.name: M:Au.Util.IconsAsync_.AddRange(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Au.Util.IconsAsync_.Item})
member.summary: Adds multiple file paths to an internal collection. The same as calling multiple times. This function copies the list.

member.name: P:Au.Util.IconsAsync_.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of added items. sets it = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Util.IconsAsync_.GetAllAsync(Au.Util.IconsAsync_.Callback,System.Int32,Au.Types.IconGetFlags,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts getting icons of added files.
member.param: A callback function delegate.
Icon width and height.
Something to pass to callback functions.
member.remarks: After this function returns, icons are asynchronously extracted with , and callback called with icon handle (or default(IntPtr) if failed). The callback is called in this thread. This thread must have a message loop (eg Application.Run). If you'll need more icons, you can add more files and call this function again with the same IconsAsync_ instance, even if getting old icons if still not finished.

member.name: T:Au.Util.JSettings
member.summary: Base of classes that load/save various settings from/to a JSON file.
member.remarks:
Derived classes must provide public get/set properties. - 'get' usually just return a field. - 'set' must call a SetX method provided by this base class. Then changes will be automatically lazily saved.
All functions are thread-safe, except when setting/getting non-atomic struct types (containing multiple fields, decimal, also long in 32-bit process).

member.name: M:Au.Util.JSettings._Load``1(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads JSON file and deserializes to new object of type T. Sets to save automatically whenever a property changed. Returns new empty object if file does not exist or failed to load or parse (invalid JSON) or useDefault true. If failed, writes error info to the output.
member.param: Full path of .json file. If null, does not load and will not save.
Use default settings, don't load from file. Delete file if exists.

member.name: M:Au.Util.JSettings.Dispose
member.summary: Call this when finished using the settings. Saves now if need, and stops autosaving. Don't need to call if the settings are used until process exit.

member.name: M:Au.Util.JSettings.SaveIfNeed
member.summary: Saves now if need. Don't need to call explicitly. Autosaving is every 2 s, also on process exit and Dispose.

member.name: M:Au.Util.JSettings.SaveLater
member.summary: Call this when changed an array element etc directly without assigning the array etc to a property. Else changes may be not saved.

member.summary: Sets a string property value and will save later if need. If !_loaded, sets prop = value. Else if value != prop, sets prop = value and _save = true.
member.param: Property.
New value.

member.summary: Sets an int, bool or other IEquatable type property value and will save later if need. If !_loaded, sets prop = value. Else if value != prop, sets prop = value and _save = true.
member.param: Property.
New value.

member.name: T:Au.Util.Serializer_
member.summary: Binary-serializes and deserializes multiple values of types int, string, string[], byte[] and null. Used mostly for sending parameters for IPC through pipe etc. Similar to BinaryWriter, but faster and less garbage. Much faster than BinaryFormatter, CSV, etc. Serializes all values into a byte[] in single call. If need to append, use BinaryWriter instead.

member.name: T:Au.Util.Serializer_.Value
member.summary: Type of input and output values of functions. Has implicit conversions from/to int and string.

member.name: M:Au.Util.Serializer_.Serialize(Au.Util.Serializer_.Value[])
member.summary: Serializes multiple values of types int, string, string[] and null. The returned array can be passed to .

member.name: M:Au.Util.Serializer_.SerializeWithSize(Au.Util.Serializer_.Value[])
member.summary: Serializes multiple values of types int, string, string[] and null. Unlike , in the first 4 bytes writes the size of data that follows. Can be used with pipes or other streams where data size is initially unknown: read 4 bytes as int dataSize; var b=new byte[dataSize], read it, pass b to .

member.name: M:Au.Util.Serializer_.Deserialize(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Deserializes values serialized by . Returns array of values passed to Serialize.

member.name: T:Au.Util.SharedMemory_
member.summary: Memory shared by all processes using this library.

member.name: F:Au.Util.SharedMemory_.Ptr
member.summary: Gets pointer to the shared memory.

member.name: M:Au.Util.SharedMemory_.CreateOrGet(System.String,System.UInt32,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Creates named shared memory of specified size. Opens if already exists. Returns shared memory address in this process. Calls API CreateFileMapping and API MapViewOfFile.
member.param: Shared memory name. Case-insensitive.
Shared memory size. Ignored if the shared memory already exists.
Receives true if created and not opened.
member.remarks: Once the memory is created, it is alive at least until this process ends. Other processes can keep the memory alive even after that. There is no Close function to close the native shared memory object handle. The OS closes it when this process ends.

member.name: T:Au.Util.StringBuilder_
member.summary: Provides a cached reusable instance of StringBuilder per thread. It's an optimisation that reduces the number of instances constructed and collected. Used like using(new Au.Util.StringBuilder_(out var b)) { b.Append("example"); var s = b.ToString(); }.
member.remarks: This is a modified copy of the .NET internal StringBuilderCache class. The cache uses 2 [ThreadLocal] StringBuilder instances, which allows 1 nesting level. Not error to use deeper nesting level, but then gets new StringBuilder, not from the cache.

member.name: F:Au.Util.StringBuilder_.MAX_BUILDER_SIZE
member.summary: 2000. The cache is not used if capacity is bigger.

member.name: M:Au.Util.StringBuilder_.#ctor(System.Text.StringBuilder@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a new or cached/cleared StringBuilder of the specified capacity, min 200.

member.name: M:Au.Util.StringBuilder_.Dispose
member.summary: Releases the StringBuilder to the cache.

member.name: T:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_
member.summary: Thread pool where COM can be used. Initializes thread COM as single-thread-apartment.

member.name: T:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.WorkCallbackData
member.summary: Work callback function parameter type. More info: .

member.name: T:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.WorkCallback
member.summary: Work callback function type.
member.param: Contains state and completionCallback that were passed to the submit function. Your work callback function can change completionCallback and/or state. For example it can set completionCallback = null to prevent calling it (the call is expensive); or change state, if want to pass another object to the completion function. Note that the completion function is never called if initially it was null.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.SubmitCallback(System.Object,Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.WorkCallback,System.Threading.SendOrPostCallback)
member.summary: Requests that a thread pool thread call the callback function.
member.param: Something to pass to the callback functions.
Callback function to call in a thread pool thread.
Optional callback function to call in this thread after workCallback.
member.exception: (only when completionCallback is used) This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null; or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.CreateWork(System.Object,Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.WorkCallback,System.Threading.SendOrPostCallback)
member.summary: Creates a object that can be used when need more options than has.
member.param: Something to pass to the callback functions.
Callback function to call in a thread pool thread.
Optional callback function to call in this thread after workCallback.
member.remarks: Call Dispose() to avoid memory leaks. If not called, the object and related OS object remain in memory until this process ends.
member.exception: (only when completionCallback is used) This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null; or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.name: T:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.Work
member.summary: Allows to submit a callback function (one or more times) to be called in thread pool threads, then optionally wait and cancel. Can be used when need more options than has.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.Work.#ctor(System.Object,Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.WorkCallback,System.Threading.SendOrPostCallback,System.Boolean)
member.exception: (only when completionCallback is used) This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null; or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.Work.Submit
member.summary: Requests that a thread pool thread call the callback function. This function can be called multiple times.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.Work.Wait
member.summary: Waits until all submitted instances of the callback function finish their work. While waiting, this thread cannot dispatch events and Windows messages.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.Work.Cancel
member.summary: Waits until all running instances of the callback function finish their work, and cancels pending (still not running) instances. While waiting, this thread cannot dispatch events and Windows messages.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA_.Work.Dispose
member.summary: Calls , releases all resources used by this object and allows this object to be garbage-collected. Call this to avoid memory leaks. If not called, the object and related OS object remain in memory until this process ends.

member.name: M:Au.ATask.Run(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Starts an automation task. Does not wait.
member.returns: Native process id of the task process. Returns 0 if task start is deferred because a script is running (see meta option ifRunning). Returns 0 if role editorExtension; then waits until the task ends. Returns -1 if failed to start the script, for example it contains errors or cannot run because a script is running.
member.param: Script name like "Script5.cs", or path like @"\Folder\Script5.cs".
Command line arguments. In script it will be variable args. Should not contain '\0' characters.

member.summary: Starts an automation task and waits until it ends. More info: .
member.returns: The exit code of the task process. See .

member.summary: Starts an automation task, waits until it ends and gets its strings written by . More info: .
member.param: Receives output.
member.returns: The exit code of the task process. See .

member.summary: Starts an automation task, waits until it ends and gets its strings written by . More info: .
member.param: Receives output whenever the task calls it.
member.returns: The exit code of the task process. See .

member.name: P:Au.ATask.WndMsg_
member.summary: Finds editor's message-only window used with WM_COPYDATA etc.

member.name: M:Au.ATask.WriteResult(System.String)
member.summary: Writes a string result for the task that called or to run this task, or for the program that executed "Au.CL.exe" to run this task with command line like "Au.CL.exe **Script5.cs". Returns false if this task was not started in such a way. Returns null if failed to write, except when s is null/"".
member.param: A string. This function does not append newline characters.
member.remarks: The RunWait(Action) overload can read the string in real time. The RunWait(out string) overload gets all strings joined when the task ends. The program that executed "Au.CL.exe" to run this task with command line like "Au.CL.exe **Script5.cs" can read the string from the redirected standard output in real time, or the string is written to its console in real time. The string encoding is UTF8; if you use a bat file or cmd.exe and want to get correct Unicode text, execute this before, to change console code page to UTF-8: chcp 65001.

member.name: T:Au.AScript
member.summary: This class is used in automation script files as base of their main class. Adds some features.
member.remarks:
This class adds these features: 1. The static constructor subscribes to the event. On unhandled exception shows exception info in output. Without this class not all unhandled exceptions would be shown. 2. Provides virtual function . The script can override it. 3. Provides property .
More features may be added in the future.

member.name: M:Au.AScript.OnUnhandledException(System.UnhandledExceptionEventArgs)
member.summary: Writes exception info to the output. Override this function to intercept unhandled exceptions. Call the base function if want to see exception info as usually.

member.name: P:Au.AScript.Triggers
member.summary: Gets or sets an instance, as a field of this class.
member.remarks: This property can be used in automation scripts to avoid creating an ActionTriggers variable explicitly. The returned value is a field of this class. The ActionTriggers object is auto-created when callig this property first time or after setting it = null. In automation scripts this property is available because this class is the base of the Script class. In other classes need to create an ActionTriggers variable explicitly. In scripts you also can create explicitly if you like, for example to have more than one instance.

example.code: Triggers.Hotkey["Ctrl+K"] = o => AOutput.Write(o.Trigger); Triggers.Run();

member.name: M:Au.APerf.SpeedUpCpu(System.Int32)
member.summary: Executes some code in loop for the specified amount of time. It should make CPU to run at full speed.
member.param: How long to speed up CPU, milliseconds. The minimal required time probably is about 100 ms, but depends on CPU.
member.remarks:
Code speed measurements often are misleading because of variable CPU speed. Most CPU don't run at full speed when not actively used.
You can make CPU speed constant in Control Panel -> Power Options -> ... Advanced -> Processor power management -> Minimum or maximum power state. There are programs that show current CPU speed. For example HWMonitor.

member.name: P:Au.APerf.Shared
member.summary: Gets a reference to a variable in shared memory.
member.remarks: The variable can be used by multiple processes, for example to measure process startup time. Note: slow first time in process, eg 3 ms. It's because need to JIT-compile functions and open shared memory.

member.name: T:Au.ATime
member.summary: Time functions. Get time, sleep/wait, doevents.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.PerfMicroseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of microseconds elapsed since Windows startup. Uses the high-resolution system timer.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryPerformanceCounter. This function is used to measure time differences with 1 microsecond precision, like var t1=ATime.PerfMicroseconds; ... var t2=ATime.PerfMicroseconds; var diff=t2-t1;. Independent of computer clock time changes. MSDN article: Acquiring high-resolution time stamps.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.PerfMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup. Uses the high-resolution system timer.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryPerformanceCounter. This function is used to measure time differences with 1 ms precision, like var t1=ATime.PerfMilliseconds; ... var t2=ATime.PerfMilliseconds; var diff=t2-t1;. The return value equals /1000 but is slightly different than of and other similar functions of this library, Windows API and .NET. Never compare times returned by different functions. Independent of computer clock time changes.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.WinMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup.
member.remarks: Uses API GetTickCount64. Like , but returns a 64-bit value that does not overflow. Uses the low-resolution system timer. Its period usually is 15.25 ms. When need to measure time differences with better precision, use or . Independent of computer clock time changes.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.WinMilliseconds32
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup.
member.remarks: Uses API GetTickCount. The same as . Returns a 32-bit value that overflows after 24.9 days. Uses the low-resolution system timer. Its period usually is 15.25 ms. Independent of computer clock time changes.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.WinMillisecondsWithoutSleep
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup, not including the time when the computer sleeps or hibernates.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryUnbiasedInterruptTime. Uses the low-resolution system timer. Its period usually is 15.25 ms. Independent of computer clock time changes.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.Sleep(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits timeMilliseconds milliseconds.
member.param: Time to wait, milliseconds. Or .
member.remarks: Calls . Does not process Windows messages and other events, therefore should not be used in threads with windows, timers, hooks, events or COM, unless timeMilliseconds is small. Supports APC. If the computer goes to sleep or hibernate during that time, the real time is the specified time + the sleep/hibernate time.
member.exception: timeMilliseconds is negative and not Timeout.Infinite (-1).

member.name: M:Au.ATime.ms(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits timeMilliseconds milliseconds. The same as .
member.exception: timeMilliseconds is negative and not Timeout.Infinite (-1).

member.name: M:Au.ATime.s(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits timeSeconds seconds. The same as and , but the time is specified in seconds, not milliseconds.
member.param: Time to wait, seconds.
member.exception: timeSeconds is less than 0 or greater than 2147483 (int.MaxValue/1000, 24.8 days).

member.name: M:Au.ATime.s(System.Double)
member.summary: Waits timeSeconds seconds. The same as and , but the time is specified in seconds, not milliseconds.
member.param: Time to wait, seconds. The smallest value is 0.001 (1 ms).
member.exception: timeSeconds is less than 0 or greater than 2147483 (int.MaxValue/1000, 24.8 days).

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepDoEvents(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits timeMS milliseconds. While waiting, retrieves and dispatches Windows messages and other events.
member.param: Time to wait, milliseconds. Or .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function retrieves and dispatches Windows messages, calls .NET event handlers, hook procedures, timer functions, COM/RPC, etc. Supports APC. This function can be used in threads with windows. However usually there are better ways, for example timer, other thread, async/await/Task. In some places this function does not work as expected, for example in Form/Control mouse event handlers .NET blocks other mouse events. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as . Calls API MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx and .
member.exception: timeMS is negative and not Timeout.Infinite.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepDoEvents_(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: SleepDoEvents + noSetPrecision.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.DoEvents
member.summary: Retrieves and dispatches events and Windows messages from the message queue of this thread.
member.remarks: Similar to , but more lightweight. Uses API functions PeekMessage, TranslateMessage and DispatchMessage. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as Application.DoEvents.

member.name: T:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_
member.summary: Temporarily changes the time resolution/precision of Thread.Sleep and some other functions.
member.remarks: Uses API timeBeginPeriod, which requests a time resolution for various system timers and wait functions. Actually it is the system thread scheduling timer period. Normal resolution on Windows 7-10 is 15.625 ms. It means that, for example, Thread.Sleep(1); sleeps not 1 but 1-15 ms. If you set resolution 1, it sleeps 1-2 ms. The new resolution is revoked (timeEndPeriod) when disposing the SleepPrecision_ variable or when this process ends. See example. See also . The resolution is applied to all threads and processes. Other applications can change it too. For example, often web browsers temporarily set resolution 1 ms when opening a web page. The system uses the smallest period (best resolution) that currently is set by any application. You cannot make it bigger than current value. It is not recommended to keep small period (high resolution) for a long time. It can be bad for power saving. Don't need this for ATime.SleepX and functions that use them (AMouse.Click etc). They call when the sleep time is 1-99 ms. This does not change the minimal period of and System.Windows.Forms.Timer.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API timeBeginPeriod.
member.param: New system timer period, milliseconds. Should be 1. Other values may stuck and later cannot be made smaller due to bugs in OS or some applications; this bug would impact many functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.Dispose
member.summary: Calls API timeEndPeriod.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.Current
member.summary: Gets current actual system time resolution (period). The return value usually is between 0.5 and 15.625 milliseconds. Returns 0 if fails.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.TempSet1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Temporarily sets the system wait precision to 1 ms. It will be revoked after the specified time or when this process ends. If already set, just updates the revoking time.
member.param: Revoke after this time, milliseconds.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.TempSet1_(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls TempSet1 if sleepTimeMS is 1-99.
member.param: milliseconds of the caller 'sleep' function.

member.name: T:Au.ATimer
member.summary: Timer that uses API SetTimer.
member.remarks: Similar to System.Windows.Forms.Timer, but more lightweight, for example does not create a hidden window. Use in UI threads. Does not work if this thread does not retrieve/dispatch posted messages (WM_TIMER).

member.name: P:Au.ATimer.Tag
member.summary: Something to attach to this variable.

member.name: P:Au.ATimer.IsRunning
member.summary: true if the timer is started and not stopped. Note: single-period timer is automatically stopped before calling the callback function.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.After(System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts one-time timer. If already started, resets and changes its period.
member.param: Time interval after which will be called the callback function, milliseconds. The actual minimal interval is 10-20 ms.
Something to pass to the callback function as .
member.exception: Called not in the same thread as previous Start.
member.remarks: The timer will be stopped before calling the callback function. The callback function can start it again. If already started, this function must be called in the same thread as when started.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.Every(System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts periodic timer. If already started, resets and changes its period.
member.param: Time interval (period) of calling the callback function, milliseconds. The actual minimal period is 10-20 ms.
Something to pass to the callback function as .
member.exception: Called not in the same thread as previous Start.
member.remarks: The callback function can stop the timer or restart with different period. If already started, this function must be called in the same thread as when started.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.Stop
member.summary: Stops the timer.
member.exception: Called not in the same thread as Start.
member.remarks: The callback function will not be called after this. Later you can start the timer again (call or ). Don't need to call this function for single-period timers. For periodic timers it is optional; the timer stops when the thread ends. This function must be called in the same thread as Start.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.Now
member.summary: Execute the timer action now.
member.remarks: Does not change any properties. Just calls the callback function. Does not handle exceptions.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.After(System.Int32,System.Action{Au.ATimer},System.Object)
member.summary: Creates and starts new one-time timer. Returns new object. Usually you don't need it.
member.param: Time interval after which will be called the callback function, milliseconds. The actual minimal interval is 10-20 ms.
Callback function.
Something to pass to the callback function as .
member.remarks: The timer will be stopped before calling the callback function. The callback function can start it again. The callback function will be called in this thread. This thread must must get/dispatch posted messages, eg call Application.Run() or Form.ShowModal() or ADialog.Show(). The callback function is not called while this thread does not do it.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.Every(System.Int32,System.Action{Au.ATimer},System.Object)
member.summary: Creates and starts new periodic timer. Returns new object that can be used to modify timer properties if you want to do it not in the callback function; usually don't need it.
member.param: Time interval (period) of calling the callback function, milliseconds. The actual minimal period is 10-20 ms.
Callback function.
Something to pass to the callback function as .
member.remarks: The callback function can stop the timer or restart with different period. The callback function will be called in this thread. This thread must must get/dispatch posted messages, eg call Application.Run() or Form.ShowModal() or ADialog.Show(). The callback function is not called while this thread does not do it.

member.name: T:Au.AWaitFor
member.summary: Contains functions to wait for a user-defined condition or variable.
member.remarks:
Specialized 'wait for' functions are in other classes, for example .
All 'wait for' functions have a secondsTimeout parameter. It is the maximal time to wait, seconds. If it is 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, then stops waiting and returns default value of that type (false, etc).
While waiting, most functions by default don't dispatch Windows messages, events, hooks, timers, COM/RPC, etc. For example, if used in a Form/Control event handler, the form would stop responding. Use another thread, for example async/await/Task, like in the example. Or option .

member.name: T:Au.AWaitFor.Loop
member.summary: Can be used to easily implement 'wait for' functions with a timeout.
member.remarks: See examples. The code works like most 'wait for' functions of this library: on timeout throws exception, unless secondsTimeout is negative. Similar code is used by most 'wait for' functions of this library. See also ; usually it's easier; internally it uses similar code too.

member.name: P:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.Period
member.summary: Current period ( sleep time), milliseconds. Initially it is , optionally multiplied by constructor's options.Period/10. Default 10 ms. Then each increments it until .

member.name: P:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.MaxPeriod
member.summary: Maximal period ( sleep time), milliseconds. It is *50 (default 500).

member.name: P:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.TimeRemaining
member.summary: Gets or sets the remaining time, milliseconds.

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.#ctor(System.Double,Au.Types.OptWaitFor)
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, then returns false.
Options. If null, uses , else combines with it.

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.Sleep
member.summary: Calls . If it returns true, returns false. Else sleeps for milliseconds, increments Period if it is less than , and returns true.

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.IsTimeout
member.summary: If the secondsTimeout time is not expired, returns false. Else if secondsTimeout is negative, returns true. Else throws .

member.summary: Waits for a user-defined condition.

Callback function (eg lambda). It is called repeatedly, until returns true. The calling period depends on options.
Options. If null, uses , else combines with it.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.remarks: More info: .
member.example: See .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Handle(System.Double,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: Waits for a kernel object (event, mutex, etc).
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
One or more handles of kernel objects. Max 63.
member.returns: Returns 1-based index of the first signaled handle. Negative if abandoned mutex. On timeout returns 0 if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.exception: Failed. For example a handle is invalid.
member.remarks: Uses API WaitForMultipleObjectsEx or MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx. Alertable. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Wait_(System.Int64,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: Waits for a signaled kernel handle. Or just sleeps, if handles is null/empty. If flag DoEvents, dispatches received messages, hook notifications, etc. Calls API WaitForMultipleObjectsEx or MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx with QS_ALLINPUT. Alertable. When a handle becomes signaled, returns its 0-based index. If abandoned mutex, returns 0-based index + Api.WAIT_ABANDONED_0 (0x80). If timeMS>0, waits max timeMS and on timeout returns Api.WAIT_TIMEOUT. If failed, returns -1. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Wait_(System.Int64,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.Object,Au.Types.WaitVariable_,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: The same as + can wait for message and variable. If msgCallback is not null, calls it when dispatching messages. If returns true, stops waiting and returns handles?.Length. If it is WPMCallback, calls it before dispatching a posted message. If it is Func{bool}, calls it after dispatching one or more messages. If stopVar is not null, when it becomes true stops waiting and returns handles?.Length + 1.

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.PostedMessage(System.Double,Au.Types.WPMCallback)
member.summary: Waits for a posted message received by this thread.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
Callback function that returns true to stop waiting. More info in Remarks.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.remarks: While waiting, dispatches Windows messages etc, like . Before dispatching a posted message, calls the callback function. Stops waiting when it returns true. Does not dispatch the message if the function sets the message field = 0. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.MessagesAndCondition(System.Double,System.Func{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Waits for a variable or other condition that is changed while processing messages or other events received by this thread.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
Callback function that returns true to stop waiting. More info in Remarks.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.remarks: While waiting, dispatches Windows messages etc, like . After dispatching one or more messages or other events (posted messages, messages sent by other threads, hooks, etc), calls the callback function. Stops waiting when it returns true. Similar to . Differences: 1. Always dispatches messages etc. 2. Does not call the callback function when there are no messages etc. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Variable(System.Double,System.Boolean@,Au.Types.OptWaitFor)
member.summary: Waits until a variable is set = true.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
Stop waiting when this variable is set to true.
Options. If null, uses , else combines with it.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.remarks: This function is useful when the variable can be changed by any thread. To wait for a variable changed while processing messages etc in this thread, it's better to use .

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs
member.summary: Allows to define custom scopes/contexts/conditions for triggers.
member.remarks:
Similar to (code like Triggers.Of.Window(...);), but allows to define any scope/condition/etc, not just the active window.
To define a scope, you create a callback function (CF) that checks some conditions and returns true to allow the trigger action to run or false to not allow. Assign the CF to some property of this class and then add the trigger, like in the examples below. The CF will be assigned to the trigger and called when need.
You may ask: why to use CF when the trigger action (TA) can do the same? 1. CF runs synchronously; if it returns false, the trigger key or mouse button message is passed to other triggers, hooks and apps. TA cannot do it reliably; it runs asynchronously, and the message is already stealed from other apps/triggers/hooks. 2. CF is faster to call. It is simply called in the same thread that processes trigger messages. TA usually runs in another thread. 3. A CF can be assigned to multiple triggers with a single line of code. Don't need to add the same code in all trigger actions.
A trigger can have up to 4 CF delegates and a window scope (Triggers.Of...). They are called in this order: CF assigned through , , window scope, , . The NextX properties assign the CF to the next single trigger. The FollowingX properties assign the CF to all following triggers until you assign another CF or null. If several are assigned, the trigger action runs only if all CF return true and the window scope matches. The XBeforeWindow properties are used only with hotkey, autotext and mouse triggers.
All CF must be as fast as possible. Slow CF can make triggers slower (or even all keyboard/mouse input); also may cause warnings and trigger failures. A big problem is the low-level hooks timeout that Windows applies to trigger hooks; see . A related problem - slow JIT and loading of assemblies, which can make the CF too slow the first time; in some rare cases may even need to preload assemblies or pre-JIT functions to avoid the timeout warning.
In CF never use functions that generate keyboard or mouse events or activate windows.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs.NextTrigger
member.summary: Sets callback function for the next added trigger. If the trigger has a window scope, the callback function is called after evaluating the window. This function is used with triggers of all types.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs.NextTriggerBeforeWindow
member.summary: Sets callback function for the next added trigger. If the trigger has a window scope, the callback function is called before evaluating the window. This function is used with triggers of these types: hotkey, autotext, mouse.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs.FollowingTriggers
member.summary: Sets callback function for multiple triggers added afterwards. If the trigger has a window scope, the callback function is called after evaluating the window. This function is used with triggers of all types. The value can be null.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs.FollowingTriggersBeforeWindow
member.summary: Sets callback function for multiple triggers added afterwards. If the trigger has a window scope, the callback function is called before evaluating the window. This function is used with triggers of these types: hotkey, autotext, mouse. The value can be null.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions
member.summary: Allows to set some options for multiple triggers and their actions.
member.remarks: You set options through a thread-static property . Changed options are applied to all triggers/actions added afterwards in this thread.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.Thread(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Run actions always in the same dedicated thread that does not end when actions end.
member.param: A number that you want to use to identify the thread. Can be 0-127. Default 0.

Defines when to start an action if an action (other or same) is currently running in this thread. If 0 (default), don't run. If -1 (Timeout.Infinite), run when that action ends (and possibly other queed actions). If > 0, run when that action ends, if it ends within this time from now; the time is in milliseconds.
No warning when cannot start an action because an action is running and ifRunningWaitMS==0.
member.remarks: Multiple actions in same thread cannot run simultaneously. Actions in different threads can run simultaneously. There is no "end old running action" feature. If need it, use other script. Example: Triggers.Hotkey["Ctrl+M"] = o => ATask.RunWait("Other Script");. There is no "temporarily pause old running action to run new action" feature. As well as for scripts. The thread has . There are several ThreadX functions. Only the last called function is active. If none called, it is the same as called this function without arguments.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.ThreadMain
member.summary: Run trigger actions in same thread as Triggers.Run();.
member.remarks: The action must be as fast as possible, else it will block triggers etc. Use to create and show toolbars (). Rarely used for other purposes.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.ThreadNew(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Run trigger actions in new threads.
member.param: Don't run if this action is already running. If false, multiple action instances can run paralelly in multiple threads.
Don't set .
member.remarks: The action can run simultaneously with other actions.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.ThreadPool(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Run trigger actions in thread pool threads.
member.param: Don't run if this action is already running. If false, multiple action instances can run paralelly in multiple threads.
member.remarks: The action can run simultaneously with other actions. May start later if the pool is busy. You should know how to use thread pool correctly. The action runs in the .NET thread pool through .

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.BeforeAction
member.summary: A function to run before the trigger action. For example, it can set options.

example.code: Triggers.Options.BeforeAction = o => { AOpt.Key.KeySpeed = 20; AOpt.Key.TextSpeed = 5; };

example.code: Triggers.Options.AfterAction = o => { if(o.Exception!=null) AOutput.Write(o.Exception.Message); else AOutput.Write("completed successfully"); };

member.summary: Adds an autotext trigger.
member.param: The action runs when the user types this text and a postfix character or key. By default case-insensitive.
Options. If omitted or null, uses . Some flags are used by .
Postfix type (character, key, any or none). If omitted or null, uses ; default - a non-word character or the Ctrl key.
Postfix characters used when postfix type is Char or CharOrKey (default). If omitted or null, uses ; default - non-word characters.
member.exception: - Text is empty or too long. Can be 1 - 100 characters. - Postfix characters contains letters or digits.
Cannot add triggers after Triggers.Run was called, until it returns.

member.remarks: If null (default), postfix characters are all except alpha-numeric (see ). The value cannot contain alpha-numeric characters (exception) and characters (triggers will not work). For Enter use \r.
member.exception: The value contains letters or digits.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.AutotextTriggers.PostfixKey
member.summary: The postfix key for all triggers where postfix type is or (default). Can be Ctrl (default), Shift, LCtrl, RCtrl, LShift or RShift.
member.exception: The value is not Ctrl or Shift.
member.remarks: This property is applied to all triggers, not just to those added afterwards.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.AutotextTriggers.WordCharsPlus
member.summary: Additional word characters (non-delimiters). Default: null.
member.remarks: By default, only alpha-numeric characters ( returns true) are considered word characters. You can use this property to add more word characters, for example "_#". This is used to avoid activating triggers when a trigger text found inside a word. This property is applied to all triggers, not just to those added afterwards.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TKFlags
member.summary: Flags of hotkey triggers.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.ShareEvent
member.summary: Allow other apps to receive the key down message too. Without this flag, other apps usually receive only modifier keys. Also, OS always receives Ctrl+Alt+Delete and some other hotkeys. To receive and block key messages is used a low-level hook. Other hooks may receive blocked messages or not, depending on when they were set.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.KeyModUp
member.summary: Run the action when the key and modifier keys are released.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.LeftMod
member.summary: The trigger works only with left-side modifier keys.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.RightMod
member.summary: The trigger works only with right-side modifier keys.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.NoModOff
member.summary: Don't release modifier keys. Without this flag, for example if trigger is ["Ctrl+K"], when the user presses Ctrl and K down, the trigger sends Ctrl key-up event, making the key logically released, although it is still physically pressed. Then modifier keys don't interfer with the action. However functions like and (and any such functions in any app) will not know that the key is physically pressed; there is no API to get physical key state. Unreleased modifier keys will interfere with mouse functions like . Will not interfere with keyboard and clipboard functions of this library, because they release modifier keys, unless AOpt.Key.NoModOff is true. Will not interfere with functions that send text, unless AOpt.Key.NoModOff is true and AOpt.Key.TextOption is KTextOption.Keys.. Other flags that prevent releasing modifier keys: KeyUp, ShareEvent. Then don't need this flag.

member.summary: Mouse wheel direction for mouse wheel triggers.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TMEdge
member.summary: Screen edge for mouse edge triggers.
member.remarks: To activate a screen edge trigger, the user touches a screen edge with the mouse pointer. Each screen edge is divided into 3 parts: 1 - center 50%; 2 - left or top 25%; 3 - right or bottom 25%. Constants like TopInCenter50 specify an edge and part; the trigger works only in that part of that edge. Constants like Top specify just an edge; the trigger works in all parts of that edge.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TMMove
member.summary: Mouse movement directions for mouse move triggers.
member.remarks: To activate a mouse move trigger, the user quickly moves the mouse pointer to the specified direction and back. The screen is divided into 3 parts: 1 - center 50%; 2 - left or top 25%; 3 - right or bottom 25%. Constants like UpDownInCenter50 specify a direction and screen part; the trigger works only in that screen part. Constants like UpDown specify just a direction; the trigger works in whole screen.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TMScreen
member.summary: Screen index for mouse triggers.

member.summary: Run the action when called, if the window then is active (for ActiveOnce etc triggers) or visible (for VisibleOnce etc triggers).

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TWFlags.LaterCallFunc
member.summary: When using the later parameter, call the currently active Triggers.FuncOf functions on "later" events too. If the function returns false, the action will not run. The function runs synchronously in the same thread that called Triggers.Run. The action runs asynchronously in another thread, which is slower to start. As always, Triggers.FuncOf functions must not contain slow code; should take less than 10 ms.

member.summary: Became invisible. This event also occurs when closing the window, if it was visible; then the window possibly is already destroyed, and the handle is invalid. This event occurs when changed the property, and not when changed the property.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.WindowTriggers.SimulateActiveNew(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Simulates event "activated new window" as if the the specified window is that window.
member.exception: Cannot be before or after Triggers.Run.
member.remarks: This function usually is used to run ActiveNew triggers for a window created before calling . Here "run triggers" means "compare window properties etc with those specified in triggers and run actions of triggers that match". Normally such triggers don't run because the window is considered old. This function runs triggers as it was a new window. Triggers like ActiveNew and ActiveOnce will run once, as usually. This function must be called while the main triggers thread is in Triggers.Run, for example from another trigger action. It is asynchronous (does not wait). If you call this function from another trigger action (hotkey etc), make sure the window trigger action runs in another thread or can be queed. Else both actions cannot run simultaneously. See example.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.WindowTriggers.SimulateVisibleNew(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Simulates event "visible new window" as if the specified window is that window. Similar to .
member.exception: Cannot be before or after Triggers.Run.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.WindowTriggers.LogEvents(System.Boolean,System.Func{Au.AWnd,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Starts or stops to log (write in output) window events that can help to create or debug window triggers.
member.param: Start (true) or stop.
An optional callback function that can be used to reduce noise, eg skip tooltip windows. Return true to skip that window.
member.remarks:
For primary trigger events is logged this info:
Time milliseconds. Shows only the remainder of dividing by 10 seconds, therefore it starts from 0 again when reached 9999 (9 seconds and 999 milliseconds).
Event (see ).
Letters for window state etc:
A - the window is active.
H - the window is invisible (!).
C - the window is cloaked ().
O - the window is considered old, ie created before calling Triggers.Run.
T - the even has been detected using a timer, which means slower response time. Else detected using a hook.
Window (handle, class, name, program, rectangle).
Colors are used for window event types used for primary triggers: blue if activated; green if became visible; yellow if name changed. For "later" events is logged time, event and window. Black, tab-indented. Only events that are specified in triggers. When a trigger is activated, the event type is red.

example.code: Triggers.Window.LogEvents(true, o => 0 != o.ClassNameIs("*tooltip*", "SysShadow", "#32774", "TaskList*"));

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.WindowTriggers._LogEvent(Au.Triggers.TWLater,Au.AWnd,Au.Triggers.WindowTriggers._ProcCaller,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called by _Proc.

member.name: T:Au.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Main classes of the automation library, except triggers.

member.name: T:Au.AWnd
member.summary: A variable of AWnd type represents a window or control. It is a window handle, also known as HWND.
member.remarks:
AWnd functions can be used with windows and controls of any process/thread. Also can be used with .NET form/control and WPF window class variables, like AWnd w=(AWnd)form; w.Method(...); or ((AWnd)form).Method(...);.
There are two main types of windows - top-level windows and controls. Controls are child windows of top-level windows.
More functions are in the nested classes - , etc. They are used mostly in programming, rarely in automation scripts.
What happens when an AWnd function fails: - Functions that get window properties don't throw exceptions. They return false/0/null/empty. Most of them support , and it is mentioned in function documentation. - Many functions that change window properties throw exception. Exceptions are listed in function documentation. Almost all these functions throw only . - Other functions that change window properties return false. They are more often used in programming than in automation scripts. - When a 'find' function does not find the window or control, it returns default(AWnd) (window handle 0). Then will return true. - If a function does not follow these rules, it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions fail if the window's process has a higher [](xref:uac) integrity level (aministrator, uiAccess) than this process, unless this process has uiAccess level. Especially the functions that change window properties. Some functions that still work: Activate, ActivateLL, ShowMinimized, ShowNotMinimized, ShowNotMinMax, Close.
The AWnd type can be used with native Windows API functions without casting. Use AWnd for the parameter type in the declaration, like [DllImport(...)] static extern bool NativeFunction(AWnd hWnd, ...).
See also: MSDN article Window Features.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.op_Implicit(Au.Types.Native.HWND)~Au.AWnd
member.summary: Converts from a special handle value.
member.param: See API SetWindowPos.

member.summary: Gets the window handle as AWnd from a System.Windows.Forms.Control (or Form etc) variable. Returns default(AWnd) if w is null or the handle is still not created.
member.remarks: Like , but does not throw exception if null. Should be called in control's thread. Calls and .

member.summary: Gets the window handle as AWnd from a System.Windows.Window variable (WPF window). Returns default(AWnd) if w is null or the handle is still not created.

member.summary: Miscellaneous window-related functions and classes. Rarely used, or useful only for programmers.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.PostThreadMessage(System.Int32,System.Int32,Au.Types.LPARAM,Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Posts a message to the message queue of the specified thread. Of this thread if threadId is 0. Calls API PostThreadMessage. Returns false if failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.WaitForAnActiveWindow
member.summary: Waits while there is no active window. It sometimes happens after closing, minimizing or switching the active window, briefly until another window becomes active. Waits max 500 ms, then returns false if there is no active window. Processes Windows messages that are in the message queue of this thread. Don't need to call this after calling functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.EnableActivate
member.summary: Temporarily enables this process to activate windows with API SetForegroundWindow. Returns false if fails (unlikely). In some cases you may need this function because Windows often disables SetForegroundWindow to not allow applications to activate their windows while the user is working (using keyboard/mouse) with the currently active window. Then SetForegroundWindow just makes the window's taskbar button flash which indicates that the windows wants attention. More info: SetForegroundWindow. Usually you don't call SetForegroundWindow directly. It is called by some other functions, for example Form.Show. Don't need to call this function before calling and other functions of this library that activate windows.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.WindowRectFromClientRect(Au.Types.RECT@,Au.Types.WS,Au.Types.WS2,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calculates window rectangle from client area rectangle and style. Calls API AdjustWindowRectEx.
member.param: Input - client area rectangle in screen. Output - window rectangle in screen.
member.remarks: Ignores styles WS_VSCROLL, WS_HSCROLL and wrapped menu bar.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.BorderWidth(Au.Types.WS,Au.Types.WS2)
member.summary: Calculates window border width from style.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.BorderWidth(Au.AWnd)

member.summary: Calls API GetGUIThreadInfo. It gets info about mouse capturing, menu mode, move/size mode, focus, caret, etc.
member.param: API GUITHREADINFO.
Thread id. If 0 - the foreground (active window) thread. See , .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.RegisterWindowClass(System.String,Au.Types.Native.WNDPROC,Au.Types.RWCEtc)
member.summary: Registers new window class in this process.
member.param: Class name.

Delegate of a window procedure. See Window Procedures.
Use null when you need a different delegate (method or target object) for each window instance; create windows with or . If not null, it must be a static method; create windows with any other function, including API CreateWindowEx.

Can be used to specify more fields of WNDCLASSEX that is passed to API RegisterClassEx. Defaults: hCursor = arrow; hbrBackground = COLOR_BTNFACE+1; style = CS_GLOBALCLASS; others = 0/null/default. This function also adds CS_GLOBALCLASS style.
member.exception: wndProc is an instance method. Must be static method or null. If need instance method, use null here and pass wndProc to .
The class already registered with this function and different wndProc (another method or another target object).
Failed, for example if the class already exists and was registered not with this function.
member.remarks: Calls API RegisterClassEx. The window class is registered until this process ends. Don't need to unregister. If called next time for the same window class, does nothing if wndProc is equal to the previous (or both null). Then ignores etc. Throws exception if different. Thread-safe. Protects the wndProc delegate from GC.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.Is0
member.summary: Returns true if the window handle is 0 (this variable == default(AWnd)).

example.code: AWnd w = AWnd.Find("Window*"); if(w.Is0) { AOutput.Write("window not found"); return; }

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsAlive
member.summary: Returns true if the window exists (the window handle is valid). Returns false if the handle is 0 or invalid. Invalid non-0 handle usually means that the window is closed/destroyed.
member.remarks: Calls and API IsWindow. Although an AWnd variable holds a window handle, which is like a reference to a window, it does not prevent closing that window and making the handle invalid. After closing the window, the OS can even assign the same handle value to a new window, although normally it can happen only after long time. Use this carefully with windows of other applications or threads. The window can be closed at any moment, even when your thread is still in this function.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsVisible
member.summary: Returns true if the window is visible. Returns false if is invisible or is a child of invisible parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.remarks:
Calls API IsWindowVisible. Does not call .
Even when this function returns true, the window may be actually invisible. It can be cloaked, on an inactive Windows 10 virtual desktop (cloaked), inactive Windows Store app (cloaked), transparent, zero-size, minimized, off-screen, covered by other windows or can have zero-size window region.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsVisibleAndNotCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if returns true and returns false.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.IsVisibleIn_(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Returns true if this window is visible in the specified parent or ancestor window. Like , but does not check the visibility of the specified parent/ancestor window.
member.param: Parent or ancestor window.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Show(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window.
member.remarks: Does not activate/deactivate/zorder. This window can be of any thread. If you know it is of this thread, use . This function calls it.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ShowLL(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window.
member.returns: Returns false if fails. Supports .
member.remarks:
Does not activate/deactivate/zorder.
There are two similar functions to show/hide a window: - is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It calls ShowLL, and throws exception if it fails. Adds a small delay if the window is of another thread. - ShowLL is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. It is low-level. Does not throw exceptions. Does not add a delay. But both functions can be used with windows of any thread.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.IsEnabled(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns true if the window is enabled for mouse and keyboard input. Returns false if disabled. Also false if failed (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.param: Check whether all ancestors of this control are enabled too. If false (default), this function simply calls API IsWindowEnabled, which usualy returns true for controls in disabled windows.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Enable(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables. Calls API EnableWindow.
member.param: Enable or disable.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsCloakedGetState
member.summary: Gets the cloaked state. Returns 0 if not cloaked or if failed. Else returns flags: 1 cloaked by its application, 2 cloaked by Windows, 4 cloaked because its owner window is cloaked. On Windows 7 returns 0 because there is no "cloaked window" feature.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if the window is cloaked. Returns false if not cloaked or if failed. On Windows 7 returns false because there is no "cloaked window" feature. Windows 10 uses window cloaking mostly to hide windows on inactive desktops. Windows 8 - mostly to hide Windows Store app windows.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsMinimized

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsMaximized
